This has to be the best value hotel in Manhattan! We travelled as a party of three, two of whom were in NYC for the first time. The "room" is essentially an apartment, and  was incredibly spacious: one bedroom with a huge king bed, one bedroom with two twins, plus a large lounge, kitchen and bathroom. It was perfect for being able to retreat to when we'd had a huge day of walking. The location was brilliant: two blocks from the Rockefeller Centre, 20 minutes walk from Empire State building, and about five minutes walk to Grand Central Station, from where we could get anywhere. There's also a subway station right around the corner that we used almost every day.  The staff were incredibly friendly, especially Maria who welcome us off a long flight. She spent time to give us detailed directions and helpful tips, and it was a great start to our stay.  The rooms aren't fancy, but they're clean and have everything you need, with very comfortable beds. The hotel is undoubtedly in a great location close to several subway stations and lower Manhattan. It's within walking distance of Chinatown, The Brooklyn Bridge and South Ferry. Though if you're after evening nightlife and restaurants, you will have to walk at least a few blocks as most of the places in the immediate vicinity are closed after normal working hours. The hotel itself is decent enough, it's got all the amenities needed and has very spacious rooms for the area. It is let down however by its general state of repair and a feeling of lack of care. The whole place feels very dated and rough around the edges, you've got scratched and scuffed walls and paint, broken picture frames, furniture full of marks and scratches. It just feels like it needs a complete refurb and it was maybe nice like 10-15 years ago. In terms of cleaning. The room seemed clean enough when we arrived, though the pillows sticking out of the cases did have some stains. But the standard of housekeeping throughout our stay was very basic. They just came in and made the bed, emptied the bin, folded the towels and replenished the toilet paper. It didn't even seem like they had swept the floor, they didn't replace the glasses in the bathroom. The worst though was that on two occasions our room was left open and unlocked by the housekeeping staff. It seemed that the door should slam shut and lock when closed but it just stayed ajar if not pulled closed. We mentioned this to the receptionist who sent someone to "fix" it, but it happened again! Luckily nothing was taken but literally anyone could have walked into our room whilst we were out which made us feel a little anxious whilst out during the day.

I have four major complaints, each of which is independently reason enough to never stay at The Ridge again.  1 - A Standard Double on Booking.com (a “Full” room in Ridge terminology) claims to be 200 square feet, 50% more than the actual area of 130 square feet.  I verified this with a measuring tape.  200 square feet is not a rounding error, it is fraud!  The total area includes shower, toilet, bed, etc., by the way, not space to move around.  Walking space, including in the bathroom, is about 60-65 square feet.2 – When I called the hotel (there are no live people; the hotel provides “touchless” service) to point out the discrepancy between actual and stated size, I asked if I could move to a room that was closer to the advertised 200 square feet.  The employee agreed to move me the next day.  So, I packed up the next morning and left my things to be transferred to a new room – which turned out to be exactly same size! 3 – The first room got too hot (77 degrees); however, the new room was hotter.  I woke up sweating at 2:30 am to blasting hot air and a temperature of 86 degrees and rising!  Only by running an air conditioning unit 24 hours a day was I able to get the room down to the lower 70’s – while the temperature ranged from 42 to 55 degrees outside.  If the room overheats that badly in the fall, what would it be like in the summer?  4 – The bed was so hard, I had to put an inflatable pillow under my hip bone to sleep on my side.  I could go on about lower-priority complaints, like the tedious online check-in process, lack of table and chair (though “all rooms have them”, I was told on the phone), harsh lighting, lack of decaf coffee, inconvenient outlets, and cheap construction, but none of these were deal-breakers like the four issues described above.When in NYC, find yourself an ethically run hotel that covers all the basics and delivers on its promises – not The Ridge!

My wife and I flew to NYC for a family visit. We travel there at least twice a year. This particular vacation was fraught with disasterous airline/FAA controllers issues. We were trapped in NYC for an extra week because of the enormous amounts of cancelled flights. We booked the Belleclaire for our forced extended stay due to our familiarity with the hotel (we have stayed there before).  Let me first tell you that we have always enjoyed our stay at this hotel. But, it was quite conforting to know that even though we were stuck in NYC for an extra week, we would be well taken care of by the hotel and staff. The staff, all of them, from management to the regular employees are wonderful. They are responsive to requests, they help you with transportation and things to do and see. We also couldnt ask for a cleaner hotel. They really take pride in their appearance and it shows. I mean, come on, this is NYC, the land of tourism! You would think that with that much foot trafffic coming and going, the place would be kind of run down, worn out. I assure you that it is not. An additionak benefit is the most lovely french cafe in the lobby, yes it does get quite busy, but people like good things so the crowds can grow for the cafe alait and pastries. The location of the hotel on the upper west side is perfect. When in NYC you tend to walk a lot! This hotel is centrally situated and is walkable to most spots you would want to visit. The subway system is still decent in NYC and this hotel is close to the subway lines. The added benefit for us, is the location to Columbus Ave, Broadway and Amsterdam Ave. Theses streets on the UWS contain so many restaurants and bodegas that you will be able to eat, whatever tye of food you want, whenever you want. The room size was not what was advertised & no larger rooms were available (I am an Honors member). The only positive is very nice staff. We did not complain about the smoking just tolerated it.  It was a 3 night trip & we were not in our room a lot. I will never stay here again & resent that I ended up with physical issues due to other idiots smoking/vaping. The worst hotel I have ever experienced!  I checked out within 30 minutes of arriving.  The primary issue was the ill fitted single glazed window which allowed a very strong draught to blow constantly into the room.  The draught was so severe it was like being outside, I am certain I would have got pneumonia or worse had i stayed a night.  The bed was right next to the window and could not be moved due to the size of the room.  There was a little heater below the window which made an unbearable noise but gave out virtually no heat and certainly not enough to compensate for the draught.  Other more minor matters was that the room was presumably last decorated in the 1970's with furnitureto match.  The bed springs were completely gone and the bedding was  green color with evident stains from use over a many number of years.  The bathroom was dirty, full of grime and mold, I am glad I did not need to bathe there.  I asked initially to change the room and was told they were all the same, so i checked out.  The only positive I can say about this hotel is the location, but for not much extra there are far nicer hotels close by.I asked for a refund and the manager replied not even apologising and stating they "do not issue refunds for the room being a little cold"; they completely ignored everything I had written.  They obviously had no interest except keeping my money.  I have therefore raised a section 75 claim on.my credit card for a refund, as the roon was not only not as advertised but was a health hazard.Honestly do not stay at this hotel.  It is worse than any hostel or hotel I have seen in any other country.

I was having trouble with my bank. And was issued another card, but it didn't come by the time I had to leave. Found a way to use Google pay and that helped a little. Told her the situation with the bank, she didn't care. Showed her my account that the money in it. She didn't care. I asked if they could punch in the numbers, or if there's anything they could do to help. She said no, that they need a card. She was about to toss me out on the street, on my vacation/honeymoon, and wouldn't figure a way to help me. She just stood there, looked at me, and said sorry, we need a card. After she left, the guy behind the counter took a risk to help me out. Somehow he had the computer except my google pay, my wife's card, and got to where I was able to pay 7 out of 10 nights of my stay. So that gave me enough time to fix the issues and pay the rest of my stay. Thanks to Terrence Conseillant!! He hung in there and did everything he could to help me out. If something failed, he said let's try something else. Then after that didn't work after awhile, he said hold on we'll figure this out. Not only did he help out with the issue, but he also found out the situation that google pay was giving me. If I was able to give Terrence Conseillant a rating, it would have to be a 10!

You don't expect to get poor service, all your food cooked incorrectly, and vague racism at a place like the Carlyle, but that's what happened. Such a strange night.    Just the facts, no opinions here:  - Asked for medium rare salmon, got well done, no pink; asked for medium lamb, got rare, fully red. That's $95 right there, done wrong. Salmon wasn't hot when served.  - When we were sat, 30 min before anyone came to take a drink order, even though there were 7 of them walking around this small dining room in their suits, with only about 7 tables to serve. While we saw with nothing but menus, one of the men chatted that entire time with a tall blonde who was eating alone. During the whole night, no-one ever even said they'll be our waiter: the person who did wait on us said "I'm *above* the waiters, I'm the *captain*".  - Ordered flat bottled water, they poured sparkling.  - Waiter saw my emptied plate and said "I see you enjoyed the salmon!", so I had to tell him about the problems, he immediately went to the manager, she came over. I described the problems with the entrees and no-one coming to our table, showed a photo of my salmon that I took before finishing it, showed her an untouched cut of the lamb.   - She apologised, took both our entrees off our bill. - At the end of the night, we were told our entire bill was on the house. We had the salmon, lamb, bottled water, and 3 drinks from the bar (cocktails are $28 and up), that would be at least $175, though I never saw the bill.  - I said to the waiter, "That's very gracious of you, thank you, I was a waiter for many years and I never saw that done for anyone". He replied "Yes, well, the woman seated behind me is the general manager for the *hotel*, and she saw the whole thing". I'm assuming "the whole thing" refers to me trying in vain to waive down a waiter to place an order, returning the sparkling for the flat, describing the problems to the manager, etc. She saw the entire team fail at every turn, from the smallest things to the largest, front of house to back of house.   So I was feeling like they had really addressed the issues, but that's when things got REALLY weird. The waiter, who was white (the entire staff was white), then randomly told us a very long weird story that inexplicably was about three unrelated people of color, two of those anecdotes being related to their sexuality. The monologue began with "I'm not a racist" -- it was inexplicable why he included that. "I had a roommate in college, she was a -- this is a weird word -- a *mulatto*, it means half black half white, she used to walk into the common area *topless* to get coffee in the morning... We never *asked* her to do that, she just did it... I used to have a coworker who was black -- *African American* -- I once said to her, we need to hire more black people, she laughed and said 'I *am* black' -- I'd forgotten she was black, ha ha ha... One of the lifeguards in college, I thought he was black, he had brown skin and the kinky hair, turned out he was Spanish, he was really buff, several girls would come talk to him at the same time while he was on duty". My gf and I aren't black and no-one ever mentioned anything about black people, so his long monologue about three people of color was mystifyingly out of the blue.   The website for the Carlyle says this: "Unparalleled among Upper East Side restaurants, The Carlyle's New York fine dining establishments set the bar for culinary artistry and flawless service." Tonight they were unparalleled only in that no other restaurant I've been to in my 23 years of living in Manhattan managed to fail in so many areas.…

I do not recommend staying at St. Mark's Hotel. First red flag when I arrived: no smoke detector in the room. I immediately alerted the staff to this alarming lack of fire safety - and it took 3 days and several follow-ups for a properly functioning smoke detector to be installed. At one point, a staff member put an old one on the ceiling that only had 2 out of 3 batteries in it - and of course wasn't working properly, contrary to his assurance that it was working "totally fine". It felt like I was being treated as dumb. On top of this, my request for a discount for the last night of my stay due to this substandard service was flat-out refused - the employee said that "we never give any discounts, even when there are complaints". I would have left early and switched accomodations if it hadn't been for a busy schedule and the fact that the conference I was attending was in walking distance.Other things weren't great either: no fan or window in the bathroom, constant noise of running water from somewhere inside the walls in the bathroom, cigarette burns in the duvet cover, a window that could not be opened properly (it was a guillotine window where the panel did not click into place when pushed up), and payment is cash only (very inconvenient). At US$150 (incl tax) a night for a room with a queen bed, St Mark's is relatively affordable for Manhattan. However, I have stayed at much cheaper hostels with dormitories in the past that were in better condition and had better service than this place. Next time I want a private room in Manhattan I'd rather pay a bit more. St. Mark's Hotel gets one point for location (very central near Astor Place metro, NYU campus, Washington Square Park) and one point for the room+bathroom being clean.

Rooms were clean and tidy.  Beds were comfortable.  This is in a sketchy part of town and I would not stay here again no matter the cost.  The front desk offered a limo ride to LGA when my husband had to leave before the rest of the family.  Price was quoted for $65 and was indeed what he paid plus a tip.  Hours later same day when they offered the rest of the family a ride to LGA was quoted $65 and I asked at least twice no added fees?  Once we arrived at LGA, driver said $10 for tolls ( REALLY ?)  and suddenly it was $85 !!  Don't know what the other 10 dollars was for.  So I recommend NOT GOING WITH ANY TRANSPORTATION THEY OFFER TO SET UP FOR YOU.  Make it easy on yourself.  UBER everywhere you go and you know the exact price and there are NO SURPRISES.  Cabs in NY add fees so watch out.  BEWARE.  In fact, they set up a cab another time and got the address wrong where we were going and we told the driver again the address and he went the wrong way and we had to pay for it.  Do not trust them.  Get an UBER.

2 days before we were due to fly to New York I  noticed a pending charge on my card for £528.74, puzzled,  thought  my option is to pay in full on arrival.    After our plane was delayed for 4 hours from Dublin we arrived at Tempo NY Hilton Times Square at 11pm on 23rd Dec shattered, stressed, tired and disappointed we missed out  on the daytime sight seeing because we should have arrived in the afternoon. The hotel lobby has a beautiful entrance which gave us a big lift from our damped  spirits.  I enquired at the check in desk about the pending charge on my card - Tempo NY Hilton Times were holding £528.74  since 21st Dec which had limited my spending power I was told it will be refunded back to my account once  we checked out.  So I Paid the room in full however I kept asking what were the charges the staff would not say and tried to take payment from my card which would not go through my bank blocked Tempo!!! After confirming authorised with my bank  payment went through smoothly.  Next morning found I was charge almost double for the room.  So I still have  a pending charge holding my £528.74  plus I was charged a room with 2 queen beds  for £451.92 (tax, service already included and already paid in full )  and a security deposit was taken for £161.89 which is still at pending stage all of this for 1 NiGHT stay!!!!!!!!!  We are still in New York and my trip  ruined with this continuous enquiry, emails etc a  week has passed, the pending charge for £528.74 is still ongoing inclining the security deposit I was told should be refunded 2-3 days after check out.  I complained to booking.com where I made the booking they raised it with Tempo NY who declined my complaint.  Furious I contacted Hilton Reservations and Customer Care Team.  Theyvacted swiftly, apologised profoundly about the confusion, frustrations etc and stated my booking was cancelled !!!! Hence I was charged late payment!!!  Strangely my booking invoice confirmed no cancellation.  Tempo took out another reservation and charged me again.  Also they states my 17 year old son made the booking in his name and  2 rooms were booked and late payment were charged to him ??!!!!!! I’ve never heard anything so ridiculous in my life. I thought 17 year stays free hence 2 queen beds were book for 1 room. So the theft Tempo NY Hilton still holding  my £528.74  and trying to bush everything under with this so called cancellation, son booking, making a long list of excuses with their ‘investigation’ , stay AWAY FROM THIS HOTEL they employed  dishonest devious staff who would do anything to mislead  and manipulate your booking and bill charge

We had read several reviews regarding this hotel prior to making our reservation, so we had a good idea of what to expect...Overall we were pleasantly surprised by the standard of both the hotel and rooms.When we travel and stay at hotels, we have 4 basic requirements for our accommodation; general good cleanliness of the facilities (common areas/rooms), shower/water pressure (and hot/cold water), comfortable/clean bed and friendly staff. This hotel ticked all these boxes with ease.The tempur-pedic beds (we booked another stay within the same week upon check-out after our first stay) in both our rooms were some of best ones we've ever experienced, it was a joy to take a hot shower (and bath) during the cold November days and the staff were always friendly, knowledgeable and greeted you with a smile every time you passed through the lobby/reception area. And as many reviewers before us, a special shout out needs to go to Seki and Gina - you won't find better people in any hotel anywhere.The continental breakfast (served between 07:00-10:00 AM) also outdid our expectations. As we've travelled a lot in Europe, a continental breakfast usually means a few slices of white toast, jam/jelly/marmelade and maybe a cup of watered down coffee.To find both delicious bagels with several choices of cream cheese, yoghurts, fruit and pastries with your coffee/tea - together with the beautiful skyline views over the city (breakfast is served on the 20th floor) - wasn't the worst way to start off your day, on the contrary.And as others have mentioned, in the afternoons, before heading out to dinner, they offered wine hour everyday (free of charge) between 5:00-6:00 PM, on the same floor, this time accompanied by nighttime views of the same skyline.Yes, the hotel in general - and the rooms - have some wear and tear to it/them which we're certain will be rectified once their renovations are completed.We would like to point out, that the staff was more than welcoming to receive, and took notes, on any feedback you would give them during your stay in regards to the hotel and its facilities in order to take the necessary action either immediately or to be added to their "renovations list" for the future. Always with a smile and thank you.Overall we felt that, all of the main features were in order, so we didn't care if the elevator upholstery is dated - it took us up and down all the floors safely, and fast, we might add.Could the breakfast and wine hour area (on the 20th floor) use a minor 'makeover' with dimmed lighting, a few more plants, candles on the tables, some Ibiza chill tunes (playing during wine hour) and a generally cozier atmosphere? Definitely.But we enjoyed our fresh breakfast every morning while watching the sunrise and in the evenings we enjoyed small talking for an hour and a few glasses of rosé wine on the house - so what's not to like - if you've seen the prices for a glass of wine in any NYC restaurant.We have stayed at several different hotels and locations throughout the years in NYC when visiting, but this is the first time we honestly can say that we know that we will come back the next time we're in town - it was simply the perfect fit for us and our budget.Well done Hotel on Rivington!

We were quickly checked in at 9 pm by a friendly receptionist. We got two rooms on the 4th floor. If you book a room with one bed, it will face the street and be noisy, noise insulation is non-existent so you will hear all the garbage trucks at 3 am and everything else. If you book a room with two beds, it will face the back and have no view, but be quieter.  The best thing about this hotel is room size. By New York standards, the rooms are huge and even by normal standards, they are largeish for a three-star hotel. The hotel has gone through a complete makeover when they changed owners a few years ago, and the rooms are in good condition, albeit rather ascetic. The beds are comfortable and there are plenty of sockets by the bed. All sockets are of the US type, so bring an adapter if needed. There is a large desk (with more sockets), a luggage rack, a fridge, and in the rooms with one bed, there is an armchair as well, but no coffee table even if there would be room for one. Amenities include a safe, a bathrobe and slippers, but no bottled water. The AC is efficient but a bit noisy. Wifi was free, fast and unlimited, although it required a few log-ins every day.  The bathroom isn't large, but okay. It comes with your typical American shallow bathtub which is not really suitable for taking a bath. There is a handheld shower with only adequate but not great  water pressure. Soap, shampoo, conditioner, bath gel and body lotion come in tamper-proof wall-mounted containers and are C. O. Bigelow branded, which is well-suited for NYC.  There is no breakfast offered at the hotel. There are several breakfast options nearby, some more crowded than others and all insanely expensive.  While the receptionists and maids were friendly, the security guard was way out of line, having guests run up and down for restroom keys that weren't really needed and making up his own rules about which of the two staircases should be used. Perhaps he would be better off working somewhere other than a hotel.  The hotel enjoys a great location on 35th Street, half a block from the E train that takes you to JFK and close to several subways, shopping and eating options etc.  We paid $365 a night, including all taxes and "resort fees". I would gladly give the hotel four green dots if the price were a hundred dollars less per night, but at these price levels, even with the large rooms, it doesn't deserve more than three dots. It is, after all, a very average three-star hotel with few services.…

We arrived on at the Shoreham Hotel the afternoon of November 23, Wednesday. That first night, when turning in, it was discovered that the bath water ran BROWN!  After letting it run in hopes it would clear, they called the front desk to ask for help. The engineer said he could do nothing about it, and other rooms also had this problem.  My room was okay, and my other son’s room was okay, but when I asked to move my son, his wife, and 2 kids to another room, they were told that wasn’t possible. The front desk said they could do nothing because the manager was not on duty, and we would have to take it up with her in the morning.  And the engineer will work on it all night because the whole wing is like that. So, the family went to bed without baths after a long day of travel.    The following day, I talked with Anna, the manager, and was told no report had been made from the night clerk or engineer, but she would give me credit for the room for the night and move my family to a different room. 609 on the other side of the building. I assumed the credit would be for the one-room one-night stay.  But when checking out I discovered the credit was only $50.00.  The irony is that when I called the booking.com number to report the problem, I was charged a 54.00 fee for an out-of-the-country call:(. So the credit I received wasn’t even enough to cover the call.   This was a rare family holiday for us, and this was a big disappointment after a full day of travel.  I want to receive the full credit for the one room for the first night.  That is only fair for the inconvenience and terrible Brown water problem. …

I have been a hotel guest at Aman twice in the past two months.The hotel is stunning and understated at once.  The décor and mood are soothing and details are attended to as expected in a hotel of this caliber.After two stays I have a few notes that would make the guest experience even more superb.We booked our stays using Amex Platinum (Fine Hotels + Resorts) which guarantees a 4pm late checkout amongst other perks.These were not reviewed nor discussed with us at our first stay. We were surprised by a phone call at noon on checkout day asking if we needed assistance with our luggage.  The Amex perks had not been applied.To Aman’s credit, during our second stay, they reviewed these perks specifically and adhered to them.We experienced the omakase at Nama which was fabulous.  We wished there was a sake pairing, but none is offered.The iPad in the room doesn’t display the menus at Nama or Arva nor does it allow for reservations to be made from the device.  This would be useful.The brunch/lunch menu at Arva was hit or miss and the menu had strong breakfast or dinner-ish options but skips over good lunch options (wraps, salads, sandwiches)I had a fabulous spa treatment. However, once changing into a robe and leaving the ladies’ locker room, usually there is a relaxation area to wait for your therapist to take you to the treatment room.  There is not a dedicated area for this, I could either wait in the sauna/steam room, in nice seating outside the locker room in the hallway, or inside the pool area.  Then my therapist had to walk us downstairs to the treatment rooms. I’d much prefer to go to a pre-treatment area near the treatment rooms to relax with some hot tea.For some reason we had issues during both stays getting items delivered to the room.During our first stay, we were met in our room by our butler, who asked how we take our coffee in the morning (there is a Nespresso in the room and sugar).  I said milk, which wasn’t brought.  We went out for the evening and forgot.  I called again in the morning for milk, and after about 30 minutes I just had black coffee.  The milk was never delivered.During our first and second stay, I called for a bucket of ice since we’d brought our own bottle of scotch.  The first stay I had to call twice.  On the first night of our second stay I had to call 3 times over an hour and a half before the ice was delivered.  On the second night, I called and asked for ice again, but after 45 minutes it hadn’t arrived.  My husband got frustrated and went looking for an ice machine (about 11pm).  He saw a staff member and explained the problem, the staff member was very concerned and we had a bucket of ice delivered in about 5 minutes.  Of note, upon our arrival the second stay I asked the butler for milk and it was delivered very promptly.  The takeaway here is there is there seems to be a defect in the communication/execution process for these small but meaningful requests.When we checked in for stay 2 we noticed the room was cold and used the IPad to adjust it to 70 degrees.  After dinner we came back and it was still cold, however we went to bed.  In the morning we addressed the concern with maintenance who promptly troubleshooted the issue.  The temperature control was locked to 60 degrees due to a prior guest's request.We received the wrong room on our second stay.  We booked the 56th street Premier Suite for the floor to ceiling windows and different layout, however after our stay we realized our room was a Sanctuary Suite facing 57th, which was smaller and lacked the floor plan we were expecting.None of these should deter any sane person from staying at Aman,  these observations are constructive feedback to an otherwise outstanding property.Update 8/24 we received our folio after 5 days (!) and we were charged for an open bottle of whiskey, which was open when we arrived. We brought to the attention of both the staff who came to restock the minibar and the front desk during our stay.  This is annoying.  The service is broadly good but details are lost.

I chose this hotel because of the price and location which is near Mt Sinai Beth Israel hospital. It was a rainy day and the hotel was easy to find. It is located at a corner. You go up a short flight of stairs and reach the small lobby. Front desk ladies are very professional and pleasant . Lobby was bare bones with a small seating area and a stand with some NYC brochures. The room was pretty basic. Doors had a good lock. Our Full Bed was clean , pillows were nice, plump enough and fresh and the white bed sheets were fresh and nicely starched. Air conditioner was newer and worked very well and the bathroom was also very clean. It was a relief to come to a nice cool room with a clean bed after a long day of walking around. However it isn’t a luxury hotel. The paint job on the walls is fresh but is poorly done and one of the black out curtains had one hook missing so the edge was dangling. The closet had an ironing board but no iron . The coffee table had one mug and a couple of packet of instant coffee and cream but no coffee maker. Turns out you have to walk to the front desk and ask for the iron and coffeemaker if you needed one. There was a small lcd TV which was working. There were two clean white bath towels in the bathroom but no hand towels . At least the towels were clean and fresh. The floor , shower curtain and the  tub was also newly scrubbed and very clean.  Toiletries were sparse . One single bottle of shampoo. They were out of soap bars. I had to go to the front desk and ask for more towels and another bottle of shampoo which they apologized for but gladly provided.  So, would I go back again in the future? Yes. For one night it is more than what I need.  It is a clean basic bed and shower place to crash into after a long day of walking. If I had to stay more than a night I would bring my own soap and coffee maker next time. …

What a wonderful hotel . My wife and I stayed for 3 nights right before Christmas . I find the New York City noise really relaxing . But as I said , this really wasn’t an issue and I’m just trying my best to think of one negative thing.  As it was Christmas , we paid quite a bit for our room but was still worth it . I checked prices out for out of season dates and they are well below what the hotel is worth per night .  Thanks to all the staff for making our stay so great. We shortlisted The Shelburne Sonesta for two main reasons - spacious rooms and the location and boy did it surpass our expectations on both these aspects and went beyond in so many other ways. In addition to spacious rooms (we opted for the 1-bed terrace suites), which we very well maintained & appointed, it was their service & hospitality that made our stays memorable. A special thanks to Petr, Gul, and their team for assisting us all through and ensuring our stay was nothing short of perfect.The property is located in the vicinity of Murray Hill and right on Lexington Avenue - it's a mere 5-minute walk from Grand Central - which is pretty much the main station to go around anywhere in the city. Within a radius of 10 minutes walking distance, you'll find multiple restaurants, bars & stores - most Indian restaurants in Lex are a few blocks away :)The hotel building is a heritage property albeit is very well maintained. The terraces extend a grand elevation to this stately structure. Inside they have a spacious lobby with a sizeable sitting area. They have a self-service laundromat, which is a brilliant utility to have onsite, and being so central one doesn't really miss a convenience store or a dining outlet.Our rooms (1-bed suite with a terrace) were unlike any other we've stayed-in at NY, meaning they were spacious and very much so. The hall had a working, dining, and sitting area with access to the terrace (more on the last part later), while the bedroom had a large king-sized bed and a sitting area. The rooms also had a kitchenette and enclosed storage areas. The rooms were clean and immaculately maintained, well-lit, and very well-appointed (with large LED televisions and plug points & USBs aplenty). The bathrooms are again spacious, though those with a bathtub can be a little difficult to access. The kitchenette is complete with a sink, refrigerator, coffee maker, and microwave - so very useful if you want to heat a snack or host someone. All things considered, the highlight of our rooms were the terraces (with one of them being exceptionally large) - they were resplendent with stunning views of the Manhattan skyline dotted with the Empire State Building, the One Vanderbilt, the Metlife facing us. One can spend countless mornings and evenings just watching them from here...While they currently don't have a functional restaurant but have one coming up in early-24 and maybe a rooftop bar - would love to try them when next staying hereThe service across the board was top-notch, and getting assistance from Gul & Petr while booking was priceless. The front desk was very accommodating to our request for early check-ins, they helped us with collecting our multiple Amazon parcels and consistently helped us in navigating our way across the city. That apart, their cloakroom staff, their doormen, and their housekeeping were always helpful, pleasant, and a pleasure to deal with. This culture & attitude is something that will make any hotelier proud of their set-up.All-in-all, our experience with the Shelburne Sonesta was nothing short was splendid. They went out of their way to make our stays memorable & comfortable. While at times, one can consider the hotel to be a tad expensive, it's definitely worth it for the sheer comfort, quality of service, locational convenience, and overall experience. I just spent three nights at this interesting hostel in NY. I enjoyed it very much. I ended up booking myself into this place because of the crazy prices of hotels in NY. And what a pleasant surprise! Of course, you have to be ready for a different experience. It is NOT a regular hotel. It suitable only for people travelling alone and you have to be happy with the basic minimum. No luxury at all. But you get a clean "pod" with everything you need for a good night sleep. Despite the pod being individual, soundwise you are not completely isolated from the other pods and so you are able to listen to anything is said in the other pods including.....snoring!:-) But nothing that a set of earplugs (provided by the management) cannot solve. And people are very respectful and keep quiet. The shared restrooms and showers are perfectly functional and clean. The 24/7 breakfast is simple but sufficient (plenty of fruit, cereals, juice, milk, yogurt). No coffee! Only tea and hot chocolate. And the spiritual touch invites you to meditate about what is important in life (books provided in your pod) and how many things we have are simply not necessary. If you are ready for something different and like travelling of the beaten tracks and do not need luxury....this could be your place! Plus...location is amazingly convenient. Literally 5 min walking from Penn station. And if you want to experience a Knicks game (as I did!), you just walk to the MSG. The staff is very nice and helpful.…
Your task is to classify consumer hotel review into one of the following ratings: ["1", "2", "3", "4", "5"], where "1" indicates very dissatisfied and "5" indicates very satisfied.

What a Bizarre Experience at the Leon Hotel.   My wife and I decided to book this hotel for the weekend due to its great location (it really is situated perfectly). On arrival, we were very happy to be able to store our bags at the front desk prior to check-in, as we arrived in the city far before the check-in time.  After check-in, we were happy to have a nice room with a good view. However, our first night at this hotel was honestly so bizarre and odd, and our subsequent encounters with hospital staff were so poor and gaslighting, that I cannot help but write a review about this experience in hopes that any future traveler won’t walk away from this hotel with such a ridiculous story.   My wife and I went to bed around 10pm on our first night. At roughly 1:15am, I awoke to the last ring of the hotel room phone, and before I could reach it, I heard my cell phone vibrating as well. When I checked my cell phone, I had three missed calls from Joseph, the front desk staff member, with three separate voicemail messages. My initial thought was something horrible must have happened, as that seemed to be the only rational reason to place so many calls so late at night.   I promptly called Joseph back, at which point I thought I must have still been sleeping when I heard his reason for the call. He told me that the woman who stayed in our room the previous night was in the hotel lobby stating that she had left a valuable item in the room’s safe and was needing to retrieve it (the safe must not have been checked and reset between guests).   Joseph had called the room phone, and my cell phone FOUR total times at 1am to…….wait for it….. inform me that a complete stranger (importantly, not management, but the woman herself) would need to enter our room where my wife was still sleeping at the time, to retrieve this mysterious valuable item at ONE-THIRTY IN THE MORNING.   After I made sure I wasn’t still dreaming after hearing that request, being a reasonable person, I stated that I understood the situation and would was happy to allow this previous guest to retrieve her item the following day, even first thing in the morning. However, being that I was paying in total over $300 a night to have a safe and private room, and being that my wife was still sleeping and that we had an early morning to prepare for, I was not comfortable allowing a complete stranger to enter our room in the middle of the night.  It was clear from Joseph’s response that this was not going to be an appropriate resolution to the problem, as he stated again that she needed to enter the room at that time (I found out the following day that the New York City Police were involved at this point). Ultimately, in an attempt to preserve our façade of privacy, I located the safe and saw that it was not secured to any solid structure in the room, and told Joseph that I would take the safe to them.   So, still not sure if I was dreaming about carrying out a jewelry heist, or simply following the remarkably persistent and untimely requests of the hotel front desk, there I was at 1:30am, carrying a hotel safe across my chest with a mysterious valuable object inside, through the hallway and down the elevator into the lobby. I went back to Booking.com and looked at the terms and conditions of our stay, and for some reason, I just could not find any place where it mentioned either allowing random strangers into our room in the middle of the night, or carrying safes into the lobby.   The next morning, after very little sleep after the safe-heist,  I approached the front desk to debrief on the evening’s events. I told the nice woman behind the counter that I was hoping to speak with Joseph in hopes of determining an appropriate compensatory discount to our stay for the significant disruption. She said that unfortunately Joseph was not working currently, but she told me not to worry, though, as they had already granted $20 off the previous night, and $50 off the following night for the inconvenience.  Considering the absurdity of the event and resulting lack of sleep, I told her that $70, which equates to 11% off our 2-night stay, simply did not seem sufficient. She told me again that Joseph was not working but that I could stop by that evening and speak to him, which I agreed to.   Surprisingly, though, 30 minutes later my wife and I came down from the room and there was Joseph, working behind the counter! Apart from an apology, we were told that there was absolutely no further compensation that would be provided in light of our disruption. In fact, he seemed profoundly surprised that I was not happy with the original compensatory discount. It honestly made me reconsider the absurdity of the event (I reconsidered it and decided that yes, it was still absurd).   I told him that his unwillingness to make the situation right was surprising, as it was clear that they valued the prior customer’s experience so much that he was willing to compromise our personal peace and privacy in the middle of the night to allow her to retrieve her item! He didn’t seem to appreciate the irony like I did.   Ultimately, no further compensation was provided, and while we had no further issues the following night, we left the Leon Hotel with nothing more than this bizarre story and a desire to never receive 4 calls from the Leon Hotel front desk in middle of the night ever again.   While the hotel itself is nice and the location is great, I am sure you can find a place to stay that will accommodate you as well as the Leon hotel accommodated the guest from the night prior to ours, and not how they accommodated us.…

Went here on an out-of-state study trip; nice place to stay as long as you know what to expect!Pros: The location was great, within walking distance to multiple subway stations, cafés and restaurants, shopping, and tourist destinations. The building itself is very secure and located right across from a police station. The accommodations, while basic, were clean and tidy, and the communal bathroom and shower appear to be cleaned twice a day. The staff I interacted with were friendly and more than happy to offer help. Not a lot of noise can be heard from the street, at least not from where I was staying. The communal kitchen, dining room, and courtyard were nice, and I enjoyed chatting with other students and travelers over breakfast.Cons: The hostel is definitely showing its age. There are no elevators and the staircases are pretty cramped (especially with luggage), so keep accessibility in mind when booking. There was no AC unit in my room, so I needed to sleep with a window open most nights. The communal shower took quite a bit to heat up, and some of my friends had problems with having to wait until housekeeping was done cleaning to use the bathroom or shower. The doors are also pretty loud, and while the people staying around me were quiet and respectful of others, I could hear doors opening and closing from throughout the building. Toiletries and some essentials are not provided (bring your own hand soap and a lock for your locker), but the hostel is close to multiple convenience stores.I’d recommend staying here as long as you don’t have 5-star hotel expectations and know what to expect, especially if you don’t plan to spend too much time in your room. If you go in expecting the Ritz, you’ll be disappointed; the Chelsea International isn’t luxury by any means, but it’s a nice enough place to stay and rest!

Overall, The Standard High Line is an icon, and was an honor to stay - though, I was a bit taken aback by the lack of service - both by the front desk staff and the Standard Grill employees. There's a level of aloofness that I can give grace for potentially being understaffed on a holiday; but nonetheless I would want it brought to my attention as a hotelier.   Secondly, a lot of the rooms are dated - the TVs in the rooms I experienced did not have a streaming option, and the lack of armature in the King/Queen suites left a relatively uncomfortable viewing angle.   In the bathroom/rain showers, pieces of the walls were wearing and chipping from water damage, and our in-room menus and printed brochures were riddled with stains and worn paper.  The redeeming factor is the food and drink itself, one of the best meals I've had in-room in 20 years. Cocktails included.   From a partnership/Fine Hotels collection standpoint; a lot is left unclear and seems like an afterthought in comparison to other hotels in American Expresses collection. i.e. A lot of benefits were only explained verbally but not iterated on the printed materials (breakfast, limitations, etc.).  Additionally, the primary factor in my personal choosing of hotels is the option of a tub. I love that even in the king suites you include one of the largest tubs I've seen.   Thank you for a great stay, and I hope the feedback is helpful. …

Your task is to classify consumer hotel review into one of the following ratings: ["1", "2", "3", "4", "5"], where "1" indicates very dissatisfied and "5" indicates very satisfied.

Upon our arrival at this establishment I was still fuming about being forced to slum it across the Atlantic (in club world) and I was eager to get to a comfy bed. The first inconvenience occurred when we were directed to use a lift to reach the salle d'attente on the second floor, cue the PA struggling to fit my 15 piece matching set of Louis Vuitton luggage (and his back pack) into the rather tight elevator. I left the PA to carry out all the check in formalities, however I was rather flabbergasted to see him spinning a wheel as if he was some kind of game show host. It was then back to the elevator to reach our room on the 23rd floor, this is where problems started as all the lifts were full of other patrons; I instructed the PA that he would have to take the stairs with my 15 piece matching set of Louis Vuitton luggage. I eventually managed to get myself into an elevator after being told to go in sideways and not touch the sides. Obscenities began to be shouted towards the PA when he finally showed up to the 23rd floor because he hadn’t left me the room key, he then ushered me into the room which was rather diminutive. First thing I noticed was how cold the room was and I had visions of having to sleep in my morning dress, the PA found the thermoregulator and turned up the temperature; what a mistake that was at it sounded like the PA had started a diesel generator. For a quick dinner I allowed the PA fetch something called a “takeout” however he hadn’t picked up any silverware, I found some coffee stirrers in the room and we had to make do with those to eat the Mac’n’cheese (pasta and a cheese sauce). The beds were incredibly comfortable which resulted in both of us feeling very refreshed come dawn, this came in handy for the PA as due to the popularity of the lifts there was a wait so I demanded to be carried down the stairs (I don’t like burning calories unnecessarily). The gentleman on the ground floor was always very courteous and I tipped my top hat each time we passed. It was a little disappointing to find the housekeeper hadn’t cleared any of our detritus we’d left beside the receptacle, likewise the coffee stirrers weren’t replenished which resulted in the PA having a mac’n’cheese flavoured coffee. For our early flight from JFK I requested the PA to request a station wagon from reception, this was met with blank stares resulting in us vulnerable gentleman having to brave the conditions at an ungodly hour trying to flag down a cabriolet. Ultimately despite the few negatives our weekend retreat at the DoubleTree New York Downtown was pleasant and enjoyable, if the PA booked this boarding house again I would be fine with it.

So let's start with the good things, the hotel is centrally located so great if you want to get around New York. Most places are a reasonable walking distance or short Uber rides to where you need to get to. The room was clean and serviced well daily.   Now the bad things, the staff were quite awful from the moment we arrived the check in process was unfriendly with no information provided and the staff were more interested in talking to each other than serving customers. It wasn't even busy as we were the only ones checking in at that stage. A bit of customer service asking about your trip what you were interested in, telling you about the hotel ..... nothing. Unfortunately that carried on throughout the stay and this hotel needs to train all their staff in customer service. I think the problem is supply and demand, as there is such demand they get filled without even trying and as such their staff just don't should any attitude to care. There were just stupid things like 3 of us staying and only two cups each day in the room, empty shower gel, towels not being left. Every day there was something we had to contact them about and the reaction we got wasn't apologetic either. The rooms are quite dated with peeling paint from the ceiling in our room, the heating sounded like you were beside a 747 at takeoff and only cold area was pumped out. This place needs a refurbishment to really bring it up to any decent standard.   One thing to be aware of as well is that if you book through a third party provider none of your Hilton Honors are considered, so you don't get anything benefits whatsoever. That came as a complete surprised and was hugely disappointing to a Diamond member. I think that policy stinks and is restrictive trading. Even after complaining Hilton just weren't interested, so am looking to switch loyalty given their behaviour over that. Even if you booked directly I'm not sure there is any benefit at this hotel, there is no executive lounge and you certainly don't feel that loyalty matters here. On hindsight I shouldn't have thought being loyal and booking to stay at Hilton was a good option especially when there were many better deals at other hotels and its a lesson learnt for me and one that will make me stop using Hilton as a result.  So in summary I would recommend other hotels, there is even a good Holiday Inn in the same road which was a better offer including breakfast and better rooms. Unless you are pushed for choice I wouldn't consider this place. I think a testimony to any stay is would you go back and from my experience I certainly won't be staying there again for any visit to New York. …

Booked a Christmas evening stay at the JW Essex House on Central Park S. Horrendous stay. We were in a Manhattan Suite as a family of four. We booked this hotel after reading the many glowing reviews on this site .. travelers beware! This is not the hidden gem everyone raves about. Upon our arrival, the front desk clerk was ok - not super friendly, not rude - just whatever towards us. No big deal but certainly nothing to make us excited about checking in.  Once inside our double suite executive, we discovered it was not clean! Beds were made, couch spiffed up but bathroom was dirty with hair as were window ledges. I grabbed the phone to call the front desk and as I put it to my ear I discovered that the handset had been sitting in a puddle of beer! Had it not been such a long exhausting day of travel (from CA) maybe I would've noticed before touching it to my face but unfortunately, I did not. It left my hair and face smelling of stale beer. So gross. I asked the front desk for a sponge to clean the dishes (which we never got) and Clorox wipes (which they wouldn't provide). The front desk was apologetic & kind but the woman who came to re-clean seemed frazzled and still didn't remedy the bathroom. The next day my husband found a joint behind the window coverings in the living-room & I found a Sheraton key on a nightstand - making it even more apparent how inadequate the room cleaning had been.   At that point it didn't seem worth it to call them again b/c it was clear they wouldn't clean up to a higher standard so, we dealt with it and re-cleaned what we could. The uncleanliness is less than comforting in any stay but made worse since we had our young kids with us (5 & 8). The hotel said it was their "busy season" (12/26-12/31) and unfortunately, it may have been over-looked. I was less than impressed. We could already tell that they didn't real care about the issues so we stayed b/c truthfully, we didn't feel like battling with them over leaving.   Room size was generous and the building's location is WONDERFUL however, this location needs a lot of TLC & I wouldn't stay here again unless some changes are made. …

I booked this as an award stay as a Globalist, Hyatt's highest status.  It was a close-in booking so I was thrilled to be able to get anything at all b/c we went for three nights a few days before Christmas.  I was not able to secure an upgrade.  It looks like this hotel has a very limited number of suites that they make available to members for upgrades.  For example, I look out at December of 2024 and they have no standard suites available at all...more than 11 1/2 months in advance.  Prior to arrival, I had corresponded with the concierge to request a rollaway bed for our room.  We arrived at the hotel late on December 20th.  We checked in and were told there were no rollaways for that night, or the following two nights of our stay.  When I mentioned that was fine but I had corresponded with someone (and named that person) the FD agent left to check on it, then came back and said the bed was already in the room.  Cool.  We were also upgraded to a room with a view.    When we entered, I was surprised at the size of the standard king room.  I have had some very small rooms in NYC and was expecting the room to be tight.  It wasn't.  It was a fairly standard sized room actually and the bathroom was very large.  The shower was a huge walk in, there was a tub in the bathroom, and the room with the toilet was also very large.  The bathroom had two sinks which is always a plus.  In not all that familiar with NYC, but we were facing toward Central Park and loved the view of the skyscrapers out the windows.  The room itself had a desk and plenty of closet space.  The bed was comfortable and there were plenty of outlets, including USB-C plugs, on either side of the bed.  We had one minor service issue.  The automatic curtains would not raise up in the bathroom.  This was mentioned when we left one morning and it was taken care of when we returned that afternoon.  We ended up eating breakfast all three mornings in The Living Room, and had dinner there two nights as well.  The food was all very good and the service was great.  We really enjoyed our stay here.  It was far enough from Times Square that the crowds weren't a problem, but it was close enough to easily get to Radio City or Rock Center by foot.  We would definitely look to stay here again in the future.…

The look, the location and the amenities of the Westgate Hotel Grand Central made our recent stay an absolute winner. It's right on 42nd street at second avenue. I thought it would be a very busy area. Instead, it was just perfect. Centrally located to tons of fine places to eat, to shopping, to transportation, to walking. If you like "looking up," the building structures were dynamic and beautiful. Duck in for a hot chocolate at Zuckers. Have breakfast or lunch at one of the two closest diners (Townhouse and Gemini; we hit both). Head a block north or five or six blocks south to a meal or a hangout. You can get everywhere, so easily. Even back to LaGuardia, whether by Uber or taxi we did both).The hotel is beautiful. The staff goes out of their way to accommodate. There's a wonderful seating area to meet friends and hang out, across from a "marketplace" and bar where you can have a cocktail or heat up one of the food options in the microwave. The room was perfect. Totally updated. Oodles of storage... drawers, closet with cubbies and hanging space. The nightstand had a refrigerator! (We didn't discove that until we were ready to depart.) Bathroom was totally updated and easy. Lush, thick towels and plenty of them. Shampoo, conditioner, body wash and body lotion were upscale and plentiful. The dresser and desk were quite handsome with leather-look fronts drawers and vintage metal feet on the mid-century modern low chest. Plenty of charging stations for phones iPads, and hands-frees. Bed comfort was heavenly, like sleeping on a cloud. Our reservation let the hotel pick our room. When we checked in, we were told they had a king room available if we'd like (and we did).The staff went to great lengths to please. We'd intended to take Uber to the airport, and it was suggested we might wish to take a taxi. Chafik said he would be happy to get us a cab and a reputable ride. We went with that and it was perfect. Even a little cheaper than Uber would've been.My companion lost one of her favorite gloves and thought it might've been left in our room, or dropped in the lobby somewhere. We'd already checked out and checked our luggage to go to lunch. When we got back to hotel, Chafik said he'd gone up to our room to check for the glove (not there). Just going the extra mile was very special. (The companion then thought it might've been dropped/left at the bagel place up the street. That was correct and I retrieved.)Each time we entered or exited the hotel, the doorman opened the side door for us, or started the revolving door if we were headed that way. Staff was just wonderful. The room was comfortable, the bed was a great respite for hard-walking days. The hotel is centrally located, near Grand Central, and near the UN. In the middle of so many restaurants, stores. Second Avenue, First Avenue are a delight to walk along on the fashionable East side of manhattan in the East 30s and 40s. I'd love to stay at the Westgate ... again and again.

Where do I start!?So seriously I love this hotel for many reasons and a little put off for small reasons.Good:   On our first day checking in me and my partner were totally horribly burnt out and you can see it....  The person checking us in "Chantel" was her name....  Pure gold.  She was super kind, friendly, accommodating and definitely had awareness of the situation which is crucial for a client facing role like hers.Location:  If you like to walk the location is awesome and we picked it partly for this reason.  It's smacked in the middle of anywhere you want to be in NYC, so most Lyft or Uber fairs were from $12-$30 to most anywhere around the city if you don't take the subway.Design:  If nothing else The Redburry has awesome style and design is well thought out.  I loved it.Not so good:  The first room we got the first didn't even have space for the suitcases...  the bathroom was literally bigger than the sleeping space.....  We upgraded to a Deluxe for the next 7 days.There were small things missing in rooms of a hotel of that caliber that were off putting....  Since I don't like to bother people even if I am paying this was a bit a fuss to have to go down or call room service for slippers, Tooth brush/paste, water.... hotel water....  There was also an added amenities fee if I'm not mistaken but.... I felt there were little to no amenities for this.Staff:  Like I said before "Chantel" was a godsend and the fact that it's the only name I remember says a lot ha....   I'd say 90% of the experience with the staff was brilliant and lovely.   There was one particular staff member that was not so friendly and made a fuss about us asking for water....  (Note we were staying at this hotel 8 days consecutively)...    This attitude I'd expect from a motel or a 7 Days in, but not a Chelsea $200-300night hotel...On that note please put Kettles in the room guys.... Atleast the Deluxe rooms should already have basic things already in the room like I mentioned earlier.Overall I'd say I had a great experience with a few small bumps but it's expected after staying so.many days right?   For 1-2 days I'd definitely stay again, but I need to stay for s week or longer I'd suggest staying somewhere else if you don't want to bother staff for small things over and over.Great experience overall!

We last visited NYC in 2018 and stayed in Hell's Kitchen, this time we wanted to be near Broadway and HINYCTS was the perfect spot, within walking distance from just about everything we wanted to do for our short stay there (23 hours flying for a 5-day stay!) Food is in abundance-high end restaurants to budget; grocery store up the road, a little fridge in the room to store milk for that desperately needed caffeine shot in the morning (before bodily parts can function), subway access on just about every street corner within minutes, shopping (Macy's 10 minutes away- we arrived just in time to catch the Black Friday sales), Bryant Park where the Christmas markets had just started, a few bars with good drink selections.. and Madison Square Garden, also minutes away on foot.  We'd never been to an NBA game so managed to get tickets to a NY Knicks game at the "Garden" with the Knicks never looking like they were going to lose (to the Hornets!).  Caught a couple of musicals and TKTS seats (booked under the "Red Stairs" near Times Square were prime seats at significantly discounted prices-wouldn't get these seats at these prices in Aust!  We had a family room, travelled with our adult daughter (as a graduation present!) so the extra bed in the room did make it tight although given that we were mainly in the room to shower, sleep & recharge-  was adequate for our needs. The lift can be busy at "peak hour", only 2 lifts for the property so allow time especially if you need to check out and rush off to catch a flight-we were prepared so no dramas there.  Also, the reception staff were very helpful in ordering a car to the airport at a very reasonable price (without the hassle of trying to get a cab or Uber). Overall, would recommend the hotel for its central location, great hot shower and the comfort of the Holiday Inn brand.  No safety concerns re street traffic outside the property; be street-smart & all is fine, it is NYC after all! Thanks to the staff who made our stay memorable-we would return.

I booked a Park View One Bedroom Suite for three nights through American Express Fine Hotels + Resorts (FHR).  I booked through FHR for its exclusive benefits that included (1) free breakfast for two each day and (2) $100 credit during stay.  Upon check-in, the front office confirmed these benefits and gave me a sheet detailing them.  Then a problem occurred when I was checking out.  The front office said that there was an error and that I was not eligible for FHR benefits since I booked through a travel agent.  When I explained that I had booked directly through AMEX FHR, not through a travel agent, Javier Alvites, the Overnight Front Office Manager, came out and said that I needed to resolve the problem directly with AMEX.  I showed them a direct email from AMEX confirming my reservation and FHR benefits, but this did not help.  I then pointed out  that upon check-in the front office confirmed my FHR benefits and gave me a sheet detailing the benefits.  Mr. Alvites said that it was a staff error, for which they were not willing to bear responsibility.The matter did not get resolved until I later identified myself as a lawyer, asked for Mr. Alvites' business card and mentioned that I would not let this matter just pass.  Although I was able to avoid the false charges, there was no apology of any kind or expression of sympathy from Mr. Alvites.  This dispute left a very sour ending note to my otherwise wonderful trip---and, while I am still trying, I find it very hard to forgive the hotel for ruining the end of my trip.  I hope this review helps other travelers and prevents them from experiencing similar annoyances.

A six-storey, red brick, Romanesque New York landmark, houses the Mercer Hotel, a cool but trendy downtown luxury property in SOHO, a district rooted in cast iron engineering, with excellent shopping and some of the best restaurants in town. I relished my Loft Suite with a penthouse vibe and packed with a bevy of features: high ceilings with exposed brick, open concept footprint, hardwood floors and huge arched windows affording lots of natural light. A muted color palette with modern furniture, mirrors as big as walls and living, dining and workspaces added touches of hominess to the dwelling. The bath was marbleized and outfitted with a 2 person tub and a walk-in shower. Sartianos restaurant serves modern Italian food-fare with items that range from Yellowfin Tuna Tartare to Heirloom Beets to  Bomboloni. I scooped up the flavorful Octopus selection accompanied by some 'melt in your mouth' homemade Focaccia.  As a confirmed bookworm I loved the handsome library space in the lobby. Floor to ceiling mahogany bookshelves, curated weekly, are tended to much like a garden.  It's was such an pleasure for me to sip a Manhattan and flip through the libraries picks. Titles range from all over the place but it is my habit to look for titles out of the ordinary. There's a book for every interest..........so forget your computer...............and pack your reading glasses.  If you yearn for a luxury Soho based hotel that is center stage to the parade of local shops............then try the ............Mercer Hotel................a stellar location & great library.…

This place was an absolute god send when we booked our stay last summer. My friend and I booked it about a week in advance for 3 nights, and it was only about $40 each per night, which seems very reasonable for Manhattan. The hostel is located on the upper west side, right next to central park. The surrounding area was also great and had lots of shops, laundromats and places to eat so we had everything we needed. It's in a gorgeous and upmarket part of the city which tourists would probably not normally get to visit, so it was great to see a nice residential area. Staying here will make you feel like a proper New Yorker! We also had our own private room with bunk-beds, which was actually cheaper than just paying for a bed in a larger dorm (I think this was $50 a night per person). The room was nice and clean, and so was the communal bathroom. Although it may seem far from Times Square etc I actually preferred this as it was a lovely place to return to late at night in a very attractive location. The subway ride there is fairly short and the stop is about a 5 minute walk from the hostel. The staff were friendly and helpful and it felt very safe. There is a bar and outdoor area, however my only complaint is that there is no laundry room, as this is often essential for travellers. There is a laundromat one block away though so it isn't too much of an issue. I would definitely recommend staying here regardless of your budget as it feels far more authentic than staying in Times Square. Will definitely return for my next visit.

A friend and I had two reservations at TMC through RCI during November and December 2023.  The first week we were unfortunately in a small unit.  There was a window, but you could barely open it, and the view was of massive pipes etc. so all we really had, was some light coming through the window (which was sandblasted I think).  I've stayed at TMC twice before, both times thinking it was lovely, but this was an eye opener.  It was not the same anymore.  I had quite a shock when I opened the kitchen cupboard, to only find a few plastic plates, cups, glasses, and the little throw away sets of knives and forks!!  What!!  I phoned and asked what was going on, and finally got some decent crockery and cutlery brought to the room.  Then heard that these rooms, I think it was second floor, were called 'Metropolitan Suites', and it was standard!  Getting wifi was impossible, so we were finally given a gadget to carry with us for wifi.  We found the staff not very helpful, and even battled with our own luggage on the day we left!  For our second stay, we had a one bedroom unit with a lovely view on the 16th floor.  What a difference.  We were just back in NY from a cruise, and even though we were paying for a week, we only spent 2 days and 1 night there.  This time there was decent items in the cupboard.  We did have some help from the bell hop with luggage.  Front desk staff again not bursting with enthusiasm, and friendly and happy as with all the other places we stayed at during this overseas holiday.  I was really disappointed in TMC.  They have also had two hefty security deposits on hold on my credit card, and even though I've asked them to instruct their bank to remove the holds (after my bank said it was their responsibility to do do, even though they were telling me my bank should be doing it!), I still have one large hold.  They just don't seem to want to do anything themselves to remove these.I have always thought that this was a really lovely establishment, but this holiday has changed my mind.  The hotel is in an excellent area, has a good business centre, etc.  The one bedroomed unit was very good.  We often saw specials at the hotel, but always it was stated 'for owners', so we did not bother, seeing that we were not owners.  Is this because we had our reservations as exchanges through RCI??  By the way, the 'kitchen' in the small room was impossible!  You had to bend under the cabinet to open the tap.  In both rooms, the so-called kitchen is really nothing more than a fridge, microwave, sink, few odds and ends.  Getting lifts can also be a daunting task, you can wait forever.  Make sure you get your luggage to the foyer very early on the day of departure, as you could stand waiting at the lift for a very long time!Finally, STAY AWAY FROM THE 'METROPOLITAN SUITES'!

My recent stay at The Manhattan hotel in New York City left me with mixed feelings, earning it a 3.5-star rating. While the hotel boasts a prime location near Times Square and a short walk to Central Park, as well as a beautiful lobby and smooth check-in experience, the overall stay was marred by dated accommodations.The hotel's proximity to Times Square and Central Park was undoubtedly a highlight, offering convenience and easy access to key attractions. The lobby was impressively adorned and the staff provided excellent service, even assisting us to our room with our luggage – a touch of hospitality that was appreciated.However, the experience took a turn upon reaching our assigned floor. The hallway seemed frozen in time, displaying a dated decor and a noticeable smell of dampness. Unfortunately, this theme persisted in our room. The accommodations were extremely old-fashioned, and the pervasive damp smell was off-putting. The radiators were inconsistent, with only one occasionally functioning.While we were primarily using the room for sleeping, it was disappointing to find it lacking in quality. Notably, other floors seemed to be undergoing or had undergone renovation, but our floor was an exception. The room fell short of the quality depicted in online images, leaving us somewhat disappointed.Despite these shortcomings, the staff's professionalism and assistance were commendable, showcasing a level of service that exceeded the room's standard. If only the same attention to quality were applied to the accommodations, The Manhattan hotel could truly live up to its potential.In summary, if you prioritise location and excellent service but are willing to compromise on room quality, The Manhattan might suit your needs. However, for those expecting a consistently high standard across all aspects of their stay, a thorough evaluation of room options might be advisable.

I booked here for a 12 day stay. I think I was misinformed by all the reviews as most guests usually stay here for 1 or 2 days maximum. It is intolerable to stay here for so long as I did. Firstly, the photos of the rooms do not represent the real situation. The room was quite dusty, the floor boards squeak all night and you can actually hear when the guest one floor above you flush the toilet. What really pissed me off was that they thought I was a homeless guy staying at the shelter since my stay was so long. I was so embarrassed and they even thought I was doing something illegal that they insisted I allow them into the room as I usually tidy up and sanitise everything especially when it comes to having a child. The housekeeping staff wipes everything in the toilet with the same wash rag: toilet bowl (inside of the rim of bowl), bathtub and face basin. I was so shocked. Clean everything yourself. Also there is an internet charge per day which when added to the nightly rate plus taxes work out to be more than staying at a Hilton or Doubletree chain of hotels. They also held a security fee for almost one week after my departure and it caused my credit card to go into over draft. I had to call them to release the funds. Having stayed worldwide at many hotel being a flight attendant, I must say that this place is a dump. Avoid it all expense!

The AC works but is LOUD!! The room was decent and clean, but I wish the hotel had a teeny more decor...like...for example....framed showcards on the walls. Like those nice signed ones where they raise money for Broadway cares/Equity fights AIDS. It's called Hotel Shocard, so why not? Everything about this hotel is small. The lobby is just a counter, the hallways and elevator are small (no key card needed, even though there's a thing for it in there), but I'm small so I was ok with it.    My little room grew on me and became my little quiet sanctuary after barely escaping the craziness of Times Square.  It's comfortable, cozy, and I was sad to leave.  I'd love to stay here again.

Keener was receptive to our request and managed to get us a free upgrade to a classic room, which felt more spacious and had room to sit (much needed after a ton of walking!) The staff also were accommodating of our request to hold our luggage after check-out so we could explore the area.Both rooms were clean and modern. The shower and sink were top-notch, with great water pressure. My main gripe was that most of the hooks in the rooms did not have stoppers at the ends, since the design was just a cylinder... so heavy coats and bags could slide right off. We managed to make do by rotating the standing mirror around, as there were metal bars on the back that could be popped out and used in lieu of hooks.We loved the option of free breakfast -- it seems like earlier in the morning, they have croissants (pretty good, with a nice crunch to them), and then they swap in for bagels later. They also provide filtered water and cups in the breakfast area.Overall, a lovely experience! Next time, I will book the classic or superior room :)

When we first checked in, there was some frustration in the line because it was after 4:00 and there were just no rooms available.  It was a busy weekend in December, and all of Midtown was packed.  Some of the guests in line were taking it out on the people working at the front desk, who were doing their best.   I am not sure how the people working check-ins were able to keep their demeanor based upon how they were being treated  - yes this is a 5 star hotel, but clearly they were slammed with dozens of people checking in at once.  Despite how busy it was, the woman checking me in was nothing but smiles as she searched for a room, unsuccessfully.   I told her to please not worry about it, I'd give her my phone number, and she'd contact me when the room was ready.    Meanwhile they took our bags, and we went for a cocktail nearby.   An hour or so later, our room was ready - not a big deal, not sure why others can't be more patient.   I'm not in NYC to hang out in my room.  Upon checking in, they acknowledged my Platinum Elite status and my birthday, and provided an upgrade.     The room was absolutely fantastic.  Very luxurious, with a wonderful view of 5th Avenue.   They also gave us a $100 hotel credit to make up for the tardiness of our room - much appreciated!  The bed was extremely comfortable and the bathrooms very posh, and immaculately clean.  This was honestly one of the best hotel experiences that I've had, and I've traveled quite a bit, also having stayed at 3 other different St. Regis properties.    The only thing that I would change is that the sole option for getting a cocktail in the hotel was at the Cole Bar, which ALWAYS had a long line to get in.  I am not going to wait 30+minutes to wait for a cocktail in Manhattan - plenty of other options, but I'm sure others would not mind.  Personally, I like to have something cozy and less trendy in the hotel I am staying in, but again - that's just a personal preference.    Finally, the location is great if you want to be in Midtown.   Of course, very touristy, but that's to be expected.  It's very convenient to the major sites this time of year, such as Rockefeller Center, Saks, etc.  I'm more of a downtown person but it was nice to stay in a different part of Manhattan for a change and a quick and easy subway or cab ride to escape.  In summary, thank you, St. Regis New York, for a memorable stay and treating us so well.   Well done.  …

Lovely hotel located in midtown Manhattan. We stayed here for 5 nights just before Christmas. Staff were lovely and personable.   Our room was on 6th floor, and although quite compact, was modern, fully featured and spotlessly clean.   The lobby bar was really pleasant as was the rooftop bar (both separate businesses I believe).   I will say however that the ‘Resort Fee’ or whatever they call it of $36 a night is extortion and basically covers your wifi use and free long distance phone calls. It’s basically a tax avoidance scheme for Hotels who pay lower tax on these fees, and creates an artificially low price to attract customers. It’s basically just a shake down. We paid it because you aren’t give a choice really but apparently it’s illegal and you can make a complaint to the New York State Attorney General. You’re also within your rights to do a charge back on your credit card so bear this in mind if you want your money back.   Hotels are desperate to normalise this shady business practice to line their own pocket. It’s a real shame when a nice hotel does this. …
