We stayed here over the New Year period for 4 nights on a couples city break. Immediately what stood out was the location and value of the hotel - both excellent. We decided we'd be out exploring for most of our time in NYC so did not need a grand lobby or huge hotel with restaurants etc. This place matched what we were looking for perfectly. Still modern and comfortable, the hotel met our every need. The rooms were spacious enough and we went for a basic one, the staff were also incredibly friendly and helpful offering lots of knowledge about the city. The absolute hidden gem is on the top floor, an observatory/lounge offering a nice atmosphere of peace out of the chaos of the city and great views outside, the Chrysler building in particular. It has a great coffee machine, and we saw plenty of guests enjoy the ambience with some drinks/food they had bought themselves (there's a small store right opposite). I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel for those with needs similar to ours. My only feedback is you have to ask for housekeeping services, it isn't standard. Once we knew this it was fine, although we did ask one day and it wasn't done. This was resolved the next day with an apology. Thanks for a great stay

My flight got canceled at the very last minute, and the airline's handling of the situation left much to be desired. They refused to provide any accommodation and instead gave us a brochure with supposedly discounted hotels in the city. Faced with the uncertainty of 200+ people trying to secure a place, I quickly glanced at the brochure and decided on the "Chelsea Inn" due to its 3-star rating on the website.However, as I was en route to the hotel, I read the fine print and discovered two significant concerns: 1) The hotel had shared bathrooms, and 2) There was no reception. The latter worried me since I didn't have a US phone and hadn't received any confirmation from the hotel. Thankfully, upon arrival, I found someone at the front desk.Although the room itself was clean, I couldn't help but feel disappointed considering the price I paid. Private bathrooms should have been included at that rate. Additionally, having to carry my suitcase up five flights of stairs was quite inconvenient. The hotel's lack of luggage storage was another major drawback, especially for travelers with late flights. Furthermore, they charged an extra $35 for housekeeping, which thankfully I didn't require during my one-night stay.In conclusion, this hotel might be suitable for those who plan well in advance and receive check-in instructions on time. However, it should never be advertised as an option for last-minute bookings, especially for international guests who might urgently need a room. I can't imagine the trouble I would have faced if there hadn't been anyone at the reception upon my arrival.

I've stayed in many hotels throughout NYC and this is by far the worst! I wish I never booked a room here. No one should pay money to stay at this place. There were too many things wrong. Where do I even start?  1) The key had a hard time turning just to unlock the door. Things just went downhill from there. 2) The bedroom and bathroom were very dusty, almost as if no one had been there for years. There was also a smell of cigarettes even though there was a sign in the room that said it was a non-smoking room. 3) The sheets on the bed weren't clean, had stains, hair, and dust. The room didn't have a phone (or a clock) so I had to go downstairs to tell them that the sheets weren't clean. The guy at the front desk gave me "clean sheets" only for me to find out when I got back upstairs that even though those sheets were cleaner, they were still dirty with red stains.  4) The comforter was even dirtier and looked disgusting. One corner of it had a big yellow stain resembling urine. 5) Even though the windows were closed, you could still feel a draft of cold air coming in so the room was very cold and not much heat was provided throughout the night.  6) The (dirty) ceiling near one of the 2 windows had water dripping from it. 7) There was a small roach on one of the bathroom towels.  8) The bathroom sink drains so slow that I had to floss and brush my teeth in the shower.  9) The shower head was really dirty, but to be fair most hotels don't seem to clean this. I actually took the filthy shower head off just to shower. 10) The wall outlets were practically useless. Anything that you plugged into them usually fell right out just seconds later. So I couldn't charge my phone. 11) You can hear quite clearly when anyone in a room next to yours is talking. Doesn't matter if you're in the bedroom or in the bathroom, you can still hear them. The people next to my room stood up most of the night talking just adding to my frustration of all the problems the room already has. And to make it worse people were slamming doors incredibly loud between 11pm to about 3am. 12) Hotels.com told me that checkout was at 12 noon. That wasn't true, checkout was at 11am. 13) Some rooms had no bathroom. Mine did, which is probably the only positive thing I can say about it.  There were more issues. But those are the ones I remember at the moment. As if all those things alone weren't a major turn off, the dirty sheets and comforter is completely unacceptable. The primary reason people stay in a hotel is to have a place to sleep in for the night and if everything on the bed is nasty, how are you supposed to sleep on that? This place should either fix all of it's issues or shut down their business. It's not worth the money or time to stay at this hotel. Hotels.com should de-list it from their search results. I feel cheated. Stay away!!!…

I honestly had no complaints about the room or stay itself. It was a cheap hotel, I was expecting a basic room without anything extra and during my stay that's what I got. However, I had to pay a deposit before checking into the hotel in cash. I'm used to it being on credit but no big deal. After checking out they said I would have to wait a few days and then call them to get my deposit mailed back to me. Strange but I understood. They have to check the room, make sure I didn't break anything. That's the last I saw of that money.I call multiple times after about my deposit, and each time I was told the office was closed and to call back later. No specific time was ever given of course but each time I called back it was the same excuse. After a month of this they said that they probably don't have my deposit anymore so I escalated my call to the booking site Expedia. When they called them the hotel said that I, quote "did not return the key to the staff after the guest checked out and the accommodation has to change the lock and produce new sets of the keys and the cost for this process was $135.00Therefore the guest still obligated to pay for the remaining cost of changing the lock and producing new keys."This was a lie. I handed the key directly to the front desk employee who checked me in the first night and there is probably security footage showing that. Unfortunately I didn't record myself handing the key to front desk as I was not expecting my deposit to get stolen and for them to lie about it. With no way to prove that I didn't have the key (how was I supposed to prove I didn't have an item I don't have?), that they lied about making a new key and changing the locks, or anyway to access the security footage proving I handed them the key back, I basically had my $120 stolen.There's little I can do about this other than warn other people away from staying at this hotel. Just shell out extra to another hotel without a sketchy reputation and history of theft.

I had the worst night of rest at a hotel here.  There are so many cons.1.  I booked a one bedroom suite with one bed and a sleeper sofa for 2 adults and 1 child.  I booked this same type of room at another NYC hotel and had no issues.  When I returned to my room and pulled out the sleeper sofa, it was an unmade mattress.  I called to state that the sleeper sofa had no linen and was asked if I requested it to be made.  I didn't think I would need to if the room was booked for 3 persons and there as only one true bed.  I didn't need to do so at the other hotel.  It is 11 pm at this time.  35 minutes later a staffer knocks and hands me linen.  No plan on them dressing the bed.  He stated, oh we can send someone up to do it.  I said that would be nice. 30 minutes later, no one arrived, so I started to make the bed myself only to discover that the linen was not sufficient to make the bed and have linen for coverage of someone sleeping.  A flat sheet and pillows.  I called downstairs again.  Was told they would send me more linen.  30 more minutes past and no one comes.  Now it is 12:30 am.  I go to the front desk to discuss this issue and an issue detailed below.  The front desk person was condescending and rude.  Telling me I needed to tell him what specific pieces of linen I wanted.  I didn't know what fit that bed and how they make them (duvet, cover sheet, spread, fitted sheet ???) as every hotel is a bit different.  He went to get a manager who came from the back and said he would personally deal with my issues and bring me appropriate linen.  By 1:10 am no one had still come.  I eventually put the flat sheet they provided on top of the mattress, put on my day clothing with socks and a sweater (because I had no linen to cover up with)  and went to bed.2.  The hotel has quiet hours from 10pm to 5 am.  While dealing with the above issue the next door hotel guest were allowing their children to scream, yell, bang on the walls.  I let it go until it was after midnight and I was on my way to the front desk.  I knocked on their door and asked politely if they could be a bit quieter.  I was told they were celebrating a birthday, and I could call security if I had a problem with it.  So while I was at the front desk, I told them about the noise from that room.  The front desk staff said they would address the noise level.  They never did.  The hotel is not responsible for the actions of others but they are responsible for addressing it.  Once again they did not address an issue of concern.  The noise continued.3.  The TVs in our room had no sound.  Picture was fine, but no sound regardless of  what we did to try to fix the situation.4.  When I went to call the front desk, the phones in the room were dead.  I had to call the front desk with my cell phone.5.  There is resort/hotel fee that was to include Hop on Hop Off tickets.  Stated on the website and told at check in.  Went to obtain them the next morning and was told they didn't renew their contract with the Hop on Hop Off company, so there were no tickets.6.  The room had a microwave but no refrigerator.  Weird and useless to have a microwave without a refrigerator.7.  Extremely busy and crowed hotel.Pros:Not far from the theaters.  Other than that, there aren't any other pros.Not a place I will want to stay in again when in New York.   I complained when I checked out about my stay.  The front desk person went to talk to a manager.  The manager never came out.  The front desk person stated I would be awarded points.  Points!  What if I weren't a Marriott member?  The points weren't sufficient for the crappy night.  There are far better Marriott hotel in NYC that everyone should use rather than here.  The room was very expensive and treatment and care was extremely poor.  They definitely did not care about me as a guest, a Marriott member or as a person.

I would not recommend staying at the Grand Central’s hotel for the reasons I stated in my other review at that hotel. Also, if you are reading this review because you want to stay close to the station, Hampton Inn is within a few blocks from Grand Central. It is an easy walk as well. The room itself is clean and spacious by New York standards. Everything worked in the room. The complimentary breakfast was adequate, and it is a plus especially if you travel with your family. First online review of anything, but I feel I must share. My family stayed at The Leon for five nights in early August 2022. I had arranged for the stay due to the location and the website photos. The room was nice enough, and quite clean. However, the service was spotty at best. Some days we got toiletries, some days not. Some days we got enough towels, some days not. I went to the front desk to ask to borrow a bottle opener and the attendant was completely baffled by the request. They evidently skip those basic amenities that other hotels have been providing for decades. This was all fine. We are not complainers, even though the price we paid was about average for our one or twice yearly trip to New York. The real problem arose upon checkout. The hotel is located at an unusual intersection so before leaving we asked where best to catch a cab. We got a dismissive reply that provided very little in the way of useful information. Any other hotel would have offered to arrange for a car. We left the premises and spent 15 or 20 minutes in extreme heat unsuccessfully attempting to get a cab (no more than 3 or 4 even passing in that time). My husband decided to return to the hotel and ask them to call a cab for us. For reasons unknown, this resulted in the gentleman behind the desk exploding. He began shouting at my husband and verbally abusing him. It was truly a shocking and bizarre experience. We travel extensively and this was perhaps the poorest customer service we have encountered. Don't be deceived by the quaint photos - The Leon Hotel is anything but welcoming.…

We’ve stayed at this property several times previously.  Nice property, good location and amenities.However, we will never stay there again.  The Time Share sales team was the most relentless, invasive, pushy pitch we’ve ever experienced.First, they have a “kill zone” of time share sales personnel located on both sides of the only path to the elevators. When he gives up, he passes you to the “Supervisor”, who is somewhat rude and insistent for the next level pitch.  Finally, when that fails, you are passed to the “Pit Boss” for a final try.Then, the phone in the room, and your cell phone will never stop ringing, the entire length of your stay.  Every time you leave and return, you are grabbed again for another sales pitch try.This was so intrusive and offensive to me, we will never stay there again.  I recommend you avoid this property.  Wyndham shouldn’t support this ridiculous setup.

The Edge Hotel, while far uptown in Manhattan, is conveniently located near the A/C/1 lines, as well as near the Columbia University hospital complex. The social area on the "C" floor is extremely clean and comfortable with a giant TV - perfect for unwinding after long days at the hospital. If you read nothing else - don't stay here. The issues that are consistent across most of these reviews are indeed present.  I love Hyatt, but Centric seems to have become their brand for hotels with good bones and management that doesn't care, and that seems to be the case here. It used to be an Andaz, which means the rooms are massive, the finishes are quite nice, and it feels more elevated. That said, none of it has been maintained.   As noted in other reviews, the shower floods the entire bathroom, and I had unresolved HVAC issues, including AC that just didn't work, throughout my stay. The room was very poorly maintained - scuff marks all over the walls and the bathroom and chipped tiles, knobs, and furniture. Housekeeping was a miss - the room wasn't the cleanest when I got in, and the room was barely turned when housekeeping came by.   The gym is "not working" (not clear what that means) and they send guests to an apartment building next door, but I didn't use it and am unsure how it works. The "Hyatt Has It" program doesn't exist here, and the service is aggressively indifferent.   The overall feeling of the hotel really is "it's New York, we know people will stay here, so why bother." I wouldn't enable them that by booking a stay.…

The property is also blessed with a professional, competent, extraordinarily caring and helpful team. Due to unexpected illness my husband and I were guests of the hotel for well over a year. Throughout our stay we felt completely at home; nothing was too much bother for each member of the staff and shining through was a genuine desire to meet our needs in a thoughtful and unobtrusive way. It was always a pleasure entering or exiting the building – the warm greeting from whomever was at the front desk was a delightful way to start or end a day. As in April 2022 it was a great pleasure to stay at AKA Sutton Place and I look forward to the next visit.

Downside--the evening people at the front desk didn't seem to care about the problem we were having.  Around 9:15 PM we started hearing what appeared to be drilling coming from the next room.  This was going on and off for over an hour.  I recorded the soulnd.  No one came up.  Called the front desk again. They claim someone came up to the floor and didn't hear any noise and went back down.  Didn't knock on my door to hear my problem and the noise I recorded.  You think they would have.  The only thing I figured, since the wall didn't fall down, was that the neighbor was taking a shower or two or three.  For over an hour???.   Really noisy. Figured it was the shower when we also heard it in the morning.  Clean people.  So, there you have it.  You will enjoy your stay.…

You better have a backup plan and budget if you are staying at the Leo House. It may seem affordable, but might end up costing you extra. We booked our stay several months in advance and requested for a quiet room. The hotel's idea of a quiet room was next to rooms they started to renovate. It was not a light face lift but a total gutting of rooms and bathrooms. Who wouldn't want to be waken up at 8 in the morning to the sound of a jackhammer during their vacation, right? So basically the room was unusable during the day because of the construction noise. We tried to change rooms, but it wasn't possible as they said they were fully booked, meaning they didn't have similar rooms available. Had we changed to a "better room", we would have had to pay that rate. The options given were to have a refund and check out the same day or stay in the same room with a slightly lower rate. Now what is the likelihood that you are able to find accommodation in New York at short notice and a similar rate you got 6 months ago. Zero. So the refund really isn't a fair option. Also a 24% discount isn't fair when forced to wake up ridiculously early and not be able to use the room for a good part (1/3) of the day. You can get a 25% discount in most hotels without any issues. But this was the best they could do. Unbelievable.Also communication was extremely painful. The front desk cannot make any decisions. The manager has to check everything with a director who is never to be seen. Basically no one is taking responsibility and everyone is going behind someone else's back. It's not me, it's the other person higher up in the food chain. The simplest solution would have been to delay the start of the reno every day for like 2 hours, but that turned out to be impossible. The reno crew was untouchable. No one could make that decision. So ended up changing hotels. We knew service in New York is horrible, but this was next level. Don't believe their marketing and mile long messages about how they care about their customers. You need to go somewhere else to get what this hotel advertises.

We stayed here from 16-20 December and overall had a good experience.  We had a Premium Room (1502) which was a nice surprise and plenty of room for 2 adults and 2 children.  It had great views towards the Hudson River.  Arrival was around 7pm on Saturday evening and we'd taken the AirTrain/Long Island Railroad from JFK, getting off at Penn Station which was a five minute walk.   The location of the hotel is excellent - 10 minutes to the heart of Times Square.  Lots of eateries nearby.  We tried the Tailor pub which was very good, plus Liberty Bagels which was amazing!  Walking everywhere is possible given the location and we walked to Central Park in around 25 minutes. The Circle Line is about 15 minutes walk and Empire State/Macys just under 10 minutes.  Overall, I would recommend this hotel for the location and room we had.  The street it is on has a Police station, so very safe, however it has scaffolding/construction, so feels a little run-down.  We didn't eat here, so can't comment on that, but did have a drink in the hotel bar which was handy and reasonably prices ($10 for a beer).  The staff also held our luggage on the last day so we could go sightseeing - there is now no charge for this, which is new as it used to be $5 apparently.  The only issue we had was with the elevators - there was a fault that meant the elevators stopped at every single floor when you went up and down - being on the 15th floor meant this was not ideal.  This was from Saturday and only got fixed on the Tuesday evening.  A fault like that should be fixed in no more than 24 hours in my view.  It led to lots of people waiting in the Lobby to go upstairs so not ideal.…

I travel extensively and live a large part of my life in hotels , so I feel I am in a position to judge standards of hotels. Unfortunately I was very disappointed with this hotel , despite all the good reviews on here, the management has got to learn how to deal with customers complaints . I paid over $300 per night for the room without breakfast and in addition there is a resort fee, which is effectively a tax and another way the hotel makes money out of their customers. When we arrived at reception the receptionist explained the resort fee to me and stated that this was for coffees, teas, and water in the room as well as Internet and the Spa?. In the room there was only 2 small tea bags and two creamers so I requested more which they obliged. Next day i  requested some more creamers as two was not enough. The receptionist said that they would bring some to the room. After 45 mins i phoned back down and inquired where the creamers were as we wanted a cup of tea after walking around NY all day, only to be told that housekeeping had stated that each room was only allowed 2 creamers a day and we already had that so therefore we were not allowed any more, i assumed they were joking , but was told this is the rules. I confirmed , that the resort fee of $16 covers this and they stated it did , however you are only allowed 2 creamers a day , despite them not replenishing the water( which is also included in the resort fee) that day . I expressed my disappointment and they told me the manager would contact me. Pete the manager phoned me and explained that he had spoken to Housekeeping and these are the rules and you are only allowed 2 creamers a day per room.I confirmed with him , that the resort fees are for these amenities and he agreed but made a big statement how the Internet (which in almost every other hotel in the world is free) is also covered by this resort fee. He agreed on this occasion that he would allowed 5 creamers ( but only delivered 4) but from the next day onward we would only be allowed 2 creamers per day. I find this pathetic and bad management , and shows the hotels attitude of squeezing money out of their customers, and customers feelings doesn't matter . I would have dropped my rating even lower but Daniel the concierge was extremely helpful.  …

We had reserved to stay here for 2 nights. We arrived (family of 4) at around 8pm on a Saturday. Just before us and just after us, other families both with young children arrived. We were all told the same thing. The hotel was overbooked and there was no room for us. To add insult to injury we had already been charged for the night for a room that wasn't even available! The hotel would have been paid twice for the same room! Plus no alternate plan for our accommodation (or the other families) had been arranged. We waited at least 25 minutes while the manager called around to find us a 'comparable type' room. Once at the alternate hotel, it was far from Mid-town where we had wanted to be, it was loud and dirty and had only double beds (not comparable to the queen beds we had reserved). When we returned the next day for the second nights' stay, the receptionist politely checked us in but there was no amount showing on the credit card machine (not his fault), when we asked what the amount would be, we were told a price that was about $100 more than our original reservation. We showed him the printed reservation which was made directly through the Marriot website, not a 3rd party, and the price was changed but had we not asked, we would have been very surprised when we got our credit card bill!To be fair, and why I gave only a 'poor' rating instead of a 'terrible' rating, our night at the alternate hotel was paid for, the one night at this hotel was refunded and our taxi to & from the alternate hotel was paid for. The room was clean and quiet. The staff (esp. the doorman(?) were all friendly. It was Marriots fault the hotel was overbooked and that we were charged incorrectly. The manager should have realized this overbooking was happening and at least looked into alternatives for guests.

Your task is to classify consumer hotel review into one of the following ratings: ["1", "2", "3", "4", "5"], where "1" indicates very dissatisfied and "5" indicates very satisfied.

I stayed in this hotel in June, particularly as it looked like a very modern hotel (since its refurbishment and rebranding) and was well located near Central Park.   The location is very good, only a 5 or so minute walk to Central Park and subway stations at the end of the street. I noted others saying it felt unsafe on the street, I didn't experience this, it's in a busy area and as 'safe' as most places in Manhattan. The hotel was still undergoing refurbishment work so not all communal areas were open, however it did seem to have more available than in recent months where others cite there was almost nothing available.  We had a really strong welcome to the hotel which I always feel is important. Having made a few basic requests to the room, despite arriving late in the day for some reason it wasn't quite ready or the staff wanted to be absolutely sure we were well accommodated. Even though the delay was brief, we were immediately whisked to the lovely bar for a complimentary drink of our choice off the menu, before the staff member came back to tell us everything was ready.  The room was well sized for New York, we had a basic twin room but there was a seating area, it didn't feel too cramped and it was modern. The bathroom was also nice, a decent shower and lighting, with premium toiletries. I was really not a fan of the shower curtain though, I always find these grubby and unhygienic in hotels. There didn't seem to be a fan either so the mirror very easily steamed up. The air con in the room was very good, not too loud yet powerful. There were no tea or coffee facilities in the room which was disappointing. Beds were comfortable and the rooms weren't noisy, with good blackout blinds to aid sleep. Note that some rooms apparently don't have locks on bathroom doors so beware if staying with friends/colleagues if you value privacy. Also, twin rooms were only available in a small size.  The gym in the hotel was quite big, a decent amount of equipment and also had a large studio with additional weights, mats and a number of Peloton bikes. I enjoyed using this most mornings. It involves a slightly awkward route, exiting the front of the hotel and going into another entrance where there's a blow dry and beauty bar down a very slow lift. The gym was exclusive to the hotel, I imagine when renovations are finished there will be an internal lift down there.  The bar was visually appealing but some of the cocktails were hit and miss. Service was always good but things could be slow, ordering breakfast one day was a frustrating experience as we waited ages. It was also incredibly expensive, no surprise for NY (everything seems to have gone up in price by about 20% since my last visit a few years ago) but a basic breakfast for 2 ending up costing $120 with tip and service, which was laughable.  The hotel offered a What's App service which made requesting anything a breeze. If toiletries were running low or you wanted additional towels, or needed your room serviced at a specific time, they were quick to respond, always delivered and staff at every level couldn't have been more helpful and friendly.  Upon check-out they weren't that keen to engage with us or ask how the stay was, rather the staff member who helped us store our bags was particularly perturbed that we didn't tip him.   Overall, it's a lovely hotel, well-located and I look forward to seeing what it's like when the final renovations are done and scaffolding is removed. It's hard to find a modern premium hotel in NY with decently sized rooms so I would happily stay again. The only thing is despite personally getting a competitive rate through a travel agent, the prices are really high to stay there-£500-600 a night which is really quite exorbitant for a 4* hotel.…

We recently stayed for 5 nights at this hotel. Although the location was good for walks to Central Park, Times Square or 5th Avenue shopping, we encountered some significant issues during our stay. Most notably, they deducted from my credit card a $500 smoking fee for no reason. I informed the hotel that we do not smoke and that we are willing to take any nicotine (or other) test to prove this fact. They said that won't be necessary, but then did not refund me, and ignored subsequent communications from us on this topic. Other (less serious) issues were iffy wi-fi, offline elevators forcing long wait times for service elevators, strange aircon settings that only provided heating, and very limited on-premise eating options. Based on the location, I could maybe still have suggested this hotel to others, but the smoking fee was the last straw. It feels like an unfair/dishonest additional charge that was simply levied to boost profits. I therefore DO NOT recommend staying at this hotel. If you have no choice, then factor in the arbitrary smoking fee that they might be adding to your room fee. Also, don't be surprised by the other minor inconveniences that I listed.…

Perched on the water in lower Manhattan, in the landmark Beaux-Arts Battery Maritime Building, is the Casa Cipriani. The Casa sports a dual hospitality personality, namely, a hotel & a members club where luxury reins 'summa cum laude'...why the house car is an Aston Martin. I soaked up my spacious Junior River View Suite adorned with mahogany floors, bespoke Italian furnishings, Art-Deco light fixtures, an adorable work desk and artwork on the wall. The suite was embedded with high tech appliances like electronic shades, selectable lighting and other futuristic tools. The bath was marbleized with heated floor and walk-in shower. The pinnacle room amenity, however, was the terrace affording me an exception views of  attractions like the Brooklyn Bridge.........why I could almost shake hands with the Statue of Liberty. One never has to leave the Casa with such a bevy of dining and drinking options where you will find the Club Restaurant, the Jazz Cafe, the Club Bar, the Promenade Bar and the Living Room. Aside from the abundance of bars, the Living Room is a communal experience while the Club is where dinner is served in Italian style with items like carpaccio and other pasta classics.........I tested the carpaccio..........it was great. Other highlights of this property is the spa & wellness area in addition to a fitness center, but perhaps the biggest draw is the membership club.   So, if you want a Big Apple hotel with luxury to the max........,,,,...then try the................ Casa Cipriani.............it  checks off all the boxes for a hotel of greatness.…

This is not a review that I want to write but I think potential guests should be aware of current circumstances affected by construction at the Jane which are, according to their website, expected to be ongoing until February 2025.    I’ve stayed here twice a year for about 7 years (not during the pandemic, obviously) and always been satisfied.  In the past:  interactions with staff have been positive; rooms, though very small, are functional and clean; although bathrooms are shared I can’t recall having to wait to use a toilet, shower or sink; the location is ideal for access to West Village, Chelsea, Whitney Museum, walks along the Hudson River, etc.; the rates have always been reasonable; and the Jane has a quirky, shabby chic charm that is missing from sterile chain hotels.  My recent 6-night visit was a major disappointment after years of being pleased.  Construction is taking place which is extremely disruptive.  Just some examples of unpleasant conditions:  • There was only one working bathroom on the 4th floor since the other one was sealed off, meaning 2 toilets, 2 showers and 2 sinks were to be shared by guests in the 40+ rooms on the floor.  Several mornings and evenings it was necessary to wait for a toilet and/or shower being used by other guests.  • Three separate instances during the daytime when it was necessary to wait while construction workers used toilets and sinks.  One of those times I had to wait for 3 workers who were washing up at what was apparently the end of their shift, using loads of toilet paper to dry their freshly washed faces.  Why aren’t there aren’t facilities or portable toilets assigned solely for workers?  • The website states that work takes place between 8 AM and 5 PM and will have “minimal impact” but one morning a loud grinding noise from within the bowels of the building started at 7:12 AM.  • Signs clearly state that the front entrance and the elevator are for guest and staff use only.  Returning from an early morning run the sidewalk and stairs were nearly impassable with construction workers standing and sitting blocking the front entrance.  Several times I shared the elevator with construction workers, once with 2 guys who got on at the third floor each with a large garbage can full of debris.  In fairness, other times when workers saw that a guest was on the elevator they said that they would wait.  It may seem like I’m a snob but the elevator is small and as a paying guest I don’t want to be up close and personal with a dirty/dusty worker hauling trash.  • Photos accompanying this review show just some of the construction evidence that you pass on the way to your room on the fourth floor.  Without reviewing credit card receipts from previous stays, I do believe that the rates I paid during this visit were more than I’ve ever paid and the stay was, to be blunt, extremely disappointing.  Quite frankly, the owners/management should be ashamed for accepting paying guests, especially at non-discounted rates.  I look forward to staying here again in 2025 when construction is complete but until then my hotel stays in NYC will be elsewhere.…

We could not wait to leave this place as it is by far the worst place we have ever stayed at. It truly has no redeeming qualities as both the rooms and service are horrendous. The staff is rude and cannot be bothered to, not only do their jobs but, act remotely human. Do not expect anyone to acknowledge you or assist you here.    Our trip started off on the wrong foot when we checked-in. We approached the front desk/reception and two individuals behind the desk were talking. When we got there, they looked at us, stared, and then kept on with their conversation. When one of them was ready (I think her name was Fran), she looked up and gestured us to the desk. She did not say "hello" or "good morning" and just asked for the name the reservation was under. We were early for check-in and knew that we likely would not be able to get a room right away, but we asked if she could give us an estimate and she said she wouldn't and that we should assume that it will be after the normal check-in at 3:00 because they were busy that day (never mind that it was in the middle of the week and we were the only ones in the lobby at the time). She also said that they do not have a queue, so we can call and check periodically if we wanted to. This was unusual as other hotels usually take down names and numbers and call guests when rooms are available, as a courtesy. Nonetheless, we asked if there was a particular number we should call and she told us to look up the phone number on the website. She had zero interest in hospitality or just being a nice person. After that encounter, we left the hotel and, about an hour later we called and another individual told us that they had several rooms available and we could come back and check-in. Had we not called, we would not have checked-in until about 6 hours later.   Once we checked-in, we went up to the room. While the hotel lobby and bar are decent, the hallways and rooms of this hotel can only be described as dark and dingy. The hallway is poorly lit and the carpet in the hallways and rooms looks like it has not been vacuumed or cleaned in years.   Our room was a "premium queen." There was nothing "premium" about this room. It was small, but that is not the issue we had with it as that is typical for most NY hotels. The carpet (again) was disgusting. The room was so poorly ventilated that the air inside was thick. The AC was set at 77 degrees and it could not be changed. The ventilation was so bad that when we took a shower, the room smelled like mildew because the bathroom did not have a fan or a window that opened. Our towels never dried because of the moisture that was consistently in the bathroom and room for the four days we were there. We had to open the door to the room to let some "fresh" air in from the hallway and let the moisture out. It would get so hot in the room that we would go into the hallway just to cool down.   The bathroom was another disaster. The toilet was not properly secured to the ground and wiggled when you sat on it. The handle also leaked every time we flushed. The shower only had a curtain that barely did anything to keep the water in. So, between the leaking toilet and the shower, the bathroom floor always had puddles of water that we needed to clean up. The shower curtain also contributed to the dampness and mildew-smell as it never dried. Also, there was no thought put into the bathroom. The space is understandably small, but a little thought into additional hooks or shelves so that guests can properly hang their clothes or place their toiletries goes a long way. I have stayed in smaller hotels in Europe where the function of the small rooms is incredible.   Lastly, to top everything off, we found a cockroach in the bathroom. Sadly, I wasn't surprised by this cockroach and I was more surprised by the fact that there weren't more in the room considering how dirty and dingy everything was.   To say the least, we could not wait to check out and leave, which is a feeling I have never had in NY or any other place I have stayed at. It is extremely disappointing to stay at a place that has zero sense of hospitality and clearly does not care about upkeep, all the while paying over $400/night. This hotel is not even that old, so why management has just completely given up is beyond me.…

We stayed at HGU New York for four nights during the Christmas break of 2023. The overall experience was mediocre, and there are several pros and cons we would like to share.Pros:Location - that is the main reason why we picked this hotel. It is a minute away from the subway line 6 station, ~5 mins walk from the Empire State Building / Koreatown, and ~15 mins walk from the Penn station. So it is very convenient to visit different places via public transportation or get delicious authentic Asian food.Staff - the hotel staff at the concierge and cafe are friendly and helpful. Even it was the busiest season during the year, they were nice enough to provide the help as much as they can. We arrived at the hotel much earlier than the expected time, but the lady at the concierge was still able to check us in. We also had some great conversations with the cleaning crews. Pet friendly policy - we were traveling with our little dog, and the hotel policy allowed her staying with us. There was a $150 fee for the entire stay, which is a common and reasonable price in NYC.Cons:Room - we booked a standard Queen room, but we were astonished by its size once opening the door. It was extremely small (200 sqft at most) even for the standard of NYC, and we did not have enough room to place our luggage or even walk freely. There was no view from the window, and the room was so dark that we had to turn on the light all the time during our stay. The pictures of the rooms provided by the hotel were not close to the reality.Elevator - there are two elevators in the building. But one of them is used exclusively by the service crew, which means all the guests on the entire ten floors need to share one elevator. There were multiple times that we spent prolonged time waiting for the elevator. You can choose to use the stairway instead, but the stairs are steep and somehow sketchy.Dinning service - the complementary breakfast was included for our stay. The barista at the cafe was nice and friendly, but the dining experience was poor which is related to how the cafe works. When we ordered food at the cafe, the barista had to contact with the kitchen upstairs, and goes upstairs to pick up the food when it was ready amid preparation of hot drinks for other guest. The waiting time can be ridiculously long during the rush hour. The quality of food was actually decent, but it was just unacceptable to wait 40 minutes for a tuna salad sandwich.Overall, our experience at HGU New York has been a disappointment. We understand that the hotel has done their best to accommodate as many as guests during the Christmas, but the amenity of the hotel needs some substantial improvement. We would not recommend it if you are traveling with a big family, or for an extended period of time. To note, HGU New York was under the “small luxury hotel” brand, but you would only expect the first half of it as it has nothing to do with anything luxury.

Located in Manhattan West at the northern tip of the High Line, the Pendry is steps from Hudson Yards & sights like the Edge. The eye-catching facade is made up of undulating waves of floor-to-ceiling windows providing front facing rooms semi-circle window nooks. I admired my corner studio whose features included an open concept living plan with 1 500 sq. ft. footprint.  A cocooned window seating area was neat but the pinnacle amenity was the wall of floor-to-ceiling windows affording lots of natural light and superior vistas of the cityscape. The heavenly marbleized bath was outfitted with a soaker tub (by a window), walk-in shower and double vanity. A wide complement of eating/drinking venues graces the Pendry. The sultry Bar Pendry is a classic waterhole where I enjoyed small bites and handcrafted drinks ......like the Moscow Mule.....kicked like a mule. The Garden Room is a casual relaxing space serving small bites, daytime coffee and evening cocktails. Zou Zou's, a well respected eatery, serves Eastern Mediterranean food-fare the likes of Duck Borek and fire roasted Leg of Lamb. I selected the Octopus Carpaccio, Smoked Cherry Baby Lamb Chops, Lemon Frozen Yogurt and Prosecco to wash it down.........a terrific food collage. Chez Zou is a premier cocktail lounge with unusual pairings like Bananas & Bourbon and Vermouth & Picked Cucumbers and others. The Vista Lounge is a modern dining space focusing on glorious breakfast food-fare for guests and locals alike. The Pendry wellness amenities feature a 24/7 1700 sq. ft. Fitness Center and a Movement Studio with high-tech equipment and Peleton Bikes, the bikes can be requested in-room. So, if you are searching for a Manhattan escape in high-end, California-inspired digs ......................then try the .............Pendry..............a West Coast vibe in Manhattan.…

I was recently in NYC for a work event, and chose this hotel because it was literally on the same block as the venue, and I was anticipating a fair amount of travel between the two, multiple times a day.    Because it was a work trip, I set the bar for my lodging expectations fairly low:  I need a private bathroom, a comfortable bed, good wifi to get work done, and some way to acquire breakfast (either within the hotel, or very close by).  That's it.  And while I *technically* did experience these things (which is why this is not a one star review), the quality of each was so sub-par, I wound up shortening my trip and checking out out early.  My sliding shower door barely slid and required significant force (and I say that as someone who is 5'10" and works out regularly).  The toilet handle was not attached to the tank, and was just hanging out the side.  The pillows were each so flat, I could ball one up and grip it in my hand.  Good luck with breakfast if you don't eat meat or are trying to limit carbs.  And the clincher--that is the worst wifi connection I have experienced in YEARS.  Oh, but wouldn't you know it, for $5, I could have a "premium" connection; I shouldn't have to pay extra to simply browse the internet and respond to emails.  I couldn't *function* in this room.  I could look past the occasional cosmetic issues--inexplicable stains on the mirrors, chipped furniture, etc (I don't think anyone staying here is expecting luxury), but there were enough to notice that collectively, the room felt very worn and tired.  I found the staff cold (with the exception of one maintenance worker I kept bumping into), with zero acknowledgement that I was a Hilton Honors member (I should note that I personally don't need this acknowledged, but in the after-stay survey I was emailed, this was a detail about which they asked).  When I checked out early, the woman at the front desk was visibly confused, asked another employee for assistance, who curtly and without any eye contact or acknowledgement that something might be amiss to require the early departure, simply said, "yeah, it's fine."  No goodbye, no thank you, nothing.  Just, "ok, that's it."  There are two other hotels on this block, and when I return for the same work event next year, I will be staying elsewhere.  I was willing to spend an additional $125 to move my flight early just to avoid staying in this hotel any longer than I had to.…

While I made my own reservation for Lotte New York Palace online, Marie of the Reservations Department had emailed me a few days prior to my arrival to learn more about my brief trip with my daughter to see some Broadway show in NYC.  (I thought it was a nice touch to greet us even before we boarded the plane.)  Marie acted like a goodwill ambassador on behalf of the hotel and wished us a great stay in advance of our arrival.On arrival day, Nana helped us with our luggage as we exited the taxi, but since my daughter and I only had one carry-on each, we needed no further assistance and thanked him for his time.As we entered the hotel through the revolving door, Captain, Mike Murray welcomed us back, remembering we had just been at the property 5 months prior.  Mike commented on how nice my daughter’s luggage looked.  (She was using luggage that was colorfully decorated in the “Yellow Submarine” characters made famous by the Beatles movie of the same name.)  Mike briefly chatted with my daughter about the Beatles and Paul McCartney, which instantly put a smile on my daughter’s face.Anne-Marie, at the Front Desk welcomed us back and checked us into our room—a beautiful corner suite in the Towers.My daughter and I ordered In-Room Dining several times and were greeted on the phone by Leslie, who was very polite and courteous while answering my questions.  Denzel and Maxine delivered our food and asked how our stay was going as they moved the food from the cart to the living room table, per my requests.  (The food was as it’s always been—fantastic.  Their chocolate crème brûlée is my personal favorite.)  On our last day, Lincy check-out the room for us and thanked us for staying at the property.  The Doorman, George, noticed my daughter’s luggage and struck up a conversation with her about musical groups, concerts and his favorite performers, all while hailing a cab for us.  He was very energetic, very entertaining and very enthusiastic about his job—again, leaving a smile on my daughter’s face.It was only a two-day trip, but the elegant hotel, it’s perfect location (across the street from St. Patrick’s Cathedral and walking distance to many NYC sights) along with world-class service of the hotel employees, made it a trip I will always remember…

I wanted to take my wife for a really nice trip to New York as it was her first time in the city.  I am not a New York expert in any way shape or form and there are obviously a LOT of hotels there, so I spent quite a long time looking for the right place.  I think the first choice most of us have is what budget we have to spend.  Do you want to spend USD200 - USD400 to stay in a Hilton, Omni,  Sheraton etc type of hotel, USD400 to USD600 to stay somewhere a step up from that or USD600+ to stay in one of the best hotels.  If you are taking that first step up and pay more than the standard then the hotel has to be worth it and I think the Pendry was!  My reasons why are below:-  Location - This was one of the most important factors for me.  Once again I am not a NY expert but I kind of figured out that most of the things I would want to see, places to go shopping or restaurants to go eat were somewhere between Washington park and the bottom of Central Park.  Given that there would be some days I might not want to walk or get the metro but get an Uber I wanted somewhere that was sort of in the middle of that area and therefore accessible via Uber (which is very expensive!).  The second thing was that reading reviews on here people would complain about coming out of their hotel around Times Square/Midtown and being met by sights they did not want to see….The Pendry is in a quiet, clean street with high class offices and a business square behind it so was basically in a perfect and safe location.  Room - As we weren’t planning on spending lots of time in the room it didn’t matter to us to book a luxury room.  We stayed in the standard room which was spacious, tastefully decorated, with a nice view over the office square behind the hotel.  The shower was powerful and constantly hot.  The room was clean on our arrival and well cleaned during our stay there.  The room was also quiet, the bed was large and comfortable and the black out curtains cut out the light and the air conditioning was perfect so you could have the quality sleep there that you would expect from a hotel this level.  The rest of the hotel - We didn’t chose to eat in the hotel and didn’t use any of the facilities really but the gym was big and it had a couple of nice looking bars that would have been good to have a late night drink in.  Given the huge choice of places to eat in NY, perhaps the hotel could think a little bit outside of the box to incentivize guests to go and eat at the restaurant…  The service/staff - We aren’t demanding/fussy guests so had limited interactions with the staff other than at check in where Violet was very nice and efficient and managed to find us a room when we arrived early which was hugely appreciated and at check out where Luis was super professional and just left us with a great final impression.  The hotel also took a few different deliveries for us and held and delivered all of them for us efficiently and professionally.  My experience was that for the price band you pay for the Pendry there is nothing I could really fault the hotel for and did not regret spending the extra.  I would definitely stay there again and wish the hotel and all the staff there huge continued success!…

We stayed at the Ritz-Carlton Nomad just this past weekend to celebrate our 2-year anniversary (we were married at the Ritz-Carlton St. Louis and are Ritz-Carlton loyalists) as well as to take in the holiday sights and experiences that NYC is known for.  Before booking I went back and forth between the Ritz-Carlton Central Park and this property and in hindsight am beyond happy and ecstatic that we chose the Nomad location.  Considering I cannot think of any negatives to report on, I'll focus on the areas that impressed us most:The location: We spent much of our days in the Midtown vicinity seeing shows, the Christmas prerequisites such as the Rockefeller tree and the storefronts along Madison and it was truly a relief knowing that we would be making our way back to the hotel and the Nomad neighborhood without the throngs of crowds and chaos.  Of course it is NYC after all and even Nomad has an electricity to it, but the neighborhood simply felt (at least to us) much calmer and more relaxed with wonderful restaurant options within walking distance (including a very festive rooftop Christmas bar at 230 Fifth Rooftop Bar). The rooms: We had a Manhattan Club Level Room with amazing views of the downtown skyline.  We slept each night with the curtains and sheers wide open so that the view is what we woke up to.  I am a bit of a bathroom snob when it comes to hotels and this one exceeded any expectations with a very large soaking tub, separate shower (with great water pressure and hot water on demand) as well as dual sinks for my husband and I.  It has plenty of space and has a spa ambiance.The Club Lounge: By far and away, above and beyond the location and the amazing room, the Club Lounge is what impressed us most and would be reason enough for us to return to the Nomad location.  David and the entire Club staff team go above and beyond with their service, friendliness, and the sense of welcoming.  The food offerings each day FAR (FAR!) exceeded most other Ritz Club Lounges (the only location that I can put on par with this one may be Naples).  The food is creative and fresh and extremely well presented, amazing desserts and different cookies each day, an excellent breakfast spread, tea service in the afternoons, and the champagne flows freely and without having to ask for a refill.  Despite being in NYC where good restaurants and drinks are plentiful, we chose to end each evening with time in the Lounge with a cocktail while we soaked up the downtown view and it truly felt like a home away from home.We joked that the only recommendation that we can think of (this is a hint to management at both locations and one that fellow lounge guests agreed with us on) would be a reciprocal agreement between the Central Park and Nomad locations that would allow Club Lounge guests to visit both locations out of convenience.  Again, considering we spent so much time in Midtown and near the park it would have been fantastic to at least have an opportunity to pop into the Central Park location for a cocktail and compare.  Likewise, for guests at the Central Park location, having access to the Lounge in Nomad may be a great way to convince them to choose this new, fantastic location for their next New York City visit and for a change of pace and scenery.I cannot say enough good things about our stay and the property and we look forward to visiting again the next time we are in NYC.

Would definitely recommend The Franklin for a great place to stay in NYC!

This was my big 40th birthday weekend in NYC. I had high hopes for this hotel, but after leaving the lobby, it went downhill fast. Reception was very nice and helpful. He promised the concierge would give some restaurant suggestions for my birthday which would be on day 3. Waited until the night of day 2 and called... concierge was out sick. Never got any suggestions. The hallway to the rooms was dark, had stained carpet, and the elevator needed a good wipe down.  We stayed in a king suite (2 adults in king and 2 kids on a pull-out sofa). My Mom stayed in another room and her bed felt like laying in a hammock (terrible). My husband requested champagne be in the room upon arrival- it wasn't there. Around 9:15 pm after a long day of travel, we had a knock on the door... the champagne arrived. Luckily my two kids were still awake. The room... where do I begin? We got a king suite. The sofa was so disgusting and dingy and looked like it was from the 80's. The mattress felt like you laid on springs and no cushion. The duvet was ratty and had rips in it. I felt so bad for my kids but they were good sports knowing it was my birthday weekend and I was already displeased with the room. They found a cigarette butt in the A/C vent. The king-room bed was somewhat comfortable but the pillows were awful. It felt like someone stuffed them with balls of socks. The carpet was stained, and the curtains in both rooms also had stains. The bathroom was so tiny and really a problem for 4 people. The sink stopper was broken and kept dropping down to stop the water from draining. It was covered in mildew along with the other drain. The shower grout also needed a deep clean. Housekeeping did a nice job sprucing up the room every day but unfortunately, the cleaning and quality of bedding was unbelievably below par. The continental breakfast was ridiculous. I've had better at a Hampton Inn. The advertised wine and cheese in the lobby sounded promising but when we arrived, it was a measly offering. One of the doormen was there for 2 days during our stay and was nice and opened the door for us, but the other one never opened the door or greeted us. In fact, my husband opened the door for someone to help them in during the rain and the doorman asked him to come inside and close the door-- completely oblivious to what just happened. Would I ever stay here again? Never. Why didn't I move hotels? We had my mother in another room, the city was busy, moving all of us would've been a task, and I didn't want to be charged for a room that I abandoned. We still had a wonderful time in the city and enjoyed the location of the hotel.

I used to look at Hilton hotels as one of the leading hotels for quality and customer service in the industry but after this stay I will choose any hotel chain besides Hilton.  I called Hilton to book our rooms as I needed connecting rooms and was told it was all set and given the price.  The night before travel I was notified for early check in on the Honors App and when I went to check in it showed three rooms and none of them were connecting.  I tried to call the hotel 4 times and never got an answer.  I then reached out to Hilton Honors and they could not reach the hotel either.  Finally reached the hotel through chat and they said they did not offer connecting rooms even though they saw that in my reservation.  After quite a bit of discussion they finally came back on the chat and said they had connecting rooms for us.  I also pre-booked for valet parking.  On the way to New York City I called to validate everything was correct and now they showed 4 rooms.  2 sets of connecting rooms.  It took a while to get the person to understand I only needed 2 connecting rooms but they finally understood and then made it sound like they did me a favor by cancelling the rooms that I never asked to be booked.  When we arrived found out we could not access valet parking and the hotel told my wife we needed to park the car ourselves in the valet garage and would have to carry our bags three blocks.  When we checked in they charged us significantly more than what was quoted when I made the reservation and told me that was the rate at the time of check-in so apparently reserving ahead of time is of no use.  The staff there was not friendly other than I would like to call out Veronica in housekeeping and the waiter in the restaurant who served us breakfast on the last day.   They provided exemplary customer service and the hotel could benefit having them train new team members on customer service.  The next day after check in I contacted Hilton Honors to discuss the overcharge and was hung up on three times.  Finally was told a manager from corporate would call me and that never happened.  A gentleman at the hotel talked to me and offered me points for the inconvenience and I responded that he could do what he wanted to but I would not stay at Hilton again after the service I saw supplied by the Honors program and the hotel both.  After returning home I contacted Hilton Honors again and relayed that I never received a call from management and was told that the file was showing that the hotel stated it was closed satisfactorily.  I told the agent that if that is what Hilton believes then it just reinforces what I see as their view of customer service.  It is to bad as the location of the hotel is great and it has an opportunity to be a premiere hotel and it would have been easy for Hilton Honors to keep my view of booking with them but the combination of the hotels approach, the way some of the staff responded, and the way that Hilton Honors responded I will move my business to another chain. This hotel is a great disappointment.   The best thing about it is its location; as mentioned by many others, Penn Station is opposite and the subway from there goes all over the city.  The hotel claims to have undergone a programme of refurbishment. I was struggling to identify where. Our room (22nd floor) has not seen any refurbishment for some time and the bathroom was from a different era. It was also very small. The common parts too clearly need some attention.  The lobby of the hotel is small. It is always busy and there are few places to sit. There always seemed to be a queue of people waiting to check-in/check-out/speak to reception. The reception staff were not the most friendly nor helpful and the duty manager was downright rude: when I talked to her about those I described as her 'colleagues', she made it quite clear they were not colleagues but her 'staff'!   We had trouble on two of the three days we stayed with our keycard for our room. to get them re-programmed, one has to show appropriate ID at reception. But our ID was in the safe in our room: neither of us is in the habit of walking around with our passports. That really sent the hotel into a tizz and we had to be escorted to our room and were watched obtaining our ID and returning to reception. One can appreciate the need for caution and care but perhaps such is the impersonal nature of large hotels with a transient clientele.  The bed was comfortable enough. There was just about sufficient storage in the room. The cleanliness of the room was not as good as I would have expected but neither was it terrible.   There is a storage facility for luggage but, of course this being New York, there is a charge for it.   This was my first stay in New York and so I am not really in a position to compare it to other hotels in the city. But comparing it to other hotels in other cities in which I have stayed, there must be better out there. I would not choose to stay here again and cannot recommend it to others. …

During our recent stay at the Maramara Park Ave Hotel, we encountered a stay that was as intriguing as it was unique. The hotel's distinct ambiance, characterized by moody, dimly lit hallways and rooms, imparted a particular atmosphere that, while captivating for some, might not entirely align with everyone's tastes. One noteworthy issue we faced was a light out over the closet, which created a visibility challenge. Though we reported it, the solution came in the form of lamps rather than a light bulb replacement.   The room's temperature controls presented their own quirk, seemingly adhering to a consistent temperature of around 69 degrees, regardless of our adjustments for heating or cooling. Nonetheless, the hotel's location close to the subway was undeniably convenient, although it's vital to mention that the nearby food pantry attracted a lot of displaced individuals, leading to their occasional presence around the building. Additionally, on the day we checked out, one of the elevators was unfortunately out of service, causing a bit of a bottleneck.  In terms of rating, the Maramara Park Ave Hotel seems to sit comfortably within the realm of a 3-star experience, not quite reaching the pinnacle of a full 5-star establishment.   Despite these nuances, the hotel's rooms were a breath of fresh air—spacious, comfortable, and perfect for unwinding. The darker ambiance might not suit everyone, but for those who appreciate a cozier setting and prioritize a conveniently located stay, it offers a unique charm.  One distinctive touch we encountered was the pervasive scent of bergamot throughout the hotel. While some might find it pleasant, I personally found it a touch overpowering, especially as it extended to the soaps and lotions provided.  Overall, the Maramara Park Ave Hotel offers an experience tailored to those who appreciate its specific atmosphere, convenient location, and unique scent. It's an excellent choice for those seeking something a bit different, but perhaps not the best fit for those desiring a more traditional or versatile accommodation experience. …

We’re not picky; all we want is clean and comfortable. The reviews all said it was a clean, comfortable place with an issue with unhoused people on the street. We were okay with that but something appears to have changed.This was probably the dirtiest hotel we’ve ever stayed in. We were there for five days and never had any housekeeping services. The carpet was filthy, there was mold growing in the bathroom and it was in a general state of disrepair. The internet was good but there were only two electrical outlets in the whole room. We had to unplug the microwave to plug in the laptop.There was no coffee maker in the room and the coffee in the common area wasn’t available for the first three days (they said they were out of plastic cups.)The main light and the bathroom light and fan were on motion detectors and came on when you walked into the room, even in the middle of the night. They were also on timers, so you had to get up to turn the lights on every half an hour. We had to unplug the reading lights by the bed to plug in my husband’s CPAP. I am giving this hotel a 3 rating, which is the average between my wife's 2.5 and my 3.5. I decided to book this hotel for end of year because of its great location and raving Tripadvisor reviews. We travel to NYC often, so we know what to expect from hotels in the city. We were not impressed by the Library Hotel and won't be going back.  There are positives for the hotel though, the first one being the aforementioned location. If you visit New York during holidays, you want to be in Midtown, close to where it all happens, but not in the middle of it (although we have stayed close to Times Square in some occasions). The area around Bryant Park, which is lovely during holidays, is our favorite.  The hotel also has a beautiful library theme, which goes well with its location in Library Way, just a few steps from the NYC Library. Every room has a topic and books that go with it. Plus, there is a great common room with lots of books, coffee and refreshments 24/7.  This is by far the highlight of the hotel, which also has a reasonable rooftop bar (which I am sure is more charming in the summertime).  So far so good, so, what did we miss?  First off, we missed the quality of service we would expect for a hotel where we paid over $500 a night. The service was so non-existent that they didn't even help us in with our luggage when they saw we were struggling with our suitcases as we were coming back from a long international flight. They didn't help us on our way out either. Overall, it felt like the service was minimal and very impersonal.  Secondly, the rooms, and the hotel as a whole, are pretty dated. Everything, from the bathroom installations to the TV or the elevators are what you would expect from a decades old hotel that has not been renovated at all. But, it is not that charming-old that we have seen in other hotels in NY. It is just plain old. I get that the library theme goes well with "old", but this is a bit of a stretch.  Again, not a horrible experience, but you can definitely do better for that price range in the city by either going to a more modern hotel or a classic but charming one.…

Also, the sofa bed is laid out poorly. The only way to get from one side of the room to the window, is to roll across the “bed” (aka piece of cotton covering the metal bars). The phone didn’t work, so we had to go to the desk downstairs when we needed something. The bathroom door felt like you were closing a vault in order to get it to fully shut. I’m guessing the building has shifted over time, but this left us shoulder checking the door to get it shut. The air would randomly set to odd temperatures (72° to 75°, 68° to 72°, etc.) without us adjusting it. This hotel has 57 floors and features 509 rooms & suites, 3 restaurants and bars, a 24 hour gym and a stylish décor.  At the time of visiting this hotel, I was a Titanium Elite member under the Marriott Bonvoy loyalty programme.  I booked a skyline view room with 2 double beds which averaged out to $700 per night.  (3 adults sharing).  I thought, being a Titanium member, I would receive a complimentary upgrade.  However, I read many reviews of New York hotels having little to no upgrades when it comes to suites.  So, I didn’t want to chance it and I used my SNA (Suite Night Award) upgrade perk under the elite benefits of the loyalty programme.    You can watch the full review on YouTube at Luxury Vegan Travel.  I chose to be upgrade to a Marvellous Suite which was successful!  The room was nice and had plenty of space, a separate lounge and bedroom, 1.5 bathrooms and 2 TVs!  Watch the video for the full details.  As an elite member, when checking in, I was given an option of a welcome amenity on top of complimentary breakfast!  The choice was 1,000 Marriott Bonvoy points or a $10 food & beverage credit.    The hotel charges a $25 destination fee, daily!  Many think this is because they are staying in Time Square.  However, the hotel, like most in New York, does not have a swimming pool, BUT, within the destination fee, the hotel can provide you with a voucher to use at a nearby gym (about 5-10 minutes walk) where they do have a swimming pool!  Pretty cool!  However, there is a decent gym onsite (more for cardio and a few weights machines and dumbbells).  The complimentary ‘elite’ breakfast is limited to a small menu (shown on the video) but they do also have an a la carte menu.  Sadly, the elite menu does not have any egg dishes for those of you who eat eggs.  These and other western breakfast options like bacon will need to be purchased from the a la carte menu.  They did have almond milk for those of you who don’t drink dairy milk.  Overall, as an elite member very close to reaching the top tier (Ambassador), I don’t think the breakfast is very good, especially compared with hotels almost in touching distance like the JW Marriott Marquis or JW Marriott Essex House.  If I plan to visit Time Square again, I would choose a different hotel, with more benefits for elite members.  However, if you are not an elite member or are gold or below, then this isn’t much of an issue and otherwise, the hotel is in a good location.  Check out the video on YouTube at Luxury Vegan Travel and I hope you enjoy it! …

Check in was 3 pm. We arrived at the hotel at 3:10pm. We went to check in at the front desk where they checked me in, paid for the room plus a few fees I didn’t know I would be paying all for them to tell me the room isn’t ready and they’ll let me know when it’s ready (should be 10-15 minutes). 3:45 rolls around and the lobby is packed full of people waiting around for their rooms to be ready. Some were waiting for over an hour for their rooms to be ready. The front desk personnel were rude to anyone who asked for an update on when the room would be ready. The reason that bothers me is if I’m an hour late to check out, I get charged another night but the hotel can withhold your room from you for over an hour and you still pay full price. My wife was feeling poorly as she is diabetic and her blood sugar needed to be checked so we asked Jose if he knew when our room would be ready. Jose was the most helpful person at the hotel. He called the manager over and explained our situation and the room was ready much quicker. The only reason I’ve given the hotel any stars at all is because of Jose. When we got into our room we discovered that we were paying $400 a night for a room the size of a shoe box that was not properly cleaned. (Cleaning was supposedly the reason we weren’t able to check in on time) there was hair in the shower, the room hasn’t been dusted, there was stuff on the sheets. Would I stay here again? Absolutely not. Moral of the story: Jose: 5 stars. Tempo by Hilton: -4 stars.

If only the service was as sparkling as the crystal.   This review is for a 2 night stay in a Classic King room on an upper floor. We dined 2x in the salon for breakfast, had cocktails in the bar, went to high tea, browsed the boutique shop and utilized the fitness room. Let me start by saying I am not a hotel snob…I’ve stayed everywhere from Holiday Inn Express to The Four Seasons. I also worked in the hotel industry for 18 years. This review is based on this experience relative to the price and my industry experience.  Departments, in order of effectiveness and level of professional service (from best to worst)  1.	Housekeeping/Engineering. The rooms and common areas were IMMACULATE. I cannot say enough about the level of cleanliness. Unparalleled turn-down service. It felt like I was the first person to ever stay in room 1103. Everything was fresh and spotless, not a speck of trash in the common areas. We literally saw someone scrubbing the lobby bar floor on her hands and knees.  Engineering - the sheer fact that you rarely saw engineering meant they were doing their job. We saw them one day painting baseboards in the hallway. (One light in the salon spotlighting a chandelier was out though.) 2.	Bell Staff/Doormen. Professional, friendly interactions, (esp Kelvin) who remembered our name and offered bottled water upon our departure to the airport. 3.	Front Desk. The female who checked me in was very thorough and literally escorted me inside the elevator and showed me how to use the key pad. She explained the hours of operation for all facilities and fully detailed the amenities.  4.	Food and Beverage. This was the most hit or miss department. Service ranged from acceptable to frustrating. The host stand was the most consistent and professional, esp the woman with a high ponytail and a mask (Mickie?). Drinks went dry numerous times both days, we had to go to another table to get Splenda (30 minutes after they opened, so clearly not restocked from the day before), straw wrappers and sugar packets laid in clear view in excess of 10 minutes before someone finally cleared them (This NEVER would have happened at other Fine establishments). We always had to ask for the check to be delivered. They mixed up our tea pots during tea service.  5.	Concierge and Fitness Room Attendant. The Concierge is usually a primary player in high end hotels, but here he meekly sat at a desk in the lobby and did not interact AT ALL with lobby patrons. When there was a line waiting to check in, he didn’t stand up and interact with guests, thank them for waiting, introduce himself and offer his services. When we passed by en route to/from the boutique, he didn’t even look up or offer a simple greeting.  Fitness Room Attendant…there wasn’t one. It certainly doesn’t have to be a full time attendant, but no one even bothered to check the facility within the duration of a 90 minute workout.  Memorable Touches/Pros •	Stunning bar décor  •	Each hallway was like a mini-museum with Baccarat pieces outside rooms •	Rooms were impeccably designed using mirrored surfaces to enlarge. Every detail reflected the Baccarat brand…from the faucet handles to the glassware in the mini bar. •	In-room beverage amenities, boxed chocolates, toiletry items •	In room stationary, debossed notepad, feather pen •	Room keys designed in the color and shape of the brand logo with a decorative silver key attached •	Fitness room hours were 7am-7pm but stated they would open outside those hours upon request •	Visible security throughout property •	Low profile hotel exterior and signage feels like you’re walking into a secret place  •	Across from MOMA  Missed Opportunities •	Boutique should sell the book featured in the room, their signature scents, tea sachets as used in the afternoon tea •	Coffee/tea service in horribly bland mugs and pots •	No matchbooks •	Non-logoed sugar packets •	Offering a dessert-only tea (without savory elements)   Food and Beverage •	Unnecessarily extravagant pricing for the bar. Their signature Old Fashioned (with custom Makers Mark), although showy, was $54. •	The tea service was also overpriced at $140. They also offer a vegetarian tea (same price) off menu.  •	Food presentation was always good, but the fledgling service detracted from the kitchen’s best efforts   Fitness Room •	What a disappointment…the room itself should have some design on the windows (echo the print that was on the bedsheets, perhaps).  •	Mini fridge was filled with glass water bottles that were always lukewarm at best.  •	No chilled towels as advertised. We called the concierge to get some because no one checked on us. Someone came down after 10 minutes and said they didn’t have any chilled towels, but could run one under cold water for us????? …

Great communication emails before I arrived so I was able to let myself in to the Victorian hallway and sitting room where jazz music was playing in the background, somewhere I heard a cat meowing.  Rene was not there to greet me, but I knew to climb the stairs to the Chester Himes room on the first floor at the front of the house, with a welcome note on the door.  A radio was also set playing jazz music softly as I entered the beautifully restored room with its comfortable old style high bed and eccentric décor. Even though the room overlooked the street it was quiet and I slept perfectly.  The shared bathroom on the hallway was no inconvenience and like a museum of Victorian plumbing and tiles with its clawfoot bath and vintage shower.  The place is close to the underground and bus stops only twenty minutes from downtown Manhattan, and I felt safe walking home at night.  Being able to leave my bags in the sitting room to collect later after I checked out was a real bonus as I had a late evening flight back to London. I met Rene on the last of my three days and had an interesting chat about how he restored the interior.  The Flophouse was great value, my only regret is that my stay did not encompass one of Rene’s live jazz nights, I will definitely stay again when I visit NY.
