This hotel, as of April 2023 and through at least August of 2023, is under renovation. I am told it will be going on for at least another year, probably more. The photos of the interior spaces of the hotel are beautiful, but they were taken before the renovation began. They do not portray the reality at all. There is no functioning kitchen or restaurant, no dining room, no lounge or sitting area of any kind, and obviously no room service. There are the rooms, and the front desk. That is all. In the morning, they set up a cart with Croissants and a couple of coffee pots. You are permitted one croissant per person in your room. They count them. If you need to wait in the lobby for any reason, the only place to sit is on a bench along the wall. The room we stayed in smelled like mildew, the mattresses seemed to be very, very old and worn out, and the bathroom smelled like a litter box. It had a moldy, plastic shower curtain. The front desk lost two of our jackets, and it took almost 6 months to get them to pay for them. When they did pay, they…”Adjusted for depreciation.”  Location is of course great, as is the park view, but I cannot shake the feeling that they are desperate at the W to keep it occupied and are being dishonest keeping the beautiful photos live (above) Noe of it exists at all. Arriving late at night with my young kids and there not being a morsel of food to feed them was a BAD feeling. That neighborhood is uncharacteristically closed down at night. The staff was friendly, but unable to provide any of the servces one would expect from a good - or even lousy - hotel.

We stayed at NH Collection for two nights during a 40th anniversary museum and Broadway getaway to NYC the week before Christmas. The hotel is in a perfect location for such a visit. We reserved the “Deluxe Room with a View”. We arrived at the hotel about three hours ahead of the 3 p.m. check-in time, intending to leave our bags and go out for a few hours. However, Deniz at the front desk found a room that would soon be cleaned and told us to stand by. Chatting with her about current art exhibits, she learned that it was an anniversary trip and upgraded us to a room with a king bed and two corner city views. Still decidedly NYC size, but comfortable for us and the modern, simple decor was relaxing. The lobby and lobby lounge are quite spacious with many areas for conversation and relaxation. During our stay Deniz also had a bottle of wine and a chocolate sampler delivered. We felt like we had a friend in the lobby. That first day we discovered the Morgan Library, just over a block from the hotel. The Library is a lesser-known attraction that is well worth a couple of hours for those interested in books, history, and architecture, with the bonus of an excellent café for lunch. When we arrived back at the hotel after dinner the lounge had a good jazz band playing to top off our day. The next morning, we had the hotel buffet breakfast which featured a wide array of American and European choices, at a reduced price for hotel guests, to get us out for a long day of MOMA and Broadway. On our final morning, we picked up a good breakfast from Rico Bagel across the street, checked out, and stored our bags while we went to the Met. The staff are uniformly friendly, pleasant, and helpful and we highly recommend this hotel.  …

I'm staying at  Club Wyndham Midtown 45 and deeply disappointed by the unethical practices I encountered. This experience has not only soured my view of this particular property but also of the Wyndham brand as a whole.Upon check-in on January 18th, my wife and I were invited to a briefing about property ownership enhancements. We were assured this was simply for feedback, not a sales pitch. Lured by the promise of a $100 incentive, we agreed to attend.Contrary to what was promised, we were subjected to an aggressive sales pitch. Worse yet, without our explicit consent, they ran a hard credit check on my wife! When we specifically asked if our credit was being checked, we were given a dubious "no," which turned out to be blatantly untrue.This incident is more than just a hard-sell tactic; it's a serious breach of trust and privacy. The lack of transparency and respect for customer consent is not only unethical but also deeply concerning for any potential guest.As a result, I strongly advise against staying at this property or engaging with the Wyndham brand. Their practices, as I've experienced, are misleading and show a disturbing disregard for customer autonomy and privacy.Be wary of offers that seem too good to be true at this property. Unfortunately, in my case, it led to a situation where my trust was betrayed, and my personal information was handled inappropriately.

Potentially a great hotel (as it used to be in a bygone era, so I've read). Stayed for two nights for business on the top floor, small but convenient room, well equipped with a coffee machine, comfortable bedding, looking over the back yard so perfectly quiet (an asset as 32nd street can be quite noisy). My only issue was a shower that took some time to warm up. In dire NY winters, the individual radiator is definitely an asset. I liked the fantastic Art Nouveau facade of the hotel and its history : the Hotel Aberdeen was popular in the Roaring Twenties and was one of the first places to accept individual bookings by woman. The place comes along with its own mystery story, the death of a Mary Jeannette Caley in suite 72 (when there were suites) back in 1905. I didn't have the opportunity to meet her ghost... Great location, very friendly and helpful staff - a bit pricey, but this is NY and hotel rooms are hard to secure! My advice would be to spruce up the lobby and some of the facilities to recall the old Hotel Aberdeen (maybe retrieve the name that can still be read on the side of the building). More could be made of this place as it boasts a landmarked facade, quite a history and, yes, a great location. Much of Manhattan is within walking distance, some great restaurants (in particular the Press Club Grill), ten minutes from Penn Station. A place I'd recommend and gladly return to.

When I was 18 I watched the somewhat highbrow BBC Arena arts documentary about life at The Hotel Chelsea, it had fascinated me and I'd always wanted to visit. With the refurb finished, and despite some reservations about gentrification, I decided that we should go and stay over Christmas. It was expensive and towards the top of the budget so my expectations were high. But delighted to say I loved my time there and felt really at home. They were kind enough to offer us an upgrade to the Pied a Terre apartments, which really helped us have a great and relaxing stay.  I really have no criticism of the apartments the beds were super comfortable and the apartment spacious and homely, but sone with style and taste. There where a few minor wrinkles that I only mention as to offer scope for making things even better: 1) There are some paint splatters on the grey/white marble tiles, it just needs someone with a good eye to scrap them of. 2) Some of the bathroom fittings are a little poorly done (loose or away from the wall), and again a component maintenance man could fix these. 3) Brass is a nightmare as it needs polishing, in general I didn't might the patina but around the toilets and in the bathrooms it looked a little unclean. 4) The sealant around the bath in 3E is beyond amateurish, it just needs redoing. 5) The hallways could benefit from some coat storage to prevent clutter in the apartment, especially if the weather is poor you've nowhere to put wet things. 6) The lighting in the closets is a great idea, but the top shelf stops the light illuminating the clothes making it a little useless. None of this impinged on our stay and the uniqueness and history more than made up for those tiny details.  Not sure how I can justify and return visit but I'm working on it. Loved it.Thanks to all the staff in the hotel and Cafe Chelsea for the warmth and hard work.…

I booked this hotel as we had always had very good luck at the Hampton Inn on 8th Ave which is now rebranded.  I read the reviews on the train ride up to NYC and was sure it could not be as bad as the reviews.  Some are accurate, some not as much.The AC system in the rooms is just odd.  The cycling on and off all night was very annoying and it did not seem that we had any control over it.The elevators were not as bad but took some effort.   They were mostly broken when we left so we missed that fun.   We saw the maintenance staff prying the doors open as we departed.The room itself was a mix.  Beds were fine, TV was big.  Bathroom was tiny. There was no soap or conditioner, and it took three calls to get it addressed.  Sink was the size of a postcard.  I never thought I would agree with a previous review that the room itself had too many overdesigned sharp edges.  Everything from the nightstand to the frame around the TV and the art was intrusive and sharp  -- cannot imagine a family with small kids not getting out of there without a bruise or cut.  This is made worse as the room is really tight even by NYC standards. There was no room for a basic suitcase let alone 3 .Breakfast was on par with other Hampton Inns.  Timing is everything.   The staff there was friendly and turned the tables quickly.   The staff was a mix of nice, to not even looking up at you.  I am sure they hear complaints a lot so I get it.  Seems that some training could be in order.The location is nice for shows and overall the property is safe and quiet.  I hope they can work out the issues here but we will not be returning soon.

Overall, the apartment was perfect for us. It was bright, spacious, mostly well-outfitted for longer stays (we were there just shy of 3 weeks), and the staff were uniformly friendly and helpful.  The supplies like soap, towels, kitchen supplies and utensils, were well-thought out and useful.  It was very clean when we arrived and was easy to keep clean. It was surprisingly quiet, given its location on a major tunnel entrance/exit, and the view of very large buildings that was due to that presence on the major arterial (thus space to see the buildings rather than just walls) gave us endless entertainment. Those visible buildings were mostly if not entirely offices, so they were quiet in the evenings and weekends. The picture on this site showing the interior shows those buildings across the recessed arterial.  Things that were a little annoying and didn't really affect our affection for the place:  1) The bed was fairly wavy/not flat, and although it didn't give us backaches or anything, it was challenging to find comfortable sleeping positions.   2) The couch (similar to the one in the picture here) was great to lie down on, not so much to sit in without adding many pillows. Since there were more pillows than we needed on the bed, this worked out fine. Not sure if it was pull-out bed, the top cushion was nice as it was.   3) The bathtub drained slowly, so you were almost always standing in a pool. I could hear the neighboring units having the same problem, and it did always drain. That was not an issue but it was odd.  4) Seemingly because it's a building with glass front (looks like a former office building that was converted, which it was), there were no exhaust fans anywhere. The only way to get smells out was to open the glorious windows, which we did for brief times in January and which fixed the smell problem, and steam from the shower seemed to dissipate in the dry January air. Still, no exhaust fans was odd.  Again, none of those things would cause us not to stay there, except maybe if the bed was worse than it was. But it wasn't, and we would love to stay there again for even longer, and hope we can.…

My family's stay at Comfort Inn JFK was lacking a lot of things. One, there was an awful odor in the air. Two, there were no stores nearby or restaurants to eat at, buy or shop for anything. They are still serving breakfast in brown bags which only offer a lot of sugary items, even the bagel isn't really a real one and nothing is served hot except for the tea or coffee that you can get from the dispenser in the lobby. I would recommend running to another hotel nearby for hot food if you are stuck like we were.  As the rest of the story goes, we had originally booked to stay in the Queen Double Room, and we had to switch to a Standard Double Room due to the strong smell (awful odor) from outside coming into the room. The photos on Booking.com do not show that you are near a sanitation depot/ landfill which doesn't help especially if you have allergies or other health issues. We had no choice after being exhausted and already paying for our 4-day stay and were told there were no other Queen Double rooms available. So, we took the Standard Double and were not compensated for the difference.  Then during the last 2 days of our stay there was no hot water, and we could not take a shower from Saturday into Sunday and were not able to have proper hygiene and be comfortable for our flight. This is all added to the stress after attending a funeral for a family member. We asked the front desk about this and if there was anything they could do. They told us to reach out to the manager via email later about it as he was not available on the weekend. We did, and even spoke to him about it. But we never heard back as he said he would reach out to us and try to make up for the inconvenience. Very disappointed and it shows a lack of caring for their customers' experience at their hotel and the hotel could have offered to do more in terms of service and customer satisfaction. …

I was astonished at how different this hotel was from the way it’s advertised. This is not a 4-star hotel. Our bathroom had drop ceiling tiles with water stains on them and thick dust around the edges along the wall. The bathroom floor was visibly grubby. The bathroom light fixture was the cheapest kind you’d buy somewhere like Home Depot. The towels were scratchy and cheap feeling. The lampshades in the room were both stained—gross. One of the lamps didn’t even turn on. There was a visible tear in the duvet cover. We had requested a room not near the elevator when we made our reservation via the hotel’s own website but our room was (you guessed it) right by the elevator. Oh! I almost forgot: you cannot adjust the temperature in your room—we had a window a/c unit that barely worked and a wall thermostat that didn’t respond to our attempts to modify the temperature. Plus, the windows paired with the window a/c unit let any traffic sound right into your room. The entire experience was so very disappointing, but since we were only staying for one night, we decided to just go through with our visit. In the end, we paid about $526 for the room rate plus taxes and fees for a room that felt like something at a sleazy motel. Honestly, we burst out laughing after we checked out and got outside. I’ll never stay here again.

Our 10-year celebration was shadowed by neglect at The Beekman, where anticipation met disappointment. The saga commenced at check-in, revealing a room devoid of basic toiletries, setting a precedent for the days to follow. Despite explicit requests—confirmed twice—for room cleaning over our 3-night journey, action was taken on only one occasion, leaving us in a perpetual state of discontent.When our room was grudgingly attended to, the service was superficial at best: counters, desks, and nightstands bore the tales of previous encounters, marred with debris and untouched trash. Personal items, including computers and toothbrushes, were recklessly displaced—abandoned on the floor and in the shower, devoid of care.Our plea for shower caps—a simple request—dragged on for an hour, further straining our patience and cramping our evening plans. The absence of fresh towels and unchanged sheets amplified our discomfort, painting a grim picture of neglect.What was to be a joyous celebration of a decade together turned into a narrative of oversight. Offered a mere consolation of 2 bar coupons amidst our voiced concerns at the front desk felt like a dismissive gesture, inadequately addressing the gravity of our compromised stay.Our anniversary, earmarked for joy, was eclipsed by a litany of lapses at The Beekman, deeply engraving our experience with disappointment.

Before I start, I need to say that all staff I encountered at Da Vinci were extremely pleasant, professional, and helpful.  Our room was very clean.   It is not their fault that the owner of this hotel does not value supporting them with a building that is not run down and in need of maintenance and basic updating.  In fact, the only reason I give this hotel 2 stars is BECAUSE of the staff.  They are holding it together.  They deserve a serious bonus for having to deal with the shortcomings of this place.Location is great, but for the price I was surprised to find:1). TV/Cable boxes that do not work.  And it's not just our TV.  It is many room's TVs in the hotel.  They just don't connect.  It was almost comical....2). Furniture that looked like it was picked up at a garage sale and painted cream.  Which by the way is the same cream color as the walls, trim, and everything else.  A lazy way to freshen up I'm thinking....3). An unsecured front door. There is no keyed entry.  Anyone can walk in and go to any room and the elevator.  Yes, the staff is there....but that's it.4). Rooms have no carpet.  Which honestly was a good thing because then you know there is less of a chance of bugs, but the floor was some sort of composite that was cold.  it made the room cold and not fun to be in.5) Bathroom was clean, but there is mold in the grout. It's not from lack of trying with the cleaning staff.  The room was very clean.  It's the kind of mold that has permanently stained the grout and needs to be redone.   The tile and fixtures look very new, so it was odd that the tub doors were outdated and with mold.  Plus, whoever installed the tile and marble left gaps and poorly cut out areas everywhere.  There was a huge hole around the shower head.6) Some of the linens were old.  We had many cigarette holes in the pillow shams and blankets. Some of our towels were old and thin with a few threadbare holes.I'm not a fussy person and I don't need fancy accommodations.  I have stayed in MANY older hotels in the Central Park South/Midtown area without these issues.  I was not expecting a modern hotel.  This was just a sad case of a building not being kept current and comfortable.  There was nothing charming about this place.The restaurant that was attached - Joe Gs Italian - was very good.  Excellent pizza and salad.  Very nice dining room.  Too bad the attached hotel is not to that standard.There are better places to stay for the same $$.  We won't be returning.

The HGU New York Hotel is quirky and interesting. It is NOT, in reality, as the fabulous photographs would indicate and we were particularly disappointed that the restaurant wasn’t functioning and that the stunning room, depicted in the photographs, was used as an ‘occasional’ bar.Our King Size Deluxe Double room contained one of the most comfortable beds we have ever slept in. The linen was immaculate and luxurious and the room was replenished with white fluffy towels everyday. Everywhere was spotlessly clean and beautifully decorated. What stopped this room from fulfilling its potential was the astonishing SMALL size of the room and the absence of any natural light. The ‘slit’ window promised a ‘courtyard’ view, but looked out on to a litter strewn service corridor. Throughout our entire sixteen night stay we had to have artificial lighting on whenever we were in the room. The room was dark and oppressive and we felt claustrophobic throughout our stay. We desperately needed natural light…Customer Service is universally poor. The person who checked us in, and checked us out, seemed to regard the presence of any guest as an inconvenience. As our photograph depicts, a member of the staff team is taking an afternoon lap in the residents lounge!! The hotel is very well located and subway links are excellent. We could walk to most attractions and the immediate area is vibrant and cosmopolitan.The hotel lift wasn’t working for the latter half of our stay and, while this couldn’t be helped, was hugely inconvenient.All photographs for HGU New York are very misleading. This is not a Four Star hotel by any stretch of the imagination.

This is a beautiful five star hotel located smack in the middle of midtown Manhattan, conveniently next to a subway line, near Central Park. The rooms are very large, elevators work well, there is a nice pool/spa area at the top of the hotel, and the rooms are well appointed.  Staffing is somewhat limited, and lines can form at various areas. The lobby floor is crowded and just essentially a snaking hallway around to the elevator. Also, the upcharges for everything are incredibly annoying. Every attempt to get more money for a room upgrade just degrades from the fact that this is a very nice and fancy hotel. Also, our room wasn't spotlessly clean when we finally checked in. I can detail this, but small but obvious things made the room less than spotless. We were upcharged for a room upgrade, and then our room's availability was delayed until after it was supposed to be ready, and then the room was not spotlessly clean. They were very apologetic and generous to make up for this unfortunate mistake, and more than made up for the error with a room credit, waving the upgrade charge, and a free breakfast, which was excellent.  Now.. to the breakfast. If it's included in your rate, it's very good. The service is competent and friendly and professional. The food is well made and high quality. The prices are laughable. Expect to spend $60+ per person for breakfast that includes a modest breakfast entree and a single drink. I know, fancy hotel prices in NYC. But please, step outside. Go to any number of decent restaurants nearby and spend 1/4 the price. Look, the food and service are good. But the prices are just stupid. $14 for tea should be loose leaf in a fancy teapot, not a teabag. We all enjoyed the breakfast, but it is just stupid what it costs.  If you want huge rooms in a very nice hotel and can look past some of these problems to get a location that is perfect for exploring the park or going to a show, you will enjoy the Park Hyatt. I usually spend a little less, go in with lower expectations, and am more satisfied because of it.…

As a family of five, we recently stayed at the Ritz Carlton NoMad for a three-night family reunion and birthday celebration. We are Marriott Bonvoy Gold Members and have stayed in over ten Ritz Carlton properties through the Amex find hotels program. Our experience at this particular property, however, was deeply disappointing and distressing.From the onset, we faced unwarranted suspicion and disrespect, particularly from a security guard named Edward Hanes. He followed us from the entrance to our rooms, scrutinizing us as if we were not legitimate guests, despite our confirmed bookings. His unprofessional conduct continued in the lobby, where he made us feel unwelcome and repeatedly questioned our guest status.The mistreatment extended to my three adult children, who were confronted by the same security guard and rudely told to leave the lobby, a public space, with no justification. This confrontation occurred under the watch of other hotel employees, who did not intervene.The following day, another hotel employee instructed us to leave the lobby unless we were purchasing something from the restaurant. This directive was inconsistent and seemingly discriminatory, as other guests were allowed to remain without question.Moreover, my wife was approached and told to turn off her phone under the mistaken belief she was taking pictures, even though she was simply making a phone call. This incident further highlights the targeted and disrespectful treatment we received during our stay.In addition to these negative interactions, we discovered unsanitary conditions under the mattress in our room, which appeared to be urine stains. We reported this to the hotel, but it was just another in a series of disappointments.We chose the Ritz Carlton for its reputation for luxury and exemplary service, expecting a special experience in line with the premium price of $2000 per night per room. Unfortunately, our experience was far from luxurious or respectful. Instead, we were made to feel like second-class guests, unwelcome and disrespected.This stay at the Ritz Carlton NoMad was not only a letdown but also an upsetting experience, leading us to reconsider our loyalty to the brand. We hope this feedback prompts the hotel to reevaluate its customer service and treatment of guests to ensure no one else experiences what we did.

For the price of our room, the accommodations were super disappointing. The studio "suite" felt much smaller than 650sf and the vibe was shabby, with worn furniture, a leather couch with cushions so misshapen it was un-sittable, and odd thrift-store knick-knacks on the shelves.  Drinks and snacks were free, and we appreciated the water, but found all the grocery store candy an odd choice.  Also, the nespresso machine had a used, wet, unreleased capsule still in the machine.  The welcome note with a bottle of wine and treats was a nice touch, but the sweets were stale.  Our room overlooked an adjacent building with a large mural of James Dean(?) - in warmer months when there would be some green, it might have seemed more charmingly urban, but in winter, the view was drab and a bit depressing.  The bathroom was the best part of the room - it was very large, beautifully appointed and the water pressure was fire-hose strong!  I also appreciated the dyson hair dryer.  We had a few meals in the lounge which is very comfortable (and dog friendly!) and the food and service both get a solid B+.  Front desk staff were friendly and helpful as well.   Overall, I'd give the stay a 2.5 - if the room had cost under $1,000, instead of $2100, I might give it a 4.

Do not check in early. Do not attempt to check in early Do not.  The A.M. front desk folks hate their jobs and anyone who attempts to check in. Wait until after 4 pm. Do yourself a favor. I'm in my 9.5 year as a Hilton Diamond member. I have been loyal to Hilton as I travel three weeks a month for work (and even own a timeshare in mid-town Manhattan) and yet to check in early at noon instead of 3 pm was a $150 dollar upcharge for guests or $75 for Diamond members. I said no. Normally, a hotel will welcome guests in if there's a room available - it's called hospitality and reduces the number of check-ins later. The morning front desk needs to learn this. It literally costs nothing to check someone in early yet garners good will. If there are no rooms available because they're still being cleaned cool. That was not the case here. So...don't do it. The afternoon desk agents could not have been nicer. They get what hospitality is about. They were kind, considerate, welcoming. This is a rebuild of the old doubletree that sat at this spot for years. This a a beautiful redo. Rooms are on the small side, but not as small as the Motto brand which are half this size. Great amenities, comfortable beds. The bar was lovely and bartenders great. The bell staff at the front door were so nice. The rooms are wonderful, but you get what you reserve, so choose wisely. Rain shower, a bluetooth speaker in the mirror in the bathroom with clock and nightlight sensor were my highlights. But, it's in Times Square so bright day and night. There are black out curtains on the main switch at the front door of your room which can also control all the lights. Will stay again. But will check in after 4 pm every single time.

Stayed here as family of 5. If you are expecting luxury this is not the hotel for you. This is an old style building but apartments are large with 2 bed (1 king and 2 single with sofa bed in living room) and 1 bathroom, very basic furniture etc. Small reception area on way in and lady on reception  very friendly. Uber from Newark to Hotel cost c$130 incl tolls and tip  They are clean and the location fantastic on 49th st and Lexington - straight walk down to Rockafella centre and about 10 mins from Grand Central station. Breakfast provided is basic but super for families.  Food includes cereal, fruits , variety of pastries , yogurts and usually pre-made omelette or scrambled egg and some type of sausage.  Breakfast area tiny but you do have option to bring back to room. We were usually down around 7.30am and it was packed at that time .  We had to split up with 2 at one table and 3at another which was fine.  The biggest downside for us was that as it is old, the air conditioning unit sits outside of window so our window never fully closed.   Our room faced out onto Main Street so basically you were sleeping with window semi open in NewYork and it was so noisy with sirens , cars beeping horns etc ALL night so we so hard to get asleep.  Also we could hear dripping all night- we think condensation from conditioning unit above us drip onto our unit (it’s metal) so drip drip all night as well.   The lack of sleep really was the only downside.     Our 3rd child slept on sofa bed and if you ask at reception they have memory foam mattress toppers subject to availability and this made sofa bed much more comfortable   If they could solve for the air conditioning / window situation this would have been better - after long day in New York sleep is vital!! maybe if booking ask for room at back as may be less noisy ?  …

I'm glad I ignored the bad reviews. I found The Selina to be an exceptional value for the location and experience. The staff was terrific, and the free welcome drink was a real treat - the margarita option was a very quality cocktail, not a cheap mix. Most importantly I appreciate they don't extort pet owners with exorbitant extra fees and were truly welcoming to my pup (we were in town for an AKC event at the Javits Center). Also the morning coffee in the lobby was a really good brew - I normally would go out to one of the many specialty cafes for coffee, but was more than happy with the complimentary cup. The room was small, as are most NYC rooms at this price point. I did not have a problem with noise other than the to be expected occasional street noise which was barely discernible. Music from the lobby area traveled up the elevator shaft but could not be heard inside the room. While I could hear the sound of other room doors opening and closing, I find that to be fairly common in hotels and was not bothered by it, nor was my dog. The room temperature was easily adjustable. I did initially feel a draft and some cool air but soon realized the window had been left partially open. I will definitely be back to the Selina for the AKC event next year- the proximity to Javits and Hudson Yards without being in the gritty really busy Times Square area was perfect.

Fantastic location. Very central all the main tourist hotspots. Easy access to public transport either by bus or nearby Grand Central Station. It’s a historic hotel. So has a certain style. Fabulous corner room. On the 19th floor we actually had a nice view of the east river and some beautiful sunrises (not that early as it was winter!) Access is an issue for us with an electric wheelchair.  Now we don’t need an accessible room as such. As long as the showers are walking in. We had space to park the wheelchair in the room. The doors were wide enough to get the chair through. The lifts were large enough for the wheelchair + 3 to get in. Although a little manoeuvring required. Good sized bathroom. Very comfortable beds/pillows. Heating -and a/c easy to control and TV (if you have time to watch anything in NYC! Again whilst the hotel cannot be adapted fully due to its historic nature, there was a ramp promptly put out for us every time we needed. Particular thanks to Jose and Shafiq the doormen who went above and beyond with assistance and advice. We had a puncture in the wheelchair. Jose even used  his own car to help us get air in the tyre! There’s a smaller limited Starbucks/bar in the lobby area which is really handy. Friendly helpful staff and a great experience all in and good value.

The room was a lot bigger than most in NYC at this price point, beds were comfy & clean and the location for access to Bryant Park, Rockefeller Center, etc can’t be beat … BUT this place is depressing.  It’s great if you only plan on sleeping there.   Throughout the early 2010s, I remember loving the Royalton lobby for happy hours etc —  a known spot for cozy meetups in front of fireplaces with great cocktails.   Now some of that beautiful lobby furniture is ripped and it’s a total ghost town. No food despite a beautiful (closed) restaurant one site.   No coffee AT ALL!!! Just bottled water at check in. This means when your kids wake up hungry at 6:30 in the AM, you walk down the street in semi darkness to get coffee & muffins.  The rooms & hallways are cute and retro but in serious disrepair. Gross carpet & cracked stone in the room, ancient radiator, ancient outlets. No detail in the room appears to have been updated since about 1985.   For one night it was a fine stay — and beds were great! But it was just very odd and felt kinda creepy. There were also some strange relics in the bathroom that must’ve been chic back in the ‘80s (see pic).   Decent price, awesome location, but needs an overhaul, including serious TLC for the lobby plus food & COFFEE to make this place feel like a quality midtown hotel.…

Non toxic in nearly every way. This very natural hotel setting which is clean and comfortable. The staff is easy going, kind, and helpful.   The environment is restful with a biophillic approach. Hardwood used on doors and drawers with a linseed type finish. Wool is used for the carpets and the beds have dust mite zipped covers on the mattress. There are no strong chemical odors of any kind. The doors are heavy and alleviated hallway noise. The housekeeping was excellent and turn down service thoughtful with children’s slippers and macaroons complimentary every night.   The only thing I would say is the lotion and soaps are heavy with perfume so bring your own if sensitive. The bar soap was the only product we used. The lobby is a little cold in winter but on 4th floor you have comfortable cozy restaurant. They could fix this possibly this with entry heaters or supplemental in their garden lounge. The shared public restrooms are all male/female which left a lot of pee on the seats. I think better attention could be spent in this area or designation for sexes would be helpful or plan on using your room if you have small children as I do.   The food is excellent farm to table options without organic listed. The restaurant staff including wait staff are very welcoming and polite. Reservations required for main dining Zou Zou. It’s excellent! My only complaint here was watching the expediter touch things like a marker and items handed to her by staff then place her bare hands into the herbs and food bowls. I know I’m a germ a phobe by many standards but this is how people get sick.   Location is near Hudson Yard with an emphasis on sustainability. The Edge is one of NYC’s latest attractions which was worth the ticket price is not too crowed as when we visited the lines were not long. There is a Whole Foods with in steps of the hotel which was great for glass bottled water and necessary items. The Pendry uses plastic bottled water but provides plenty  in the rooms.   The nearby shopping is all the usual big chain suspects with high end luxury on 1st floor. Our favorite store is Falconeri cashmere on the 2nd level which had great clearance sale for winter goods at the time of our visit 1st week in January.   Approx 20 minute ride to the West Village and Central Park but near the High Line. City Bikes offered right out the door. It’s very easy to get a cab at the Hudson Yard Shopping district and of course easy to get an Uber from this location late night.   We will definitely stay here again. We loved this hotel and understand a chain is coming to Tampa where we live full time!   …

The Residence Inn New York Mahattan/Central Park has got a late 90's contemporary art vibe - the lobby, elevators, breakfast area and common spaces have wall murals and elongated sculptures, I believe by the artist William DeBilzan. While the art is colorful, the rest of the spaces that the art occupies is rather dark. Just a personal preference, I respond better to bright and airy environments.The hotel room - a studio with a city view, has a cute boutique feel. The kitchen has a fridge and microwave which is great for microwaving leftover NYC pizza. The location is ideal if you are in town to watch a Broadway show. Walk in one direction for Times Square and the other direction for Central Park. We chose this hotel because it was the best priced and located hotel from the Marriott Bonvoy chain in the Manhattan area. It also included free breakfast. The breakfast area gets rather busy, but everything in Manhattan gets rather busy. If I were to stay in the city again, I'm on the fence about whether or not I'd return here, just because I'd like to compare it to another Marriott Bonvoy hotel. Otherwise, if you like the art vibe and are collecting Marriott Bonvoy points, this is a good city stay.

Arriving at the frontdesk I was impressed by the vibe. It looked fun after along day of work. But then it started : 1 hr to check in although payment was made before by my company. It became a problem later that week as the sun was shining. Next morning going to complementary breakfast with a voucher that had to be collected every morning. Actually breakfast was not free but 5,44 the first couple of days, then it changed. It was free but no choice anymore, and then it changed again.. Surprisingly there was no houskeeping for the first 4 days untill I asked the frontdesk (also very friendly but not trained) and then housekeeping came in even with 'do not disturb' sign on the door. Laundry : this is a disaster - had to way 3 days after depositing my laundry, It came back in a plastic bag not ironed and the shirts were not dry cleaned as requested. Upon check out on day 10 there was still a pair of trousers missing. I didnt get them back yet. The hotel should stop doing business with this supplier.The bar/restaurant is great at night, the staff is wonderfull. Food is pricy for what it is. Following my recent stay, I sensed an unsettling air about the hotel and took to scouring reviews across various platforms. I found myself nodding along with several unfavorable reviews that mirrored my own sentiments.  My visits to Park Hyatt New York were twofold - one in July and another during the festive Christmas period - and they were starkly disparate experiences, akin to heaven and hell. Regrettably, the most recent stay aligned more with the negative impressions voiced by other reviewers.  The hotel boasts a superb location, splendid rooms, and excellent amenities such as the gym and pool. The culinary offerings are commendable overall. However, the service and hospitality fell woefully short of expectations for a purportedly luxury establishment charging upwards of $1200 per day.  Contrary to the warm reception I've received at other Hyatt properties like Grand Hyatt, Hyatt Centric, or Hyatt Place, there was a noticeable lack of proactive engagement at Park Hyatt New York. Despite my globalist status, the hotel seemed indifferent.  Check-in was less than welcoming; the staff at the desk omitted pertinent details about the hotel, and while it felt unwelcoming, I cannot substantiate this claim. Nonetheless, the disparity from my previous visit, which exuded a more luxurious check-in experience, was evident.  The breakfast service mirrored the disappointing narrative echoed by other guests. Excessive waits for menus and coffee became the norm. Strangely, some patrons received immediate attention while we languished without explanation. Throughout the meal, no staff checked in on us, marking a below-par service experience, a far cry from what's expected at a luxury hotel. Furthermore, the lobster scrambled eggs lacked the promised richness of lobster, a stark deviation from prior experiences.  It's disheartening to voice grievances about a hotel that touts itself as luxurious. The service offered falls short of the hotel's prestigious name. Regrettably, I won't return to test if service standards improve. Instead, I'll seek out a different luxury hotel for future stays.  To offer fairness, I must commend the service and the restaurant manager from my earlier visit in July 2023. It's unfortunate that their excellence wasn't replicated during this recent stay. …

The room felt like a boutique hotel experience - we had two full beds and the room felt huge for NYC accommodations! The bathroom and shower were modern, lots of storage space in the closet, and the room came with a complimentary umbrella for use. Great view of the city, but was unfortunately partially blocked by some scaffolding when we were there.  The only criticism that I have is that the lobby smelled like gas for the duration of our short trip - I'm guessing that's from the street or neighboring building, but it did make you want to exit the lobby as quickly as possible, which was unfortunate because it was very welcoming otherwise.…

We booked this hotel to see Greta Van Fleet at MSG for the affordable price point and the fact its a reasonable walking distance to MSG. After we booked, I got a bit panicked because of all the awful reviews I read on here. Not sure if this place is under a different management from when others have stayed, but I expected this place to be awful and it was quite the opposite.If you are used to Hiltons and Marriotts, then I can see why someone might be a little put off by its hole in the wall feel, but I never felt unsafe or uncomfortable at this location.The room was clean, the bed/pillows were comfy. No bugs. The TV lets you stream all kinds of apps you could want to wind down to after a day in the city and not just generic cable or hotel channels. The bathroom was clean, well lit, and had surprisingly good water pressure. The AC works and keeps the room cool. The photos shown on the listing are pretty much exactly what you get. As for the staff, everyone we dealt with was kind and accommodating. They provided us extra towels when requested and let us store our bags there after check out for a small fee (we both took public transport and weren't leaving till a few hours after check out).Yes, this location is about a 15-20 min walk from Times Square. But we did it and its not awful. It's an even shorter distance to Madison Square Garden, the Megabus station, and Penn station from the hotel. Overall, this hotel really surprised me and I think people need to manage their expectations when booking a relatively cheap hotel in a great location in the city. When we come back for our next show we will definitely keep this place in mind!

This is a hotel with character in an ideal location which does not cost you an arm and a leg to stay. I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel to any visitor to NYC, it is well-maintained and the rooms are large (from a European point of view) and very comfortable. We had the good fortune of being moved from our queen-sized bedroom to a King-sized bedroom next door and could compare the two and found both to be of very good quality. This was due to a problem with the room door lock which was dealt with very efficiently (the hotel technician is always available). We loved our stay here and were particularly pleased with the hotel's location which was within easy reach of the subway lines (a metro card for 7 days now costs $35 inc. card fee). A taxi fee from JFK costs flat rate $70 +between $7 & $13 + tip. Great eating choices nearby and it's no problem walking to 9/11 memorial or Brooklyn Bridge. There is always room for improvement and the hotel breakfast was rather bland and the place could do with some fresh decor. In particular, the room carpets will need replacement soon. Still, the Wall Street Inn is a great choice!

We're Londoners and New York feels like a second home because of The Phillips Club. We've stayed three times, for over two months each time and I would never choose to stay anywhere else in New York. The staff are beyond friendly, attentive and kind - they now feel like family. I stayed before being a mom and now my partner and I have a toddler - she was doted on by the staff and she still talks lovingly about them all. There's such a sense of security coming home every day, being welcomed by smiling faces who feel as though they care about you: it absolutely enhances every day. The apartments are modern, spacious, cosy and well equipped and daily house cleaning is a luxury! The beds are huge and comfortable, and for the centre of Manhattan it is peaceful and quiet. Access to Equinox gym as part of the package is also amazing - located right across the street. The Phillips Club is situated centrally and in a  safe and well connected neighbourhood: right next to the Lincoln centre, so close to the theatre district and restaurants and well connected via subway too - I easily commuted to Brooklyn during one of my stays. As a mom now, it couldn't have been better for my toddler: the Upper West Side offers fantastic playgrounds, museums and events. In short: I could happily relocate to live at The Phillips Club!

We booked a room specifically for the "city view" they are so sure to highlight- only to find that the blinds were completely broken. The pull cord that should have been used to move the blinds up and down to allow a view of the the city- the main focus of our stay- had been ripped off completely, leaving the blinds permanently down with no way to open them. We called the front desk and asked to be moved to a different room- only to be offered a room on a lower floor that did not have the same view. Why would we book a city view room, which costs more, and then take a room without the view we specifically paid for? The 15th floor already has a partially obstructed view from scaffolding in front of one of the windows (picture attached), and the other window's blinds remain permanently closed because the cord was ripped completely off. As it was 20 degrees outside on a March night, and we checked in around 10pm, we had no other choice but to stay with the hotel room we got. We were offered free breakfast, but we booked this hotel for the view, not breakfast, and we declined. When we checked out the next morning, I made sure to make the front desk staff aware- and they seemed surprised that our experience was so poor. When I called the following day I was told by the supervisor that management is well aware that the blinds in many rooms are broken because the Bentley Hotel was used as a shelter during covid and the damages sustained to the hotel during that time have never been fixed or updated. When the view of the city is your selling point, and you are fully aware that you are making people pay for something they won't get? That is a deceptive and underhanded way of doing business.

We stayed here for 13 days before and after my husband's surgery at a local hospital. It was a decidedly mixed experience.  Pros:- very convenient: short walk to NY Presbyterian and Memorial Sloan Kettering   facilities - safe location - extremely clean- maintenance and cleaning staff were lovely- having a full-sized refrigerator and stove and a small dishwasher was very   helpful- large and clean laundry facility in the basementCons: - uncomfortable beds- dated, unattractive furnishings- indifferent front desk staff. When we asked each day about mail/packages that we   were expecting, some of the staff acted very put out by our request- a surprise charge of $20/day to have a recliner in the room. Please listen to my warning when I say New York has so many hotels, and I can absolutely assure you that your money is better spent elsewhere.   My feedback takes into account that the room cost $7500 for a four night stay in a corner Suite in December.   The TV was a non-smart LG TV from ~2014. I travel a lot for work and this was the first non-smart TV I have seen in a hotel in a couple of years. Speaking of 2014, why does a room at this price point include multiple DVD players? Are guests supposed to be going to their local Blockbusters to rent some DVDs? It just immediately makes the room setup look like dated and cheap Motel.   The room controls (blinds/lights) were all made by the same company, but some controls were analogue while others were digital. They didn't all work consistently. I can only assume that some controls (perhaps broken ones?) had been updated to the more modern (albeit, still at least 5-10 years old) digital controls, with some older analogue controls not getting the same upgrade. The mix of old and new controls might explain the inconsistencies we had with raising and closing the blinds.   The room we stayed in had several lights switches mounted crooked. It may sound like I'm being overly picky, and I maybe I am, but I don't mean they were off by a couple of degrees - the main living room light switch in our room was at a ~15 degree slant. Immediately noticeable to the naked eye. It wasn't even loose/damaged - it had genuinely just being mounted at that angle. Obviously it has no direct impact on your stay as a guest, but knowing a senior hotel employee signed off on that level of poor workmanship makes you question the overall quality of the Lotte.   The air-conditioning duct in the kitchen had been covered with a large white plastic board and white duct tape. I don't know why, and no one informed us about it before we checked in. The air-conditioning in general was very loud; I'm not sure if this was related to the taped over vent or not.   There was a very large bundle of wires, all taped together with green electrical tape, next to the bedside table. It looked like a safety hazard.  The kitchen sink was blocked on arrival. The bath plug was letting water drain at a quick rate when we arrived, so someone kindly came and tried to fix it. Unfortunately the problem continued the next day and we gave up. The seals on the plug looked absolutely ancient. The shower head was very old, full of limescale, and water was low pressure. One of our sinks had some sort of flow issue with the tap - the water would just trickle out. Again, none of these issues are immediate deal breakers, but at $1700 per night you really don't expect these sorts of issues, and if some do crop up you certainly don't expect this volume of problems.  The art choices were pleasant, and the sofa, tables and bed were all fine too.   However, the general lack of finishing at this price point was very apparent. Big scratches/dents just about everywhere (tables, counters, floor, walls). Smeared, grubby, shiny marks on the wallpaper. Grouting between the tiles has started to disintegrate between everywhere there are tiles. In the small bathroom one of the tiles had broken off, only to be physically placed back on the wall, not affixed with adhesive. Again, a broken tile that's hanging onto the wall isn't going to ruin your stay, but you can find much more generally pleasing hotels at this price point. It felt like the Lotte management have absolutely no pride in the Hotel.  It felt clean from a cleaners perspective, but the scratches and general years of wear and tear to the wallpaper/walls/floor/counters made the room feel dirty, or certainly very "lived in" which is basically the opposite of how a luxury hotel should feel. We all know hundreds of other guests have slept in the same room and bed as you when you're staying in a hotel, but we shouldn't be constantly reminded of based on how worn out the room is.  My assumption is that the Lotte Tower rooms are on the absolute brink of how far they can go without being redeveloped. They need new... everything. Either we were unlucky with our timing and perhaps all of the Towers will be redeveloped in the next year or so, or perhaps we were unlucky with our room selection and we were simply given a particularly shoddy room? Either way, I'm immensely disappointed with the hotel. Being as frank as possible, I feel embarrassed and conned. By the time I noticed any of the issues we had already unpacked and my wife and daughter had already fallen asleep (jetlag). The more I walked around the room the more it became apparent that these problems were presumably endemic to the state of the Towers in general, and complaining would achieve nothing.   I also didn't want to highlight all of the misgivings to my wife and put a downer on the trip, so I decided to not mention it to the front desk. In hindsight I wish I had done. I genuinely feel ashamed that I paid $7500 for four nights in a hotel with this level of poor finishing, outdated tech, and overall worn condition.…

I stayed at the Bowery House about 6 years ago and had a decent experience. Although there was very limited hot water on that visit. I stayed there again last week for a couple days. This will be my last time. At 60 years old, I think I just need a place where I can have some privacy and be guaranteed a good nights rest. I did have one very bizarre incident. In the middle of the night, the guy in the next “room” (who, strangely, always left his door wide open) was making a lot of noise. At one point he was shaving with an electric razor, which was quite noticeable at 2am. I opened my door and popped my head into his room to politely tell him that we could hear him.  He freaked out and jumped up and started screaming at me that he was going to bash my effing head in if I didn’t get back in my room (I had only been in the hallway for about 5 seconds) Then he physically attacked me and shoved me into my room and slammed my door. I’m sure he woke up the entire floor. The next day upon checkout, I told the front desk guy. He seemed completely indifferent and muttered something like “Huh...ok...I’ll talk to him about that”. And that was it. A weird, isolated incident, I’m sure. But very unsettling. I also think that in the age of AirBnB, this place is way overpriced.

The hotel is clearly overrated and doesn't deserve the 4 stars.We stayed 4 nights (couple with 2 kids)  and got a room on the 41st floor. The view was great but that is pretty much all you'll get.I will not expand on the ridiculous room size, on the lack of privacy due to the bathroom' sliding door (leaving at least one inch of space between the wall and the door), on the impressive time needed to take a lift (you can easily wait 10 minutes), the daily queue for breakfast, shortage of food or on the lack of lobby resulting in constant chaos at the reception. In addition to the above, we experienced serious issues with the hotel' staff and management:- One staff member got angry because our kids took a chair from another table, as the hotel staff did the two previous days (we needed a table for 8 people  as we were staying with friends). She asked my son to "give back the chair" as he was having his breakfast. The staff showed an extremely unpleasant and arrogant attitude towards my wife just because she is not fluent in English.    - The concierge and doorman tried to fool us when we asked them to call a taxi! They did all they could for us to take a private limo/van by lying to us on the taxi flat fee. We had to insist to have a taxi booked. Finally, when waiting for our taxi which was 1 min away (according to the app) the doorman insisted for us to take another one than the one booked though the app. I learned afterwards that some doormen are “commissioned” for such practices… Shameful. I am not sure those practices are legal but Marriott seems to be ok with that.-   During our 4 nights stay, our room could only be cleaned once since the cleaning lady only showed up at 5:30pm on December 30th and at 6:15pm on January 1st. As I am sure you can imagine, we were all (our friends and us) in our rooms late afternoon busy with showers of the kids after an entire day in the city and getting ready for dinner. We therefore only got our towels changed… When we complained about all those serious points to the hotel, asking for an explanation and a partial refund of our stay which wasn't worth the price we paid for (no cleaning, issues during breakfast,...) we were recommended to direct our complaint to booking.com since we made the reservation through their website. Stay away from this hotel, they are better options nearby maybe with a less stunning view but at least you won't come back pissed off with the impression of having been considered as a cash machine.

No frills, but very interesting building and rooms. The good news stops there, unfortunately. We had booked two rooms but had one party unable to attend at the last minute. Upon check-in (early at 2pm) I notified the clerk and said I understood the no refund policy but that I hoped they could check and reuse the room if anyone needed it. The clerk said the manager was not available but would be within the hour. The manager wasn't around by the time we left at 4pm so I left a callback number to explain our situation to see if they could resell the room. We did not get a call back nor was there a manager on when we returned at 11pm. There was also no manager in the morning when we left but I was able to speak to one when we dropped by in the afternoon before leaving town. I was told that they could not do a refund because it had to be through their booking agent, and it was too late. I pointed out that I would have talked to the booking agent 24 hours earlier, but no one directed me there. The manager said they would check with the booking agent and get back to me (foreshadow, they did not get back to me). I was told the chances weren't good because the hotel had been fully booked and they had to turn away customers (that they would have sold the room to if they had handled it the night before as requested). Never heard back from the manager but did end up on an email list offering me to stay again in messages with no unsubscribe.If you are still eager to stay, there is almost no information on the interesting history of the hotel at the hotel as you might expect so nothing more than you read on their site. Too bad, lost opportunity to make it a fun stay. Also, the rooms had been upgraded but not completed and the towel bars were missing, and the toilet ran constantly even though I explained it only needed a new chain.And, fun fact, the Trip Advisor link they sent me for a review was linked to The Renwick in New York, which is probably a fine place but almost got this crappy review instead.So, yeah, not a happy stay and I won't return.

The Helmsley Medical Tower is an excellent place to stay if you or a loved one is receiving medical care at Weill-Cornell.  While it isn’t cheap, the location can’t be beat because it is such a short walk to the hospital, and it is very comfortable. When my spouse was discharged, the hospital staff brought us through a tunnel under the street and then up the elevator right to the door of our room.  That was just fantastic! The room has a full kitchen, which is extremely helpful.   There are some idiosyncrasies though; our room had four sets of small and large plates, bowls and mugs and forks, but only three drinking glasses, butter knives, tablespoons, and teaspoons.  There was a large and small pot, a small frying pan, a tea kettle, a set of bowls with lids, a plastic pitcher, a medium and large sharp knife, and a cutting board in the kitchen.  The kitchen has a dishwasher and they supply dishwasher powder as well as dish soap and a small sponge.   Things you may want but they do not supply include paper towels, measuring cups or spoons, colander, and salt and pepper.   They also do not supply plastic cups, so I was really glad to have my plastic Wildo Fold-a-Cup for the bathroom as there is no great place to put something breakable.  There is not a lot of room for personal items in the bathroom so we found our hanging toiletry bags to be very useful.  A hairdryer is supplied in the bathroom. There is a combination safe in the room to secure valuables and you set your own code each time it is locked.  It is big enough to hold a tablet or small laptop.  The building seems has central heating and our room stayed at 75 degrees plus in late October/early November despite not turning on the room heater unit.  There is a large laundry room on a basement floor, but they do not have any laundry detergent vending machines so bring your own or plan on purchasing at a local store. Amazon sells laundry detergent sheets that are super easy to pack for travel.  The washers and dryers are card-operated not coin-operated. You can buy a card for $5 from a machine in the laundry room and add value there, or if you plan ahead, you can call Hercules (the laundry vendor) they will send you one in mail at no charge.  You can only add value to the cards in fixed increments either at the card machine in the laundry room or online and the increments are a little different so you may want to be aware of that.  The regular size washers and dryers are $3 a load, and large washers are $3.75 and the large dryers are $3.25.  There are only a few of the larger machines and they seem to be more popular than the regular sized machines.  The small grocery stores nearby are quite expensive, but there is a Target with more reasonable prices and a decent grocery selection 0.4-miles away, and you can get a delivery from them for a $10 charge by Shipt through the Target app which is well worth it.  We set up our delivery time for right after we arrived and it was fantastic to have the groceries delivered to the door of our room.  A large Trader Joe’s is located roughly 0.7-miles away.  It is really helpful to have a backpack for carrying groceries if you are going to walk to the grocery store.

The Lowell, with it's breathtaking entrance and art/antique clad spaces, is a NYC landmark hotel,, front door steps away from the retail outposts of Madison & Fifth avenue and the Central Park playgrounds. My Deluxe Junior Suite was very accommodating with seating space and a ivy laced landscaped terrace. Fresh flowers, curated art work, hardwood floors, desk and armchair rendered a residential feel to the environment. Classic casement windows that opened, provided natural light, fresh air and cityscape views. A wood burning fireplace elevated the coziness of the space. A marbleized bath was outfitted with separate soaking tub and shower, dual basins and heated floor. The Lowell is endowed with an array of eating and drinking venues. The Majorelle is a restaurant offering a menu of French classics fused with Moroccan influences. The decor of the Majorelle is "well dressed" with beautiful floral arrangements and table settings. Luxurious dishes from the menu include: Snails in Puff Pastry, Grilled Branzino, Roast rack of Lamb, Duck Breast and Pistachio Souffle (the house specialty). I tried the Lobster Risotto....excellent.......and I didn't pass on dessert.....Mille Feuille.....a gem of a sweet. Seasonal bar bites and coveted cocktails can be had at Jacques Bar with a decor inspired by the beautiful Majorelle Garden of Marrakesh (I loved the Moroccan Mint Tea). The Club Room is an absolutely sumptuous communal place where one can enjoy a drink and/or a small bites menu. The Pembrooke Room is a renowned European emporium available for daily breakfast, brunch and afternoon tea. So, if you want the intimacy of a small luxury hotel with beautiful surroundings coupled to impeccable service................then try the Lowell Hotel............................ .............a gem of a hotel.…

This is a very busy hotel that is one building shared by common areas of the Townplace Suites and Spring Hill Suites.  I have stayed at both brands around the US and including other NYC locations of the Spring Hill Suites.  This hotel was built for packing in as many as possible.  It is bursting with mostly tourists and has very compact if not over run common areas.  Elevators can be very frustrating, full, stopping all the time and long waits.  The breakfast was so full that there were lines and in four days I didnt use the breakfast benefit.  The lobby is very small, mainly a desk and four elevators where people queue up.  While the price was reasonable, any one staying there should be prepared for crowds.  The first room I had was a double bed room, two beds. There was practically no room for anything else.  The bathroom was small and two feet from the beds.  There was no desk just a tiny little space with a tiny chair.  The bathrooms offer little privacy if your with others, many have remarked that the doors (sliding pocket doors) dont really section off the little bathroom, there are gaps that well, use your imagination on noise and even views by angles.  Just too many corners cut in my opinion on this design to maximize space.I did move to a one bed room (king I think) that was much more comfortable with a little seating area and work space.  I would definitely not call any room a 'suite' at this hotel based on the room types I stayed at.  Other spring hill suites locations and courtyards in NYC afford a much better proportioned room with better conventional bathrooms with privacy.  I did find the front desk people friendly.  But the overall experience here was frustrating and just too buys for a restful stay.

The hotel did offer us room service but we wanted something a little more lively after 5 hours on a crowded plane. We walked the quiet streets and found something eventually. Two other peeves were the noise factor in the rooms - early next morning we could quite clearly hear the business call made by a booming male voice in ( presumably ) the next room and also the lack of a coffee/tea maker in the room. Usually at this level of hotel there is a Keurig/ Nespresso or similar machine. On the plus side the water and soft drinks were available in the fridge at no charge ( at least that's what it said, although I haven't checked the bill microscopically.  The front of house staff and the bell desk were all pleasant and amenable. The location is a plus, the in room stereo system ( bluetooth enabled ) sounded great and the blackout shades performed admirable. Not sure if the nightly rate is accurate for these issues though...…

My family of five (two teens and a pre-teen) came to Manhattan for Spring Break. Finding relatively spacious accommodations for five people was a bit of a challenge, but came across The Gardens and booked it without difficulties a few months before this week.  The Gardens is to the east of Central Park in Lennox Hill. We really liked the location, which was away from the craziness of the Theatre District, and was a convenient half a block away from the Lexington/63rd subway station. Central Park was also very easy to access.  The hotel staff were very friendly and helpful. We had a room up on the sixth floor with two queen beds and a sofa-style pullout for our fifth person. The room was quite spacious, and had a kitchenette - very handy for buying some snacks from the Morton Williams supermarket across the street from the subway access. The room was clean but could use a bit of freshening. The blackout blinds were fantastic for keeping our room dark, and our family kept on an MST schedule for our holiday. The limiting factor for a group our size was the bathroom, which was very small.  The hotel was nice and quiet for how busy it seemed to be. Overall a nice stay, The Gardens was a great base of operations for giving our kids a NYC experience.…

I booked this hotel months before our stay through Booking.Com.  We started having issues with our booking before we even arrived when purely by chance I was looking at the hotel website days before our stay.  Firstly, it was only then that I saw that refurbishment work was taking place (I wasn't notified) and then I also saw that I had booked and paid for a bed and breakfast rate through Booking.Com and breakfast would not be available for 2 mornings of our stay.  I contacted the hotel and was advised that 2 mornings breakfasts would be taken off my bill.  The website photos did not prepare me for the poor state of the hotel.  Entry to the hotel was through the small restaurant entrance where we were guided to the tiny lift to the temporary reception area.   I couldn't believe the state of the corridor, lift and even more disappointed with our room especially as Booking.Com had advised me that I had been upgraded to an Executive Room.  Our room was nothing like the Executive Room advertised on the hotel website.  The room was very small and in a very poor decorative state, the bathroom sink had a huge crack in it and there was no bath as I had requested but only a shower.  I went back down to reception to see if there was a room with a bath and I told the receptionist on duty I had been allocated an Executive Room.  I was told that the room was an Executive Room (absolutely no way) and that unfortunately the only rooms with baths were on the upper floors undergoing refurbishment.  I was too tired after a long day travelling to take the matter up any further.  Apart from the cracked sink, the shower didn't empty when using it and so you ended up standing in inches of shower water.  Our whole experience then got even worse when we went down to the Benjamin Restaurant for breakfast on the Monday morning.  On entering we told the lady at the entrance that we were staying at the Dylan Hotel and had breakfast booked.  We were shown to a table, we were the only 2 customers.  We only had pastries and hot drinks.  On leaving we were given a bill by the young gentleman serving us.  We explained that we were on a bed and breakfast rate with the hotel and were told that they had no knowledge of this as they were not part of the hotel, we needed to have given them breakfast vouchers on arrival at the restaurant which reception staff would have given to us (but hadn't) and we couldn't leave without paying.  By this time the lady at the front desk of the restaurant had also come over and said we needed to pay the bill as they are independent of the hotel.  Their tone and manner was extremely unpleasant.  We managed to agree to them letting us go up to the hotel reception to get the breakfast vouchers and take them back down.  At no point during check in had we been told that we needed breakfast vouchers nor were we given any.  The whole breakfast experience made us feel so uncomfortable that we didn't go down for breakfast the next morning and therefore ended up paying for a breakfast we didn't have.  Unfortunately, our whole stay at The Dylan Hotel from issues before arrival, check-in, room provided and breakfast was very disappointing and stressful, and spoilt a holiday we had been very much looking forward to.  I've contacted both the Dylan Hotel and Booking.Com twice since the beginning of January and have not received a response from either.…

If you are lucky and they pick up the phone they tell you that there is only one person at the desk - how this at all possible?!- ⁠room cleaning - it is not done on a daily basis for some reason, you have to call reception (see point one) or catch the housekeeping staff in the corridor and ask them to clean the room. One day when I managed to reach out the reception the response was “I will try to ask housekeeping as it is not my department”. This is not acceptable. In addition the cleaning quality is very average as they don’t clean corners at all (previous guests left a bottle in one corner and no one picked it up until now!). All in all for the 8 night stay we had 3 (!!!) cleanings and 2 of these 3 we had to ask them to come. This is the level we have never seen before.- ⁠cafe staff is not really client oriented. When we ask to make an omelette they were really puzzled and started to discuss me in Spanish (is it normal practice in your hotel?), however they stopped immediately as my wife told them she understands Spanish. Another weird situation was when I asked the cafe staff to open a bottle of wine for me the guy told me there is cork fee (!), however another guy opened it with no questions. Also they rejected to give me wine glasses into the room. One day I asked the cafe staff to send the burger into the room he told me I cannot as I’m alone here (again!) but despite that he charged 18% service!- ⁠another point is there is no drinking water in the room(!). I had to pay $10 for the bottle of water. We have been travelling a lot but this is the first time we see NO water at all in the room. Also for some reason there is no electric kettle as if you don’t drink coffee and you want tea you need to go and pay for it in the cafe. My wife caught a cold and she had to drink hot tea every day 3-4 times a day paying $5 per tea! I spoke to the hotel manager but she didn’t seem too much client oriented as well. She was very formal and was more giving an excuses (“room services sometimes late”) rather than helping. The same day after we discussed the above mentioned issues with her the room service didn’t come. And at the departure day when I asked for help with 4 pieces of luggage the front desk told me to go find a cart near the doors and handle the luggage by myself. The hotel manager proposed $500 refund but do you really think 10% off the total price I paid as a refund is enough when you charge double of the total price because of the holiday season?!- ⁠all in all the hotel rating is completely overrated. The only positive thing is location which is great indeed. The rest feedback about hotel is far below average especially given the price we have paid $4500.

The oyo hotels entrance is clean tidy and well decorated , the staff are welcoming and extremely friendly , the checking in process was faultless and simple also , going up to the rooms are the lifts which as expected for older new York buildings were small and cramped .The room are, well , basic to say the least , with tired carpets and marked walls , our room had a worrying slope in the corner which made you feel as if you were going to fall into the room below, the bathrooms are minimal and the tile work amateur at best unfortunately , the view from the window was directly onto a concrete wall but this didn’t really matter .The cleaning staff were friendly and professional and although the room was dated and tired it was atleast clean , non hot drinks facility’s means you have to come out of the hotel and across the street to Dunkin’ donuts if you want a coffee in the mornings .The hotel is amazingly placed tho, directly in Times Square a 30 second walk and you are into the hustle  and bustle of the city , with great travel links all over , use the red bus to have a guided tour as it’s really worth it and trust yourselves to venture onto the sun way as once you under stand it it makes travelling simple and cheaper , yellow cabs are expensive but you have to do one just to say you have.! The Central Park horse drawn carriages are a romantic way to see the park but you must haggle as they are expensive .The hotel over all is a three out of five , a few minor changes could bump it up but if you are only using it as a base to rest your head after site seeing it’s probably what you want , would I return ? Maybe , for the price I paid I was satisfied

I avoided booking here previously due to conflicting reviews on it's existence/reliability, but when I was throwing up on the streets of Manhattan and needed a place to stay ASAP, it was the cheapest option available to me. So in a dazed fog, hunched over on the steps of Grand Central station covered in sweat, tears, and other bodily fluids, I reluctantly booked and got the subway over to the location. After walking past it once, and throwing up again immediately in front of the restaurant next door, I made my way in and was delighted to find that it was a real building that actually existed! Desk staff were friendly and welcoming (partially out of pity I'm sure) and found my booking without too much trouble. One thing they couldn't find however was my room key, which was a little concerning. After a few minutes of looking for it, they resolved to just unlock the room with the master key and told me they'd bring me my key as soon as they found it (they never did, thankfully I was only there for the night so this was no problem short of sheepishly explaining the situation at check-out)As far as the room goes, you get what you expect for the price. It was small, it had a bed, a toilet, and a shower, which was everything I needed at the time. It seemed fairly well maintained and clean. I'm not sure it's a room I would choose to spend more time in than I had to, with the slightly claustrophobic feel of everything (including the tiniest TV I have ever seen) and the charming view of dingy brick wall out of the confusingly designed windows. But as a base of operations on a trip where you'll be spending most of your time out and about, it's hard to beat the convenience of the location for the low price offered. At no point in my experience did I feel unsafe or uncomfortable, honestly with the size of the building it's hard to feel a whole lot of anything. All in all, if I ever needed a place to stay for cheap again, I wouldn't hesitate to stay here. It is a confirmed Real Building that Exists, the staff are friendly, the rooms are clean and functional, and the location is excellent. As long as you don't expect more than that, you won't be disappointed.

an appalling, dirty, grotty corner of the Four Points By Sheraton brand, how this hotel can stand by its apparent four stars rating is beyond me. And if you're reading this from the Four Points by Sheraton group, please send somebody out for an inspection because this franchisee is asleep at the wheel, (and probably drowning in his or her own filth).First, there's a $100 per day "security deposit" that was placed on my bill without notice. That was discovered when I was asked to pay for my entire four-day stay upfront upon check-in (not check out) and was billed an additional $300 without being told. (didn't discover until looked at the receipt in my room).The rooms are threadbare, filthy, with dirt mounds accumulating in the carpet in room corners, rusty attachments in the shower, discoloured linen, and all the furniture covered with a patina of grime that made me want to buy a bottle of bleach, scrubbing brush and wipe everything down, from walls to furniture.needless to say the photos look nothing like the tired reality of this battered and desperately sad hotel which I think deserves its moniker as a catfish. There's no fridge in the room, no remote for my television, a clapped out coffee maker, and the tap water comes out as a milky gray colour, so I wouldn't even make myself a hot drink in the room.Do your research out there people and read the reviews that seem to come from genuine people. Avoid, avoid, avoid
