Not long back from a 2 week trip to New York City (mid-November to early December) and once again I stayed at the Candlewood Suites Times Square; I've stayed here several times now and for me this is my "home from home" when I'm over from Scotland; the staff are very friendly and that is what makes a hotel, whether it be 3 star rated or 5 star!!; the rooms are a good size and very clean and comfortable, a decent sized bathroom and a well-equipped kitchen area with microwave, induction hob and fridge/freezer plus crockery, cutlery and pots and pans - means you don't have to eat out all the time - and there are plenty of supermarkets and delis in the area; it is central for everything - bars, restaurants, shopping, tourist attractions and is less than 10 minutes walk from Times Square. If you're looking for a reasonably priced hotel in mid-town Manhattan then I recommend CSTS - you won't be disappointed; to all the staff, especially Laura who is just brilliant, I wish you all a very happy Christmas and a wonderful New Year. So until we meet again - Merry Christmas and Happy New Year

I’m a repeater …  I was here in early August to watch a Broadway show with some friends and said to myself I have to experience New York’s Christmas atmosphere.  As I planned my December trip, I thought where else would I stay but at Park Terrace - no point in risking or trying other hotels - I’ve found my home away from home.  It was just like a continuation … Beverly saw me off the last time and this time, she helped me check in and choose a better room.  It was like we picked up where we left off. Arlette and Kateryna also assisted after.  Ricardo was there to lend a helping hand to tag my luggage.  My room this time did not have a view, but it didn’t matter — it was clean, it had the amenities I wanted, it was a space I could relax and recharge and I felt safe.   The Nespresso helped as well as the tea selection given by the team - thanks for introducing me to Harney & Sons.  Don’t forget the unlimited supply of fresh drinking water - bring as many bottles you can carry.  The bed and pillows will bring you to dreamland —- they’re like clouds embracing and lulling you to sleep.  Then you wake up ready for another full day of activities.  The location is just perfect — close to great restaurants and bakeries, 5th Avenue, subway, bus stops, etc. With the Bryant Park Winter Wonderland - more options were available.  As I mentioned in my previous review, this hotel is a gem — it sparkles and shines where it’s needed.  To management - change things which have to be improved but keep your team - they’re one of the reasons I came back.    I’ll mention everyone I encountered who made my vacation a truly wonderful time — Beverly(plus points for managing to upgrade my room), Arlette, Kateryna, Ricardo, Yovanni, Sean, Raquel, Jean, Abdulli, Alvin and of course my chat mate, the man — Harry!  We know we encounter those who work at the front desk and housekeeping fleetingly because we have our activities to attend to.  But this team is extra special because they’re genuine - authentic.  They carry their hearts on their sleeves.  Thanks again … till my next visit. …

I arrived late (about midnight) due to a flight delay and they couldn't find my reservation. They told me to come over the next morning and they would hold my bags until my room was ready. But when I arrived around 10 am, my room was ready and I didn't need to check my bags. I appreciated the microwave and fridge (I'd requested a room with those features).  The room was clean and they even came in the next day and made the bed, provided fresh towels, etc. (something even expensive hotels have cut back on due to Covid-19).    They no longer serve breakfast, but it's not a problem to pick something up from the numerous stores/restaurants in the area and tucking it in the fridge for the next morning.   The toilet didn't seem to flush correctly and they sent someone up to fix it within 15-20 minutes.…

This was our third visit to NYC but the first time staying at Hotel St James. What a great hotel! The building is older and currently being updated but it is fantastically located with the friendliest staff and contractors.We didn't catch the name of the gentleman on the front desk (23/10/23 at 3pm-ish) but he was so welcoming with a brilliant sense of humour and instantly made us feel at home. We were allocated a room at the back of the hotel as we were staying a number of nights and it would be quieter. This did mean forsaking a view but having stayed at a 4* boutique hotel elsewhere in the city on previous visits, I can honestly say that the quality of sleep was much better - it was so quiet! The room had recently been updated/redecorated and was very spacious and clean. The bathroom, although slightly dated, was clean with a very powerful shower - lots of bath/hand towels were provided plus a reasonable hair dryer. This hotel is perfectly located - it's just off Times Square and it took us 5 minutes to walk to the theatre for our pre-booked show! There's a lovely deli next door, Starbucks and Duane Reade across the street and a wonderful Irish bar a couple of doors down - great drinks, food and atmosphere.Thanks Hotel St James. Hope to stay again soon.

I had a great stay at 11 Howard. It's in a great neighborhood, quiet part of SoHo, close to some great restaurants like Tyger and Le Cou Cou. Overall, I would stay here again.

We stayed at the Hilton Midtown Residences in a 1-bedroom suite for 7 days over the thanksgiving holiday in 2022.Let’s start with the positive. The hotel and the room were clean. The room was a good size for a NYC hotel room. The bar area and Lobby were very nice. The valet parking staff were quick and efficient. This hotel’s location is perfect for those looking to see Rockefeller Center, a show at a nearby theater or do some shopping on fifth avenue. Subway access is available at the end of the block via the 7th Ave station. Unfortunately, that is where the positive part of this review ends. The Residences is located on the 44th floor of the Hilton Midtown. There are only three elevators which can access the 44th floor. During the first half of our stay only 2 of 3 elevators were working resulting in 20+ minute waits on the elevator. Elevator access was chaotic at times with people packed into this narrow hallway and spilling out into the Lobby at times. The Residences Check-in is separate from the Main hotel check in. When we checked in on the 44th floor we were told that they would provide us with a discount code for the Valet. The front desk was unstaffed when we checked out of the hotel and there was a sign stating to see the Main hotel desk. I went to the Main hotel lobby and the gentleman at the front desk took my room keys and said he would go ask his supervisor about the valet because they don’t “deal with those people upstairs”. I not only didn’t get my discount but paid MORE than the $70/day shown advertised on the website and my reservation. Another incident we had when we were leaving involved the Main hotel bellmen. Since the Residences desk was unstaffed at the time we left, I had to go downstairs in search of a cart to get all of our bags and packages to the valet area. I couldn’t find anyone in the front lobby but saw a cart just outside the back door in the valet area. Upon coming downstairs with all our belongings on the cart, a staff member came up to us yelling at us about the cart and snatched it out of my sons hands. Only to abandon it outside the hotel in valet area. Fortunately, my son followed our property while I went to the front desk to check out. By the time I came outside no bellman was present to help load the car. So what was the point?Another issue we experienced was with the Thanksgiving parade itself. We came downstairs about an hour before the parade. There had been a flyer left in our room the night before with information about the parade. When we went downstairs to get our place in front of the hotel for the parade, we were refused entry and told we needed a wristband. Neither the flyer nor front desk at the Residences mentioned a wristband. So we went back into the hotel front desk to ask and were told they sold out of wristbands yesterday. We would have been happy to have purchased a wristband had anyone mentioned the need for one to stand in front of the hotel I was paying $900+/night to stay in. As a result, we had to go across the street in the back of the mob and couldn’t see anything but the balloons. Ruined our Thanksgiving parade experience. Other items I didn’t care for at this property include: The mattress was horribly worn and uncomfortable and the furniture was incredibly uncomfortable. There is no free breakfast or coffee in the residences. There is a coffee maker in the room, but housekeeping didn’t replenish it the last 3 days we stayed. I called once and it took an hour for them to bring us 4 coffee pods. There is no true room service. The “room service” in this hotel is from the convenience store like herb n kitchen restaurant and is delivered in a sack. I wouldn’t recommend Herb N Kitchen due to the prices and lack of freshness of things we purchased. There is a nice grocery a block and a half up 6th Ave and you can get delivery from most places in the city. No way to play subscription services on the TVs so you're stuck with their pay per view or whats on cable. Hourly phone calls the 2nd day of our stay from sales staff. It took 3 days to get a receipt from this hotel. The first one they sent showed $0. So Hilton corporate wouldn't give me credit for the stay. I was actually told at one point I didn't get any points because I wasn't a paying registered guest! I guess $6640.00 isn't enough to be considered a paying guest.  All was eventually fixed but it took several days. Incompetence and mismanagement is the theme of this hotel and Hilton will be my last choice of hotels from now on.

Horrible Experience while staying at the Bentley and dealing with the Hotel Manager, Steve Park.  I stayed at the hotel in January for 2 nights with my friend, in February for 3 nights and I will never go back to the hotel again.  The first stay we encountered low water pressure, so it was a problem taking showers.  I booked again in February and there were issues with the heater which kept the room hot.  The thermostat didn't work properly.  The second night an engineer came to "fix" the heater.  The same problem occurred as it was blasting hot air which made it hard to breathe.  I was being treated for a sinus infection and told the front desk.  I went to bed at midnight and got up at 4 a.m. as it was unbearable.  The third night, I had to worry about not having water.  The water was turned off from 9 p.m. until after 9 a.m.  or later the next morning. (BTW - the water seems to be turned off a lot as I heard from family who stayed at the hotel.)  I spoke to Steve Parks who said he was going to compensate me for $443 for the inconvenience.  This did not happen, so after multiple attempts to reach Steve Parks, I called the hotel, finally got ahold of him and he placed me on hold to never speak to me again. I was left on hold for more than an hour.  I called on another line and was told he left the building.  This is the kind of service the Bentley gives its guests.  Steve Parks does not want to hear from you and your complaints.  The hotel is old, not that clean, the carpets are dirty, and the bathroom had rust stains in the shower.  When you book at a hotel, a person should not have to worry about having a room that the furnace is broken or there is no water to go to the bathroom or brush your teeth.  The Bentley was an old office building and is not conducive to operating as a hotel.  My family has stayed at the hotel and had similar problems.  Book at another hotel - the Lombardy or the Fitzgerald and not waste your money on the Bentley.

My husband and I had probably walked past The Roxy hundreds of time, but never once had a real reason to stay. It was quite the pleasure getting to take a trip home and stay here, in one of our favorite neighborhoods.Prior to our stay I chatted with the team to see about any additions I could reserve or order for my husband's birthday, without asking was told there would be a gift upon our arrival for him in our room. As we normally travel for celebrations (birthdays, anniversaries, etc) this was completely unexpected and quite the treat. Upon arrival we were greeted at the desk and welcomed with glasses of Prosecco, which after a long trip was greatly appreciated. Our visit morning trip out for breakfast we flipped the signage on the door to share we were "out on the town", thoroughly shocked upon our return the room was already made up. In all my traveling I have never left for so little time and returned to our room being cleaned and refreshed so quickly, never really seeing any of housekeeping out and about on the floors -- quite magical.I believe one of the best and probably most overlooked aspect of staying at The Roxy is the white noise built in to the rooms. It did an amazing job blocking out excess noise. We were still able to hear the live music but it wasn't anything dramatic, just enough to be comfortable. A great benefit is if you don't want to leave the hotel you really don't have to -- you have a restaurant, oyster bar for happy hour, pool table and live music nightly, a jazz club, and a movie theatre! With the impending snow during a trip, if needed, we really would have been set.All of this is to say, we are already looking forward to a future visit.

It might even have been housekeeping that told me it just wasn't set up yet.  Again, it was too cold to walk about so we sorely missed watching.  AirPlay didn't work either.  The only other negative to an otherwise great stay is how dark the room is.  Nearly no natural light in 901 and I would guess the entire stack.

Sonder Henri on 24 in NYC is nothing more than a glorified Hostel. At over $500 Australian Dollars per night in NYC, I expected much much better.  The Hotel’s policy is as follows:  Do everything to suit the Hotel.  Do nothing that is helpful to the paying customer.  Examples are:  NO HOUSE KEEPING, in other words no clean sheets, no cleaning of the bathroom, no sweeping of the floors.  We were here for 7 nights in early Sep 2023.  Totally unacceptable.  NO HOTEL LAUNDRETTE available for  patrons staying there. Told to go to Chelsea laundrette a 5 minute walk away.  When we got there the place was closed.  If it was open we would have had to wait in there at least an hour for washing & drying.  This shows how uncaring the Hotel is towards its Patrons.  We’re here for sight seeing, not for traipsing around NYC to do our laundry.  POOR SELECTION OF TV CHANNELS PROVIDED.  Very small writing desk provided.  The lighting in the room is very weak.  The lighting in the bathroom is very poor - it was impossible to see where I had shaved my face. I’m not exaggerating, for what we paid we got no services whatsoever.  In comparison we stayed at Hilton Garden Inn Washington DC Downtown, and all the services were provided, including an indoor swimming pool, & it was much cheaper.  New Yorkers like to think they live in the best city in the world but they don’t.  Washington is clean & has beautiful greenery & parks everywhere.  Washington leaves NYC for dead. Give this Sonder Hotel a miss. 2 out of 5 stars.

Planned to come to the city for the opera evening at the Met and needed the place close to Lincoln center. TripAdvisor showed the perfect hotel. Except the rating was too low. Despite all odds i gave it a try…. Here is the unbiased review. +Location. The location is as good as is gets if you are planning to attend a performance at Lincoln center. The hotel is just a minute walk, literally across the road. Some  good restaurants like Bar Boloud and Boloud Sud are also a minute away, Columbus circle 5min walk, Central Park a block away, Broadway a step out. +Staff. Everyone from managers at the reception to housekeeping services were professional and helpful. No BS, no delays, everything run smoothly from check-in to check-out. +Dogs. Empire Hotel has a dog friendly policy, and not towards small dogs only. Big four-legged companions are welcomed as well. Rooms. Yes, rooms could benefit greatly from thoughtful renovation. But even with the tired decor, the bed linen was fresh and crisp, towels in the bathroom white and fluffy. As a frequent guest of the hotels worldwide I appreciate crisp linen and towels more than fresh wallpaper. Air con. Yes it is loud. However if you are not a finicky sleeper you would have no problem at all. Pity you can’t open the window, fresh air always helps. Alas, I just turned the air con off (I still got the noise, but the temperature was ok).  Overall Empire Hotel was an excellent choice for the purpose. At the price of $200/night I couldn’t ask for more at such location. If you want a spacious newer room with modern appliances be prepared to pay at least twice of the that price elsewhere. I would like to say special thanks for Pasquale at the reception for his professionalism, kindness and curtesy. And I certainly will be back next time I am in the city. …

I am compelled to express my profound disappointment with my recent stay at the Times Square Edition of Marriott, where my girlfriend and I encountered not only substandard room conditions but also disturbing customer service, particularly from the manager, Joseph, which tinged with racial bias.We were also accused of posing a physical threat to the staff.This accusation is not only baseless but also extremely offensive.  The state of the bathtub in our room was appalling - it was cracked and peeling, posing a significant safety hazard. The sharp, flaking pieces of the tub could have easily caused physical injury, a risk unacceptable in any accommodation, let alone one costing $2,600 for two nights. However, the response to our complaint was far from satisfactory. Despite the high price, the hotel was fully booked and Joseph offered no apology or suitable alternative, merely stating the tub was usable. He said " the tub was functional, but cosmetically unappealing"Joseph's impatience and dismissiveness during our discussion over the phone were profoundly disrespectful. He even questioned our calculation and communication abilities and insisted we visit the front desk for an explanation.  Joseph's handling of the situation was not only inadequate but also suggestive of racial discrimination. Despite my status as a Platinum Elite member, Joseph's attitude and decisions implied a discriminatory stance, especially given his refusal to acknowledge our concerns adequately and his insinuation that we were being unreasonable.When we highlighted the tub's condition, Joseph's offers of $250 in food and beverage credits or 3,500 reward points felt both insufficient and irrelevant. He denied us access to another Suite, despite availability shown on the Marriott app, claiming it was reserved for VIP guests. This discriminatory treatment was deeply unsettling.  After complaining to Marriott headquarters, he seemed forced to come to apologize. However there is no sincerity in his apology, when asking if he understands why we felt being mistreated, he refuted every points we mentioned before and insist that every decisions he made were entirely right. This behavior was especially upsetting to my girlfriend, who was reduced to tears by his insensitivity.  Most concerning was Joseph's implication that our presence posed a physical threat to him. This baseless accusation is not only deeply offensive but also a severe allegation that escalates the situation far beyond a customer service failure. His refusal to inspect the room, citing fear of our presence, was both unjustified and indicative of a prejudiced mindset.  This entire experience has left us feeling not only disregarded as customers but also discriminated against. It is unacceptable for guests, particularly those paying a high price for what should be a luxury experience, to be subjected to potential safety hazards and such levels of disrespect.  Moreover, it became evident that the hotel had knowingly assigned us a room with a damaged bathtub. This revelation, coupled with Joseph's dismissive and confrontational approach, severely impacted our experience. Not only was the bathtub in the room damaged, but the mirror and one standing lamp were also broken, and there were cracks in the sink. The bathrobe even had hair from the previous guest on it. It's hard to imagine this is a hotel worth $1,300 a night.   This encounter not only reflects poorly on the Marriott brand but also raises serious concerns about racial bias and customer disregard, particularly given the high price we paid for what was expected to be a luxury experience. We expect Marriott's corporate team to address these issues urgently to ensure that such discriminatory and disrespectful treatment is not repeated with other guests.…

I’ve never actually written a negative review for a hotel since I’ve had really great experiences for the most part but this place really rubbed me the wrong way. I was in NYC for the holidays and obviously understand things are a bit more expensive but for over $800 a night this was nowhere near close to worth that amount when I would’ve gotten better service/basic amenities at a Marriott Courtyard or whatever equivalent.To start with, whenI was outside looking at where the entrance was to check in, the bellman looked like work was the last place on earth he wanted to be and  just looked at me and pointed to the front door when I had a 50 lb suitcase and two other bags that I had to take down the stairs and through two doors myself. For what they and calling yourself a luxury hotel, that is unacceptable already soured my stay before I even walked in. The “lobby” if that’s what you want to call it is basically a coffee shop with someone assisting with check-in. Not my thing personally but if that’s what you’re looking for by all means go for it. When I was inside, the staff was friendly and helpful with my check in.Our guest room was clean but again for the price and it being a “four star” hotel, I was pretty disappointed. Two of the outlets in the room next to one of the beds didn’t work, the TV remote was not synced up to the tv so it was very difficult to change channels and the cable wasn’t working so the screen was constantly flickering. The bathroom having just 2 towels and a small wash cloth for 2 people staying there wasn’t enough. Again at other places I’ve stayed with similar ratings, there are extra towels, a towel for the wet bathroom floor by the shower (I came close to falling when I got out of the shower), bath robes. I understand it is an older building which is part of the charm but it felt extremely minimalist and not up to the level of a luxury hotel.The hotel is in a great location but for what they charge it isn’t close to worth it and there are so many better options.

In general, the hotel was really not great. But the service was.The rooms have all kinds of problems. We changed the room once and still had minor issues. It probably doesn’t matter to many short stay travelers, but we stayed for 4 days so we actually asked about it. They charge laundry BY PIECE. A pair of socks costs 6 dollars, and a pair of paints charges 19 dollars. So with the TWENTY DOLLAR per stay credit, we party of three can wash one pair of paints with the credit. Given the room rate we gave, we really don’t deserve this bare minimum treatment. If you want to rob your customers, just rob. The management and hospitality team is accommodating and they listen to requests. I bet they get complaints a lot. I genuinely wish the hotel improves their offering. You know what customers need, so just fulfill them. Lastly, highlight on bellmen of the hotel. They deserve full respect. They made our stay better, by a huge amount.Will I comeback? I need to think about it.

We arrived and were pleasantly surprised by the front area and the lobby there were very pleasant doorman and bell boys a plenty.  we checked in it was relatively seamless we were given a room on the top floor which we were quite excited about we headed to the lift and got out the lift and it was like a different world. the wallpaper was hanging of the walls the carpet was threadbare there was a "musty" smell, we round our room and entered and with no word of a lie it was awful. the bed was slightly bigger than a single but nowhere near a double I sat on it and it was on pallets it was unsteady, the bathroom was clean. the view was OK.  The TV didn't work I contacted reception to ask for a different room as this room was not fit for habitation. The Boy on reception wasn't happy told me to get my things and go back to reception which we did he gave us a different room on the 8th floor which was fine again the hallway was the same as before carpets threadbare etc.  this room was slightly better it was bigger the bed was sturdy we settled down there.2 days later the phone kept ringing and then the door went after 11pm at night it turns out the young boy hadn't notified anyone that we had been moved room and there was confusion they apologised and gave up 2 days worth of the hotel tax back which was very kind.The Hotel is below average and its expensive for what you get.I can't even begin to explain how bad this hotel was, think bad and then times that by 100.  I am under no illusion that you are not going to get any sort of luxury in NYC however this hotel wasn't cheap so I expected clean and of a certain standard.If you get a cheap deal ( and I mean cheap) take it but there is much better hotels for the small money around NYC.Please don't be fooled by the ( Instagram Hotel pics) they are not true.

Very central, budget accommodation in the Chelsea area of Manhattan. I had a single room with shared facilities overlooking the back yard, which was reasonably quiet. The room itself was basic, but had everything I needed - a nice firm single bed with pillow, sheets and blanket plus a towel. There were some shelves and a few hooks to hang things on but no coat-hangers, so best to bring your own. There was also a sink in the room, which was handy. The radiator made the room very hot initially, but it was easy to switch it off and the window could be opened. The wifi worked fine. Each floor had six rooms, some for one , others for two people, and there was a shower and bathroom per floor. It also was good to have a kitchen downstairs with a couple of fridges, two electric rings and a microwave plus some pots and pans, plates etc. Making my own breakfast and occasional other meals helped me save money. The location couldn't have been better - a short walk from both the A and E subways, and many sights walkable (depending on how much you enjoy walking!) Plenty of cafes, restaurants and shops close by. I didn't have much interaction with the staff - the guy checking me in was pleasant enough as were the cleaners. As there is no lift and my room was on the top floor (up three flights of stairs) I wouldn't recommend it to people who are unfit or have mobility issues. Being right across the road from a police station, I always felt quite safe walking home late at night! I liked it there, and will definitely stay there when I return to New York.

This was our first time using anything but a hotel for vacation.  I believe there are residents who live here full time along with units that are available for short stays. Regardless, we loved our stay here.  My only complaints are minor.   We stayed in a Studio Plus which, in our case, was a long room.  If you're laying on the Murphy bed, your fine but it was a little warm down the hallway where the queen bed was.  There was definitely a temperature difference so be aware of that. Another minor concern was the Murphy bed...it's not comfortable.  I didn't know what to expect but, since I wanted to be closer to the a/c, we switched beds with our son.  Big mistake...he could sleep on the ground and be comfortable but not me. Last issue is the sitting space...if you have 4 people, there's only really space for 3 people to sit and watch tv.  A couch and a chair.   Overall, though, we couldn't have been happier with the room.  Nice sized refrigerator, small but enough space to move around and not feel overly crowded. The location is great...on Wall Street so the Wall St Station is only a few blocks away.  Pier 11 is right down the street which gives you access to the ferry.  A lot of dining options in the area. Then there are the workers.  I never entered or left the building where they didn't have a smile on their face and say "hello" or "goodbye/have a great day".  They were attentive, helpful and, most of all, friendly.  Yes, the cost is a little high buuuuuut you're in NYC....everything is expensive!!  I would rather pay a little more for more space than be in a cramped room for the same price.  …

My family and Stayed @ Lotte in the towers from 12/18-12/20.This is a 3 star Hotel with a 5 star location with O star Customer service! We have stayed in various Hotels throughout NYC during the Christmas season for the last 18 years. We arrived around 3pm and waited at the check in desk for over 30 mins and were told room would not be ready for at least another hour. We dropped our bags then attempted to find a restroom in the lobby First 2 we went to were not open and the 3rd ones we found on the 4th floor were filthy. Finally around 6:30 I received a call from Anna Marie stating the room was finally ready and she would credit me 300 dollars for the inconvenience, This was never done. Tuesday morning called to get a reservation for Breakfast was supposed to be included in our stay because we booked with Amex and was told not taking any more reservations or walk ins for the day because they were so busy. Tuesday night starting around 11:30 we called the front desk because their were people parting in the hallway. After 3 calls nothing was ever done this went on till after 2am. Wednesday 4:30 am wake up to Head to JFK requested my car from Valet. Came down and no car asked the door man and he laughed stating they do not get in till 6am and I need to read the signs. We could not wait until 6am since we would have missed our fight to London. Now we were forced to Uber to JFK and leave our car for 10 day's @ $115 per day. The Uber to JFK was $160 there and $270 and 2-1/2 hours back into the city to Pick up my car after and 8 hour flight back from Paris. When I talked to manager on duty he offered me no help. Do yourself a favor avoid this place there are much better hotels in NYC were you can get a good nights sleep, your car, the credit you were told you were going to get and Breakfast.
